PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KILGARIFF

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 126 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia respectfully showeth:

The level of home ownership in Australia is falling as increasing costs, particularly interest rates on housing loans, continue to rise. High interest rates and the increasing difficulties in obtaining housing loan finance have combined to jeopardise the prospects for home ownership of many Australians.
Firm and positive action must be taken by the Federal Government to reduce interest rates on housing loans.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Government will initiate policies to lower interest rates on home loans and promote greater availability of finance for housing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MISSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter or urgency:
(1) That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
(2) That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 176 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 12 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I suppose the Minister's attention has been drawn to the evidence given by Mr Rupert Murdoch at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that the person who leaked the contents of last year's Budget to Mr Laurie Oakes was a senior Cabinet Minister. In order to allay conjecture about the identity of this Minister, I ask the Minister whether he will be good enough to indicate which persons had copies of the document in their possession three days before the presentation of the Budget last year.

—I did read such a statement. In my view, if anybody, any citizen of this country, has substantive evidence that a Minister of the Crown leaked a document, he has an absolute responsibility to come forward and identify that person. Let me simply say that to make a generalised statement is just not good enough because that is painting with the widest brush. I believe that if anybody has such evidence he has a duty to bring it forward. As I understand it, the Treasurer has made a statement on this matter. I want to make it perfectly clear that in my judgment and the community's judgment the Treasurer is a man of immaculate integrity and does not go in for these kinds of activities. I accept that there were no such basic leaks. The onus is on those who allege to come forward and prove this situation. It could have come from a Government Printing Office copy. It could have come from a thousand different sources.
—Yes, but we all know where it came from, don't we? We know who arranged it.
—If Senator Walsh knows I invite him to say; because, indeed, there is no greater coward's castle than this kind of technique.
—You use it every day. You are the king of the castle.
—Yes, indeed, I am the king of a coward's castle that lies on the other side of the chamber.
—What about in 1975? You were the worst offender.

—The year 1975 is being cited. I had hoped that the Australian Labour Party, after its statements in recent days on sales tax, would never mention 1975 again. As this is a serious matter and as the substance of the final part of Senator Button's question relates to information which the Treasurer would have, that is, which Ministers had the documents, I will seek that information.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister in his answer alleged, certainly by implication, that somebody in the Government Printing Office rather than a Minister of the Government had leaked the Budget, and as that allegation has been made before by Government Ministers--
—He did not say that.
—Yes, he did. I ask the Minister whether he will table in the Senate the report of the Australian Federal Police on the leaking of last year's Budget.

—That must be one of the most remarkable distortions that could be made. It is a form of double somersault. I made no such allegations. I simply said that there were a number of possibilities by which the Budget could have come into people's hands. Indeed, because the Budget was denied to outside hands widely this time, one will notice that not only was there no leaking but also there was a mass of misinformation, and all the Jeremiahs failed in that regard. I do not know whether the Government would be willing to release the results of the police investigation. I will direct that request to the proper authorities. I repeat that, if any person has any information as to who was the person, whatever the status of that person, who leaked the document, he has a very serious responsibility to come forward and tell us. If that person is not willing to do that he should make no such assertions. That, indeed, is a coward's castle.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED AIR SERVICE: PERTH TO TOWNSVILLE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to reports referring to a new air service being contemplated to operate from Perth to Townsville and return via Alice Springs and Mount Isa. As this new service will increase the accessibility of the Great Barrier Reef and other tourist attractions in Queensland to people from Western Australia and at the same time connect with overseas flights to and from Townsville and the west coast of the United States of America, will the Minister quickly ascertain whether there is any impediment to the granting of this licence? If there is none, will he expedite the decision?

—The Minister has advised me that, in fact, the application will be examined very quickly in the next few weeks. He also has a view that he sees no reason why that service should not be approved. He welcomes any proposal which will increase tourist activity in the Great Barrier Reef area and in Queensland generally.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the statement made in this House on Tuesday night by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in which the Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Repatriation benefits are also to be extended to members of peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces representing Australia under United Nations or other recognised international arrangements . . . after 1 November this year.
Can the Minister give an assurance that such other international arrangements do not and will not encompass the sending of Australian personnel, in any capacity, to the Middle East?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not thoroughly clear on the precise nature of the question and I am not thoroughly clear whether it ought not to be directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs as well. Therefore, could it be repeated so that we may understand its precise nature?

—The question refers to a statement made in this chamber on Tuesday night by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in which he expressed the policy that repatriation benefits would be extended to members of peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces representing Australia under United Nations or other recognised international arrangements. I ask whether an assurance can be given by the Government that these other international arrangements do not and will not include the sending of Australian personnel to the Middle East. I think that is a matter of policy which should be answered by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—I am sorry; I had not understood the nature of the peacekeeping forces being identified. That is why I asked for the question to be repeated. The matter stands as stated; those benefits would be extended to United Nations and similar types of peacekeeping forces. The Government has made no decision on the Sinai, one way or the other, at this moment. If it were to make such a decision it would then look at the nature of the force and at what repatriation benefits, if any, would apply. I stress that, as far as the Sinai is concerned, at this moment no decision has been made.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, is about metric conversion. I am pleased to ask my first question in this session on this subject. I ask the Minister: What is the current status of the Metric Conversion Board and its members? Have they been dismissed, and not reappointed? Is the Board still in existence or, if it is still in existence, is it anticipated that its services will soon be terminated? Is it a fact that during the parliamentary recess the Minister for Science and Technology approved the importation of measuring devices in the imperial system as well as in the metric system and, has now approved the manufacture of such measuring devices in Australia?

—I am afraid I cannot give much detail in answer to Senator Lewis's question. I know he is very interested, and I am sure the Senate is interested, in the subject. I understand that the statute under which the Metric Conversion Board was set up has expired or is about to expire. The matter has been considered by the Government. I am not sure whether the Minister has made a statement about that. I will have to refer the matter to him and ask him to do so. As to the importation of measuring devices in the imperial system, I understand that the Minister has adopted a policy of permitting that to occur. I cannot say whether any have yet been imported, but I will get the latest information on that as well.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does this mean that at long last we have won and that we will be allowed to die in peace?
—I think that Senator Lewis will be able to die in peace.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, but since it concerns the Budget it might also be of some concern to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Minister notice a report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM program this morning to the effect that in Britain cigarette smoking had been reduced by 10 per cent in the past six months as a result of heavy increases in excise, and that that 10 per cent reduction was said to be the equivalent of two million people giving up smoking? What reasons can the Government give us for exempting Australian tobacco products completely from additional taxation in the Budget, while at the same time choosing a callous and unfair imposition of new sales taxes on family necessities such as footwear, clothing and furniture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of options were considered when forming the Budget and making decisions on what items would be subjected to sales tax or to increased sales tax. I did hear the comment on the AM program this morning with regard to the reduction in smoking, or the apparent reduction in smoking, in Britain, as I understand it, after an increase in sales tax or excise in that country. I think there are those who sometimes challenge the cause or the effect of some decisions taken by government with regard to smoking. Certainly anti-smoking campaigners claim that much of their work has had an effect, quite regardless of the price that might be involved. However, in deciding on the items that were to be subjected to tax, the Government took into account a number of considerations. In this Budget there is no increase in excise or tax on cigarettes or alcohol. The items that were mentioned in the Budget were those that were considered to be appropriate. In some cases they were chosen because there were anomalies in the taxing of similar goods and in others there was a conscious decision to include them in an indirect tax base.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. With respect to the Minister, I am aware that a number of considerations must have been in the mind of the Government. I ask again: What reasons can the Government give for that decision or will it not give reasons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Mason is putting forward the view that if there were increased tax on tobacco there would automatically be a reduction in smoking habits. That is probably arguable and I do not know that I can pursue that argument here. There are those who hold strongly to the view that cigarette smoking is a health hazard. I think a great deal has been written and said about that. As far as the Government is concerned, there was no increase on this particular item in this Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the Northern Territory Government has prepared changes to its laws concerning Aboriginal land rights which, in the judgment of the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council, reduce Aboriginal rights provided for in the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act? Is the Minister also aware that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, is insisting on a final response to these very recently proposed changes being made by next Monday? Given that the land councils represent many tribes in the Northern Territory, does the Minister agree that the councils should be given adequate time to discuss with the tribes any proposed changes affecting their rights? Will the Minister request Mr Everingham to allow adequate time for proper consultation procedures before any changes are made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Ryan's question. The Senate will be aware that, following concerns expressed a year and a half ago, my predecessor invited Mr Rowland, Q.C., to produce a document relating to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and some problems which may exist in relation to that Act. That document has now been public for 9 or 10 months-I think I tabled it in this place-and it has been the subject of discussion. It is true that some of the administration of land rights matters rests with the Commonwealth, through the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, and some rests with the Northern Territory. It is true that some aspects of the Act have been of concern to the Northern Territory Government and to interests in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: What is not generally known is that discussions have been going on for some six months or so between the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and the three land councils-the Tiwi Land Council, the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council-as to how this matter should be approached. During this time it has been possible to identify the issues and to work towards the production of a document-presumably an agreed document-which may identify what would be satisfactory to all the parties involved. It would be desirable to make some provision throughout the Northern Territory for excision areas for what are called gibb communities. Senators Kilgariff and Robertson will know what the gibb communities are. They are communities which cannot make a claim under the land rights Act but still need living areas on pastoral properties. At the same time, it is desirable that we examine some of the areas of the land rights Act which give rise to concern. Already there have been three full formal meetings between the Northern Territory Government, the land councils and the Commonwealth Government. A further meeting is planned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been personally involved?

—I have been present at all of the meetings. I had the opportunity of talking to the members of the Central Land Council about a week ago and I will be talking to the members of the Northern Land Council this week. We are seeking an agreed position. Of course, anything that emerges from these discussions but does not represent an agreed position will be most difficult to progress. I hope that all of the interests of the Central Land Council, the Northern Land Council and the Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments can be accommodated in a final agreement.
—There is not too much agreement yet.
—It is very close.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of a report in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser that 'funds for salinity reduction have been cut out altogether'? Is it a fact that in 1980-81 funds for salinity reduction in South Australia totalled $2.3m? Will the Minister confirm that the report is incorrect and that funds for salinity reduction have not been cut out? Will the Minister advise when and how the allocation for such purposes will take place? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the particular problems of South Australia in relation thereto will be borne in mind in making such allocation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Hill and congratulate him upon his first question in the Senate. I acknowledge his interest in the River Murray system, a matter which is of very great interest to all responsible South Australians. I say emphatically that the report in the Adelaide Advertiser is totally incorrect. The funds for salinity control in all three States-South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales-will be made available as they have in the past. As honourable senators will know from their perusal of the Budget Papers, funds for the overall National Water Resources Program will be increased significantly to $35m this year. The practice is that when the quantum is determined each of the States is invited to make its submissions concerning priorities for particular purposes. These are then examined. That will be done this year also. Then the precise amounts to be devoted to salinity control will be considered. South Australian senators may be assured that South Australia's needs will be borne in mind when that is done.

ANSWER.PARA: I comment also that in the near future there will be discussions between the Premiers concerned, the Prime Minister and me on the overall River Murray system. Of course, the greatest continuous solution of the problem would be something that we do not have in Australia, and that is continuity of rainfall. The rainfall in recent weeks has filled the Hume Reservoir and created there a need for some spillage. The filling of the Dartmouth Dam storage also is under way, and that will bring long term benefit. A big flush is moving down the River Murray. The mouth of the Murray is now open. For the early and middle future the threat is not as real, although that is not to be taken in any way to be any kind of reason for not proceeding for the future. We will be looking in particular at means of bringing about new kinds of irrigation practices along the Murray, particularly in Victoria, so that the salt table is not lifted and we do not have deep water flooding.

All of the discussions are taking place. The key to it all is as a start the signing of the new River Murray Waters Agreement which will give to the River Murray Commission responsibility not only for quantity control but also for quality control. As soon as that is done a great advance will be made. The problem in respect of Adelaide is one of turbidity, not salinity. That is a matter for filtration. Steps to correct this problem are progressing. This Government has provided a very large amount of funds for this project, the first stage of which is nearing completion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR VETERANS' AFFAIRS: VISIT TO THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Carrick congratulated Senator Hill, and I congratulate you on your elevation to the position of President. My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. On what dates did he visit the United States of America in the last few months? Was that visit for the purpose of examining United States facilities for its Vietnam veterans? Which officers were responsible for arranging the Minister's itinerary? Did his itinerary include formal or informal discussions with the United States congressional grouping known as Vietnam Veterans in Congress? If not, why not? Did the Chairman of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress write to the Minister on 31 July 1981? I ask the Minister whether that letter stated:

QUESTION.PARA: We would like to state our disappointment that you made no effort to meet with representatives of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress Caucus.
I ask the Minister whether the letter further stated:
Your decision to (formulate policy) without the benefit of consultation with our Caucus is . . . a disappointment and a discourtesy.

Will the Minister now table his reply to the Chairman of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress? Finally, does the Minister not agree that this letter destroys the credibility of the statements he made on his return from the United States of America?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I have written down every point to which Senator Keeffe requires an answer, but I will obtain the information if he requires any more than what I will say now. The dates were roughly from 16 June until 2 July this year. The arrangements in connection with the trip were made by the Australian Embassy in Washington in conjunction with officers in my Department. The body to which the honourable senator referred-the Vietnam Veterans in Congress-was not a body of which I was made aware at the time at which my itinerary was organised. However, I did meet several people who were in fact involved in the veterans' committees within the Congress of the United States. Yes, I have received a letter from that organisation. As I have indicated, I was not previously aware of the existence of the organisation; neither, I am assured, were my officers in this case. So there is no evidence within my possession that in fact it is a public body or that in any way it made its presence felt to the Australian Embassy. Lastly, I have not yet replied to that letter because it came into my hands only in the last week.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. When the Minister replies to the Vietnam Veterans in Congress-he would be aware that this body is made up of both Republicans and Democrats-will he table a copy of that reply in this chamber?
—Yes.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources advise the Senate of the Government's understanding of the present situation concerning the oil glut on world markets and the ramifications this will have in Australia? Can the Minister also advise the Senate of the possible effects of a stabilised price agreement between member nations of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries on our parity pricing policy if that agreement brought about a reduction in the price of oil on the world market? Is such an agreement likely to reduce the cost per barrel in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators may know, recently I attended and was privileged to chair the International Energy Agency meeting of consumer countries. I then had the responsibility, as Chairman, of undertaking discussions with the leaders of OPEC including Sheik Yamani. Therefore, the substance of what Senator Kilgariff is saying and what is being reported in the Press has some immediacy in my mind.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to his first point, the Australian import parity price is currently based on the Saudi Arabian light market crude price of $US32 a barrel. This results in a price for Bass Strait oil of some $30.79. While there have been some price reductions in the spot market and some discounts reported on higher priced oil sold by other countries, the Saudi Arabian market price has not been reduced. Current discussions in OPEC do not suggest that this price will be reduced. In fact, reports suggest that in seeking price unification Saudi Arabia may be considering a modest increase in the market price to perhaps $US34 a barrel. Sheik Yamani indicated to me his desire to seek to get agreement by other OPEC countries to bring down their prices from $US38-$US39 a barrel to about $US34. If this were done Saudi Arabia would consider moving upwards to $US34 so that that would create stability in the world oil price.

If that occurs the Government will give consideration to any necessary adjustment to the Australian import parity price in the usual way. Consistent with previous practice, any adjustment in the Australian price would apply from 1 January 1982. However, the outcome of the OPEC discussions is not clear at this stage. I would not like to speculate further on possible pricing adjustments. These pricing developments reflect changed circumstances in the world oil market. During 1981 the world oil market has changed from a tightness and a potential shortfall to a temporary surplus. I stress the word 'temporary'. The major improvement in the Western world's oil supply and demand balance has resulted from falling demand, reflecting energy conservation and fuel switching. At the same time Saudi Arabia has had a high daily output of about some 10 million barrels. Iraq and Iran have produced more oil than they had thought they would. Nevertheless, one should not take the world situation of temporary surplus as other than short term. Oil is being used at twice the rate at which it is being produced. There will be a shortage-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I may be putting you to an early test, but I would like to put to you the view that what the Minister is doing in Question Time is reading a prepared statement. His doing so in Question Time prevents us from taking up the matter in general debate. Could we have a ruling from you as to whether he should behave in such a way? Could we possibly have some indication of your attitude on the length of answers being given to prepared questions? Obviously this is a prepared question asked of the Minister. The Minister has a written statement from which he is reading.

—I hope that all honourable senators asking questions will make them very clear and concise. I hope that the same will apply to the responses to any of those questions. Having said that, I also want to say that when any senator in this place asks for a response from a Minister it is the responsibility of that Minister to give the proper answer to that question. I leave the judgment of that to the Minister.

—The fact of the matter is that what OPEC is doing in the world at this moment, and its future decisions, will be of profound importance to every country and to the world in terms of living standards and economic and political stability. Is it any wonder, therefore, that along with a brief on every other subject, of course, I have a brief on this most important subject? It is sensible for Ministers at Question Time to have expert briefs so that the Senate and the community can be given the information. It is a vitally important matter. If we can achieve stability in world prices, then the world will be able to expand its trade, living standards will rise and it will have a beneficial effect on all countries. I make no apology for the nature or substance of my answer.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Transport will be aware that Trans Australia Airlines has announced the withdrawal from 1 February 1982 of its regional air services between Melbourne and north-west Tasmania and their replacement by those of East-West Airlines Ltd. He will also be aware of the Government's present policy of subsidising air travel to Tasmania by 10 per cent of the formula fare otherwise chargeable by Ansett Airlines of Australia and TAA. Will the Government continue to set fares at 90 per cent of such formula as is applicable to the new operations of East-West into north-west Tasmania, or is the 10 per cent subsidy confined to the beneficiaries of the two-airline agreement?

—Senator Tate would know that the 10 per cent subsidy of which he spoke was introduced in April in recognition of Tasmania's heavy dependence on air travel and to contain the increase in fares on those routes to approximately the national average at a time when the new fare formula was adopted to meet the thrust of the recommendations of the Holcroft Independent Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. This formula apparently involves substantial increases in short haul fares. Whilst the East-West Airlines formula might not comply exactly with the formula that is being applied as a result of the inquiry, the Minister assures me that he will take into account the matters which surround East-West's application and, in fact, will examine them in such a way as to ensure that the spirit and intention of the original decision will be maintained.

—I ask a supplementary question. Am I to understand that the Minister for Transport is to extend the precise application of the present Government concession, by grace, by exercise of discretion, to ensure that its spirit is fulfilled? In other words, is the Government subsidy as presently formulated not applicable to airlines other than Ansett or TAA?

—I am unable to give a precise mathematical calculation on this matter, but I am sure that the Minister for Transport will be in a position to ensure that East-West Airlines is given proper consideration in this regard, depending upon its own special circumstances.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and is related to interest rates and housing loans. Can the Minister inform the chamber of the proportion of housing loans taken out with building societies? Is there evidence that building societies' funds for lending were drying up because their interest rates were too low to attract investors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the proportion of housing loans approved by building societies in the 1979-80 year was about 27 per cent of total loans approved. Figures that I have relating to the period from December 1980 to June 1981 show that the total deposit intake of permanent building societies was $165m. We can contrast this with the intake during the same period a year earlier, where the figure was $855m. The average for that period during the past few years had been something around $670m. Another interesting factor that was found in a study conducted recently, which related to the claim that trying to hold down interest rates was of assistance to those seeking loans, was that it did not just fail to help those who were trying to get a housing loan but also resulted in their being disadvantaged financially in other ways. For instance, low income earners were worse off because low income households, particularly those in the older age groups, were the ones which had a very high proportion of their assets in savings accounts. On the other hand, the households in the highest income group had the greatest proportion of loans from institutions charging the lowest interest rates. In answer to Senator Walters's question, I think we have to recognise the market forces that exist when people are seeking loans of this nature. The figure I gave in relation to 1979-80, of about 27 per cent of loans being in that category, is possibly one that is relevant in the more recent year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVERSION OF GOVERNMENT VEHICLES TO LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. The Australian Postal Commission has undertaken to utilise five electric vans and two electric motor scooters in an experiment which is designed eventually to reduce the fuel consumption of its large fleet of vehicles. It is planned to convert a further 150 vehicles to liquefied petroleum gas following successful trials on 50 mail vans. I commend the action taken by Australia Post and I ask the Minister: Can he inform the Senate which other departments have adopted, or will in the near future adopt, similar fuel saving programs? How many vehicles will be involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Foreman, if he has not received it already, I will ensure that the supplementary statement from the Budget which related to the conversion of Government vehicles to liquified petroleum gas is made available to him. The announcement made in the Budget was that some 3,000 Commonwealth Government vehicles a year, both from Government departments and statutory authorities, will be converted to LPG. Over the next 3 years 9,000 conversions will be made, which will be a very significant number and will be a pace setter for Australia. That decision was announced in the Budget and we will proceed to implement it. Australia Post, the Australian Telecommunications Commission and other authorities will be asked to be in the forefront of this experiment. We will ask State governments and local governments to follow suit. Institutions such as Telecom Australia are actively interested in energy conservation and are using solar methods. I think they are spending something like $1m a year on capital equipment to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: I note the development of electric vans and scooters. We would want to encourage that to the limit possible but, whilst the technology for LPG is known and the conversion is ready, at present the electric vehicle still has many disadvantages. Those disadvantages may, by trial and error, be obviated. One of the disadvantages is that the lead storage battery still has a long way to go. Work on the electric motor is being undertaken by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council and other research bodies. I look forward to their results. I commend the question from Senator Foreman. We will be proceeding to a major conversion of vehicles and I am hopeful that over the next few years LPG will move to being a very significant fuel for fleet vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about shale oil?

—The interjection was: 'What about shale oil'? I commend Senator Walsh to the report of the International Energy Agency which stated, contrary to the honourable senator's interjection, that, in its view, shale oil will constitute the most price competitive alternative fuel supply available to Australia. I commend that statement to Senator Walsh.

—I welcome the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the United States Senate led by Senator Mark Hatfield. The delegation's visit to Australia is a short one in that it is visiting only Sydney and Canberra. However, we hope the visit will be an enjoyable one and we extend to the delegation a very hearty welcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the decision by the Labor Caucus yesterday to vote against an integral part of the Government's Budget, a decision which the shadow Attorney-General opposes. I ask whether it has been brought to the Minister's attention that the editorial in this morning's Australian Financial Review states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Labor Caucus decided that all their own protestations of principle over the past six years were so much hot air.
Does the Government condemn this threat of the Opposition to block Supply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read in the Press some statements regarding the Labor Caucus. I have read in the Press some statements regarding the Australian Democrats. I do not believe for one moment that the Australian Labor Party will move to block any money Bill that is an integral part of the Budget. I do not believe that that will happen unless, indeed, the Labor Party acts as Senator Murphy did in the past. Knowing that he could not succeed in blocking Supply because the Democratic Labor Party would not support him, he attempted to block it. It is important to remember that in the past the members of the Labor Party have attempted to block Supply. All their ersatz protestations in 1975 were against a background that they themselves and their then Attorney-General attempted to block Supply.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may be allowed to continue my answer I will do so because the people of Australia are entitled to know. It is suggested that Supply should be blocked because the Government does not have a mandate for what it proposes.
—That is right. That is the argument.

—That is right, indeed. On no occasion when the Whitlam Government brought down Budgets to alter the rates of indirect or direct taxes did it foreshadow such action in its policy speech. Let me make it perfectly clear to the Senate and to the world at large that to state that the Government cannot do something because it does not have a mandate is of the magnitude, if I may be pardoned for using the word, of insanity. Demonstrably, a Budget is a secret document. Information on tactics and areas for raising revenue and information on Budget policies are withheld until the Budget's release. To say that a government must have a mandate for both its revenue raising and its new policies is demonstrably to say that the Budget is a public document known to all before its release. It is a fact that throughout history there has been no attempt by the Labor Party to foreshadow in its policy speeches what it would do by way of revenue raising in its Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I simply say that over the weeks ahead there will be an attempt to create an anxiety neurosis. Might I draw upon the words of the Leader of the Opposition in another place. He said that there would be some huffing and puffing for the next few days. There will be some huffing and puffing on this matter. But let me also make it clear that this Government will get its Budget through. The Government has a mandate to govern this country. The Government has a clear mandate to bring down a Budget and have it passed. Whether the Labor Party's words of the past were hollow or were matters of principle is a matter for history to decide. But the fact is that nobody could knock back a money Bill after stating that as a matter of principle he would not knock back a Supply Bill; nor could he justifiably knock it back on the basis that a government had not stated its intention in its policy speech. That is nonsense. In my judgment the public of Australia should realise that for the next few weeks we are to be held in an anxiety neurosis, which I reject. The public of Australia ought to reject the huffing and puffing of all those who sit opposite in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether in giving answers to all questions he acts on the sorts of speculations which were contained in Senator Teague's question this morning. If the Minister knows so much about the matter, will he tell the Senate whether the Australian Labor Party in fact made any decision on this matter yesterday, as was alleged by Senator Teague?
—Why don't you reassure us?
—Senator Teague could have asked the question of me if he knew his Standing Orders.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My question was directed to the Government but I hope that I will be able to ask a question along similar lines of the Leader of the Opposition later on.
—There is no point of order.

—I ask the Minister whether he is telling the Senate that the Labor Party in fact made a decision about this matter yesterday. As the Minister has given the Senate a lecture about the issue I also ask whether he will inform the Senate of the differences between blocking Supply, which affects the survival of a government, and blocking lesser money Bills.

—I understand that in the Press for the last few days statements have appeared stating that the Australian Labor Party Caucus had determined to block the sales tax Bill. That statement appeared yesterday in the Press. It has appeared today in the Press. It was the subject of questioning in the other place yesterday. There has been absolutely no denial of that statement by the Labor Party. The presumption of the Australian people must be that in the absence of denial that matter can be presumed to be right. If it is not right and if the basis of the question is not right, I invite Senator Button to tell the people of Australia what is right. In relation to what Senator Button asks about the difference between money Bills and Supply Bills, quite clearly the fact of the matter is that we are talking about the blocking of a money Bill.
—Who is?

—This Government is. We are talking about the blocking of a money Bill. My quite clear understanding is that in the past the Labor Party has seen great sin in the blocking of money Bills in the Senate. Fundamental to the Labor Party and, indeed, to its shadow Attorney-General is the principle that the Senate ought not to have the power to block money Bills. The mechanisms and the power of this Senate are similar to those of the American Senate. A power relating to money Bills resides in this Senate. That gives the Senate its authority and forms the basis of the six States having the power to assert a balance of State powers. If the statements in the Press are not true, perhaps we can all be the better informed.

—I have an easy question for Senator Carrick in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Did the Minister see the article in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 18 August, stating that the Cabinet is considering granting a sum of $460,000 to the Director of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs to evaluate the implementation of the Galbally report on the Post-arrival Programs and Services for Migrants? How can such an evaluation, conducted by members of the Institute whose very livelihood depends on the continued implementation of the Galbally report, be seen as in any way objective or realistic? In times of tight financial restraint by the Government how can the expenditure of $460,000 be justified in this case?

—Although this is a question which I think should be directed not to me but to the Minister representing the portfolio concerned, I think it asks what was the intention of the Minister and the Government in this matter. I will direct the question to the Minister concerned and seek a detailed reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the government's insistence last weekend that the Australian Broadcasting Commission stand down staff not directly involved in the broadcast engineering officers strike, claiming that such other staff could not be gainfully employed. Why was ABC management instructed to proceed with such stand-downs under the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act when the only thing the strike prevented the other staff doing, at least in Hobart, was putting to air two short news bulletins. Hence, those staff-24 were involved in Hobart-could and would have been fully and gainfully employed on normal duties involving, for example, preparing taped program material for the coming week as well as maintenance and so on, for the vast majority of their shifts. Therefore, was not the Government being quite dishonest about the matter, its action being much more like a lockout?

—I will take up Senator Coates's question and mention a few things about the industrial dispute last week which involved broadcast engineering officers at the Australian Broadcasting Commission. ABC television was blacked out as a result of industrial action taken by these officers who are demanding wage increases ranging from 26 per cent to 32 per cent. As honourable senators might know, they want to retain wage relativities that they had in 1975, these relativities having been frozen at that time with the introduction of wage indexation. The case has been before Deputy Public Service Arbitrator Booth since October 1980 and it is now in the final stages of being heard.
—Try answering the question.

—I am answering the question in my own way. Last week the ABC offered the BEOs an immediate 5.8 per cent salary increase back dated to 22 May 1980-more than a year and a quarter-without prejudice to any further amount which could be awarded by the arbitrator. That is very important. It was an interim offer without prejudice to what else might be offered. The broadcast engineering officers rejected the ABCs offer and took industrial action from 7.30 p.m. on Friday, 14 August which resulted in ABC television going off the air. As a result some very important programs from England that many of us wanted to watch were unavailable.
—It was hardly cricket, was it?

—I suggest to the Senate that had the Australian public been watching, the cricketers might have done better. However, transmission resumed when the officers returned to work from the first shift on Monday, 17 August. I am advised by my colleague that on 14 August he directed the ABC to invoke the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act to suspend the broadcast engineering officers who were taking industrial action and to stand down those employees not fully employed as a result of that industrial action. Stand-downs and suspensions were lifted when the BEOs returned to work on Monday, 17 August. I am informed that the officers intend to proceed with their case before the arbitrator and that they do not propose to take further industrial action at this stage. Senator Coates's question contained a number of other points on which he required elucidation. I am unable to provide him with that specific information and will undertake to put those points to the Minister whom I represent.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister had a prepared answer to a question that I did not ask, when he seeks the other information will he ask his colleague which State managers of the ABC assured the General Manager that staff could and would be fully and gainfully employed? Did the General Manager insist to those State managers that stand-downs occur regardless, because that was what the Government required?

—Quite clearly, that is not a supplementary question. However, I will pass that second question on to my colleague to see whether I can obtain answers to both the questions asked by Senator Coates today.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry: Is he aware of reports that it has now been confirmed that cartons of meat purporting to contain beef, and seized in Australia, do contain horsemeat and that these cartons originated from the Profreeze company's works for export as beef to the United States of America? Does the Minister agree that if this substitution is on the scale alleged-namely, that after 40 cartons of beef passed inspection at the Profreeze works records were then falsified so that 400 cartons, including those with the horsemeat, were dispatched from the factory-a large number of people would have had to be involved and that it is possible that people other than company personnel would have co-operated in this criminal fraud? I note that on 17 August the Minister for Primary Industry stated that the Bureau of Animal Health and the Australian Federal Police are investigating the situation as a matter of priority. However, in view of the importance of the United States market to Australian beef producers, particularly producers in Queensland who are overwhelmingly dependent on the United States export trade, and in view of the potentially disastrous consequences for meat producers, processors, exporters and industry employees, there must be no room for doubt in the future as to the thoroughness of investigations. All involved must be prosecuted and must face the consequences of this sabotage of our beef industry. In short, not only must justice be done but also it must be seen to be done. Therefore, would the Minister agree to propose to the Government that a judicial inquiry be instituted so that all allegations and information can be publicly presented and no doubts can be cast in the future as to the integrity of Australia's meat industry as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would certainly agree with the assertion in Senator Martin's question that the issue is one of great importance to Australia because of the volume of our meat exports to the United States of America, particularly our beef exports. It is a matter of great importance to the honourable senator's home State of Queensland and to other States with substantial beef cattle herds and beef export industries. I do not think there would be any doubt in the minds of those in the United States Administration, in the minds of the people of Australia or in the minds of people in this Parliament as to how seriously the matter has been taken by the Government. The Minister for Primary Industry has, of course, kept the public and the Parliament well informed as to what action is being taken.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the specific points raised by the honourable senator, my advice from the Minister for Primary Industry is that it is confirmed that the United States Department of Agriculture has detected horsemeat in boneless beef. Ostensibly that consignment was produced at Establishment 140C in Richmond, Victoria. That is a finding which can only be to the detriment of Australia's beef export industry. It is perhaps worth mentioning that this is a unique occurrence. Never before has a substitution of this nature been reported or suspected. As the honourable Senator indicated in her question, both the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Bureau of Animal Health are investigating all aspects of the finding and are arranging for samples of Establishment 140C products still in Australia to be examined for the presence of horsemeat. I understand that that examination is continuing with a view to determining the extent of the problem which we have and with a view to determining just who has been involved.

The honourable senator suggests that the matter would best be dealt with by way of a judicial inquiry. That is a matter on which, I think, the Government would defer consideration until the normal investigative processes have been used. I do not think generally it would be thought desirable to start that sort of investigation at the level of a judicial inquiry when the normal processes of law enforcement and inquiry are probably quite adequate to do the task which has to be done. Because of the importance of the matter I stress the points which have been made by the Minister in public statements over recent days. In particular I stress that the Commonwealth will take the strongest possible action if illegal activity is found to be involved in the shipment of horsemeat to the United States. Action will be taken to protect Australia's reputation and, indeed, to protect not only the interests of our marketers and exporters but also the interests of our clients who purchase our goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I would like to test your attitude to the practice of the Leader of the Government rising and seeking to have all further questions placed on the Notice Paper. I have said before that that ought to be done by leave of the Senate. But, if that cannot be done because of precedent, surely it is up to you, Mr President, to determine whether you will accede to that request. You may have liked to call further senators to ask questions, knowing, of course, that today some questions were lengthy and some answers were particularly lengthy. You would not like to exclude any honourable senator from asking a question, especially if he had not asked one for two days. Could I suggest, Mr President, that the question whether all further questions should be placed on the Notice Paper should be one for your discretion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, in response to your question of me, let me say that I would be delighted if I could give every honourable senator a question every day. It would make this job much easier. Having said that, I must remind the Senate that for many years it was Senate practice for Question Time to be extended in order to give every honourable senator an opportunity to ask a question. It was the Leader of the Labor Party, which was then in government, who changed that practice. I mention that purely for historical reasons. The present practice has been adopted ever since by the various Leaders of the Government in this place. So basically we have established the hour for Question Time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Further in response to your question, I repeat the hope that questions will be short and to the point and that responses by Ministers-unless otherwise necessary, as at times it will be in order to permit a complete answer to be given-will be made in such a way as will allow more time for additional questions to be asked during the hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Teague in Question Time and also in the Press reports to which he implicitly referred in his question, and wish to make a personal explanation. I do not mind being described as a man of principle by anyone, even by Simon Nasht on the PM program, even by Paddy McGuinness in the Australian Financial Review, even indeed by Senator Teague. But I do resist the suggestion that I am in some way a soloist in that all of my colleagues in the Australian Labor Party are not equally men and women of principle.The reality is that we are all men and women of principle and have foreshadowed in our statements a thoroughly principled course of action in relation both to this Budget and, more particularly, to the associated package of sales tax Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The relevant distinction that we have been talking our way through, and applying in the statements that have been made by various spokesmen on our behalf is that between-as was foreshadowed by Senator Button in his question this morning-on the one hand Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government, are matters of life and death so far as the existence of a government is concerned and, on the other, those which do not satisfy that description. In the former category are undoubtedly those major supply and appropriation Bills-Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2) in the earlier part of the year and Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) in the latter part of the year-upon which the continued existence of a government undoubtedly depends. Perhaps also in that category of packages of Bills that are absolutely essential to a government's existence are some major taxing Bills, for example, Bills to establish the whole system of personal income tax, which accounts for 50 per cent or more of a government's revenue. In the latter category are included those lesser money Bills which impose fees or fines or make particular appropriations of perhaps a few hundred thousand or even a few million dollars for some particular purpose, or Bills which impose taxes, generally speaking, and do not satisfy the description of being measures which are essential to the survival of the Government.

The sales tax legislation which is in issue and which has been the subject of statements by Labor Party spokesmen is undoubtedly in the latter category of lesser money Bills which cannot be regarded on any analysis as essential to the survival of a government. That can be demonstrated in a number of ways. Let me just offer one. I invite the honourable senators to consider the pure arithmetic of it. What is involved in this financial year is half a billion dollars as compared with a total revenue side of the Budget of $40 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I suggest that as this is a personal explanation the honourable senator should confine himself to explaining how he was misrepresented.

—Yes, Mr President. Might I just add this: Undoubtedly some confusion exists and some points will be scored in relation to this matter by virtue of the fact that I, in conjunction with many others, have since the events of 1974 and 1975 used fairly interchangeably the expressions 'blocking of Supply', 'blocking of money Bills' and 'blocking of Budgets'. I acknowledge that. There are ample quotes that can be produced of my saying that, as a matter of principle, it is inappropriate for the Senate not only to block Supply but also to block money Bills or Budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not making a long speech; I am simply explaining what is crucial. It is crucial to the explanation and it is crucial to the distinction that needs to be made and understood that whenever I or anyone else has used those kinds of expressions in all the debates that have taken place since 1974 and 1975 we have been using them in the context of the events of 1974 and 1975 when what was in issue was a particular category of Bills-namely, in 1974 the Supply Bills and in 1975 Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which were on any view crucial to the continued survival, the continued existence of the Government of the day. That was the context in which that discussion has always taken place; that is the context in which I and others have used those expressions. The relevant issue then as now is whether or not the money Bills, the Budget Bills-whatever sort of Bills are in question-are relevant to the survival of a government. That is what has been in issue; that is the issue that remains a crucial one not only for this Parliament but also this nation to resolve as a matter of constitutional reform. I believe it is unacceptable--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator not to debate the matter but to get on with his personal explanation.
—I will finish on this note: I believe and I continue to believe it is unacceptable in principle for chambers, constituted as this Senate is less democratically than the lower House to use--
—This is not a personal explanation.

—I am explaining my position, having been accused of adopting positions which are inconsistent with those adopted by the rest of the Australian Labor Party. What I am saying is squarely relevant to that. I believe it is unacceptable in principle for an upper House, a Senate constituted as we are, to use the powers which undoubtedly are available to it under the Constitution to bring a government to its knees by denying a government Supply in the context of major Supply and appropriation Bills.
—Senator, I suggest with great respect that you come to your point and that you not debate the issue.

—May I finish with one sentence. It is not, on the other hand, unacceptable in principle for this Senate or for the Labor Party within this Senate to oppose the passage of Bills not so describable, Bills in respect of which the Government not only lacks an explicit mandate but also in respect to which, given its pre-election statements, it has been profoundly dishonest and hypocritical.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: That public funding for political parties is an essential part of any democratic electoral system.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party proposes to continue to debate the issue of public funding for political parties because it believes it is an essential ingredient in the whole process of our electoral system. The basis of any genuine democracy should be that at least every citizen shall have equal rights, equal access to resources, the right to speak, write and assemble in pursuit of issues seen by the citizen to be important. It is therefore incumbent upon us as part of the Parliament and as democrats to establish whether in the practice of parliamentary democracy groups, citizens and parties have that essential equity in the whole process of politics. I believe no one can say that there is not a bias against small parties and a disadvantage against the Labor Party in the process of elections today. No one can say that there is not a bias against and a disadvantage to the ALP in the way in which elections are funded. No one can deny that the present electoral system is weighted in favour of the conservative forces and the conservative parties and that there is a vital and pressing need to extend the democratic process to equalise opportunities for all citizens, groups and parties to have access to the means of modern day communications such as the Press, radio, television, postage, resources and so on. Of course, this is not presently the case.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that the conservative parties, in particular the Liberal and National Country parties, have access to large undisclosed funds. It is well known that the same Liberal and National Country parties resist any suggestion that they should be accountable to the electors, the Parliament or its nominee for the large donations that are made to them. Of course, it is well known that these same parties used their numbers in the Senate in 1974-75 to defeat legislation that would have equalised the opportunities of all citizens, representing a genuine segment of political opinion in our society, to reject the Australian Labor Party's proposals for public funding.

The New South Wales Labor Government has, of course, proceeded to introduce a number of important changes to the electoral processes in that State. Firstly, it has enshrined the vital principle of every vote having equal value; the principle of one vote one value is now in the New South Wales Constitution. Secondly, it has legislated to establish public funding for political parties. In doing this the Wran Government has seen the need to extend further the democratic process. It recognises the evolution of ideas that has been a characteristic of the electoral system in our country. I will stress this matter of evolution for a moment. One of the greatest strengths of our system of parliament has been its ability to adapt to changing conditions and a changing society. A major change that our parliamentary system has to adapt to today is the rapid development of our methods of communications. I add that these are methods which cost a pretty penny, for in today's electoral battles only those who are able to use the means of communication effectively will be in the running. But the Liberal and National Country parties seem not to be interested in this essential change.

Let us never forget that it was the conservatives, the predecessors of honourable senators opposite, who fought tooth and nail against the introduction of universal male suffrage back in 1832. It was the conservatives, the predecessors of today's Liberal and National Country parties, who fought in this Parliament in 1928 against universal adult suffrage. It is the modern day conservatives who are still fighting the principle of one vote one value which is so much a basic principle of democracy and as such an integral part of the ALP's own policies. It is the modern day conservatives in Canberra and Macquarie Street, Sydney, who resist hysterically and consistently any suggestion for the establishment of equity in funding political campaigns for the election of parliament. No one can deny the impact of advertising. No one can deny the impact of propaganda or the bias existing in certain sections of the media any more than anyone can deny the growing monopolisation of the media by one particular financial group in our country.

Let us look therefore to how we can equalise and democratise the contest by removing the disadvantages of the minorities in presenting their case; by removing the advantages that clearly come to those who can pound the electors with their viewpoint solely because they have access to what can be considered almost unlimited funds. Why are these Liberal and National Country parties so vehement in their opposition to public funding for political parties, commensurate of course with the degree of political support? Surely a party claiming to be democratic, incorruptible and fair has no grounds to object to fairness, equality and accountability. Surely such a party should be sympathetic to changes that have been widely accepted in so many other parliamentary democracies such as West Germany, Sweden and Austria and in most of the countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-countries which Senator Carrick and his colleagues so constantly refer to, ignoring the fact, as my colleague Senator Sibraa will detail later, that those countries have adopted this principle.

In the last session we were treated to some exhibitions of hypocrisy and hysteria from members of the Liberal Party of Australia. We heard the pathetic bleatings of Senator Carrick on the state of Liberal Party funds as being 'lean and poor'. If that is the case it could only be because their funds are spent as fast as they come in. Then we were granted the spectacle of the Government running scared over the prospect of the Wran Government's public funding legislation in New South Wales. The fact is that this will prove to be so successful and acceptable that it will stand as a beacon for the eventual introduction of such schemes throughout the Commonwealth.

Let us look at what has happened recently regarding the problem faced by Mr McDonald, the leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, and his posturing over Senator Chipp's exposure of funds for his election campaign. He repudiates public funds yet he accepted $7,000 from a gambling night that was run in his electorate, the means to gamble being supplied by casinos in that State. He prefers this sort of funding of elections to public funding and accountability. The bankruptcy of this reponse, if not the bank accounts, was displayed in the debate which took place in New South Wales by the hollowness of the arguments and the depths of the emotional barrel that was scraped. Today I wish to look at those responses and put them in their proper perspective. By so doing I conclusively present the case for the public financial support of political parties.

A great deal is talked about principles and the principles of democracy. It seems to me that the essence of our democracy must be fairness, justice and the application of a fair go to all. The application of that essence involves the rule of the majority, the recognition of the rights of the minorities, the fundamental freedoms of speech, association and beliefs, and incorporates such diverse concepts as the right to work and the sovereignty of parliament. It embraces the existence of political associations which we know as political parties, and goes further by requiring their existence for the continued working health of our institutions. Whether they be major or minor parties, close to our beliefs or anathema to them, they are essential to our democracy.

There is no breach of principles in the institutionalising of our system's support, both rhetorical and real, for political association. On the contrary, it is an indication that at last we recognise the crucial place that they hold in our political life. It is a measure of the importance which we attach to our democratic ideals how much we are prepared to defend and support these political associations. I doubt whether there is one honourable senator on either side of the chamber who would deny that political parties are a basic requirement for the efficient functioning of our parliamentary system. Is it fair that one side is able to gather in far greater sums for its work than the other simply because it is the side which is supported by big business, millionaires or multi-nationals? Is it fair that the resources, in money terms, available to the parties which ensure that media moguls and transport tycoons can continue to print money at will, should swamp the resources of the parties which represent the underprivileged and the disadvantaged whose ability to flex financial muscle is obviously negative?

If it were a test of a political party's viability that it can attract adequate financial support, then it could only be on the basis of the supporters' ability to give. It will always remain, to me and other members of the Australian Labor Party, a moving experience to remember, as part of the indignation in 1975, the $1 and $2 donations and the pension cheques that flowed into our coffers in great quantities. That money was pitted against the collective might of certain Press barons, the corporate sector, the conservative establishment and other powerful forces. Is that just, fair or democratic? One of the most irksome arguments which has entered this debate is that relating to taxpayers' funds being used for purposes for which they have intense revulsion, ignoring the fact that the proposition of the Labor Party in respect of public funding is to make available from public funds an amount proportionate to the amount of support given in terms of votes to the political party concerned.

Further, it is the feigned naivety and the sanctimonious posturing of people who put forward this argument against this equity that is so infuriating. These are the same people who introduced us to the word 'hypothecate', a word which was dreamt up by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), who is as adept at sophistry as they are at sycophancy. These are the people who have no hesitation in diverting enormous sums from the pockets of pacifists into armaments, in pouring millions of dollars from the supporters of public schools into private education and in encouraging the development of uranium enrichment in the face of deep-seated and genuine opposition to nuclear energy. Such people know full well that it is the task of governments to make decisions, show leadership and direct public funds in accordance with their policies. This does not suit the conservatives. It does not stop them from crying 'undemocratic' when it suits them.

Since the Government seems keen, at the moment, on the answer 'not right now', the question may well be asked: 'Why not now?'. The fact is that campaigning costs hare reached astronomical levels with the universality of television advertising and its attendant costs, and with the general maturing of the electorate with respect to advertising and propaganda. The recurring debts of political parties, especially those which are dependent upon the donations of ordinary citizens, have become all too common in the wake of elections. This is something which should be of deep concern to all democrats. The fairness of our system, such as it is, cannot survive on this basis. Inequality in our voting system has to be eliminated. The equal access to information and the communicating of information is one important ingredient to that end. If the Liberal Party's bank balance is in much the same state as Senator Carrick suggests, then the problem is widespread and the solution more urgent. I do not call upon Senator Carrick to join with us on this matter as a mere rhetorical device. Already some members of the Liberal Party have recognised the problem and have spoken publicly in support of the proposal mentioned. Ex-Premier Hamer of Victoria, whose brother sits in this place, is on record as saying:

Public funding is obviously the fair and just way of allowing voters to scrutinise the policy of the parties. The danger of receiving private support from businessmen is that it can lead to allegations of abuse and favours in return for cash.

He should well know of the many scandals that took place in that State about speculation associated with land development. The claim that the Liberal Party insulates its parliamentarians from such pressures by not telling them of the identity of donors is a lot of hogwash. It is the same ruse as the well-known 'arms-length deal' in the business world and has much the same effect. We are aware that overseas corporations have funded political parties in Japan, Italy and many other countries. The National Country Party does not even bother to make any such disclaimer. It is quite blatant with its fund raising. It is quite happy to accept public funding by encouraging companies to make large donations to be written off as advertising so that the taxpayer foots the bill. That happens particularly in Queensland. The Leaders of the National Country Party see no impropriety in suggesting that businesses should make donations as 'very essential for the protection of their commercial future'. That is a phrase from the party's statement. Honourable senators will be excused for hearing echoes of breaking glass and gunfire in those words. Having moved into the protection racket, can we now expect the National Party in Queensland to try the numbers game or bootleg liquor?

The potential for corruption in our present situation is immense. It has been ably recognised by the former Secretary of the Victorian Liberal Party and political scientist, Leo Hawkins, who has described it as a 'cancer in our system' and who has accused politicians of being slow to face up to it. It is no good honourable members of the Government parties saying that they have no knowledge about it when they know that large sums of money are flowing into their political parties for the machine to spend as they wish in order to put their propaganda before the electors. They cannot stand apart from the fact that they have a responsibility to ensure that there is some equity in this system and that favours are not required as a result of donations. My colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) intimated, when he took part in a debate on the matter in the House of Representatives in May of this year, how one large donor to the Australian Labor Party who financially assisted us in 1972 subsequently wanted his price of flesh. When that was not forthcoming the donor turned against our political party.

I return to the remarks of Mr Leo Hawkins, the former Secretary of the Liberal Party. He has given figures for the 1979 Victorian State election showing that for media exposure alone the Liberal and National parties spent $385,600 compared with the ALP's $114,200. That means that the Liberal and National Country parties spent well over three times the amount spent by the Australian Labor Party. Is that not a matter of concern? Senator Mason tabulated figures for the 1980 Federal elections which showed that the Liberal-National Country Party coalition spent $1,757,000 to the Labor Party's $936,000 on radio and television advertising alone.

The extent of the Government's outspending of the Australian Labor Party in newspaper and television advertisements during the last week of the campaign is more difficult to gauge, but those of us who want to do so can remember the intensity of that campaign and can imagine the cost. At present one full page advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald costs $7,000. One minute of prime time on television costs $1,000.
