On every radio station and television station and in every newspaper in Australia the Liberal and National Country parties expounded their point of view to the detriment of any other point of view. I have ignored the value of the Packer-Murdoch editorial support, which can never be gauged or ascertained.

I turn now to another matter of principle-the secret ballot-that has been evoked. It has been claimed by the Treasurer that the disclosure of donations to political parties breaches the traditions of secrecy and privacy. That is simply arrant nonsense. A vote for a political party is one thing and it obviously should remain anonymous. An individual citizen deserves the protection of the law from the personal intimidation that accompanied political campaigning in the days before the introduction of the secret ballot. An individual citizen still need not be concerned about the publication of identity when that person is contributing reasonable amounts to a party or candidate which he or she supports.

Let us not kid ourselves. There is a gaping difference between that sort of donation and the massive corporate and personal support of the powers which control huge amounts of finance. It is that latter sort of donation which must come under public scrutiny. There is a direct relationship between the magnitude of financial support given to a party and the potential for patronage or corruption. Who would claim that a supporter's contribution of $10 or $20 would command the attention of a Minister of the Crown? But who would deny that a corporation providing hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of support would command some response and respect from the beneficiaries? It is not simply a matter of honesty that is at stake, although that is important; it is a matter of letting the people know what they are voting for and who the candidates are. It is also a matter of political reality, of converging pressures and inevitable responses. As such, there is no earthly reason why the Parliament cannot legislate for an orderly exposure of such forces as they affect public policy and decision making. Herein lies a right, if honourable senators want one; it is the right of an ordinary citizen to know what powerful forces are at work influencing the people who are responsible for directing their lives, no matter how vicariously.

Having accepted in principle the case for public funding of political parties and for public disclosure of major donations, there remains the matter of the method of applying it in practice. The Wran Government has taken the courageous step of implementing such funding principles in its State and the indications are that, although there has been a survey suggesting the unpopularity of that step, there is now evidence of an acceptance of it by the electors of New South Wales. There is no doubt that, in the elections that will take place with public funding in New South Wales in the next few months, the Wran Government's courageous step to place election funding beyond any suggestion of corruption so that it can be a matter of public accountability will ensure that that Government will be returned. This Government, however, refuses to grasp the nettle. We condemn it for that. We suggest it should reconvene the Harders Inquiry into Disclosure of Electoral Expenditure with a brief to investigate and report on a method of public funding and public disclosure as an important and necessary progression towards an equitable electoral system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present system of financing our electoral system is one of voluntary contributions to parties by the members and supporters of those parties. We are being asked today to look at the proposition that public funding for political parties is an essential part of any democratic electoral system. Rather than being an essential part of any democratic electoral system, public funding, involving as it does compulsory contributions by taxpayers to parties and to candidates, impairs the freedom of individuals. Public funding is in direct opposition to any democratic electoral system. Citizens should not be compelled through taxation to contribute to the funds of a political party which they do not support.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not clear whether the Australian Labor Party, in proposing the motion and in putting forward the idea, wants to do away with all voluntary contributions to political parties, or whether in fact the Labor Party is advocating a system of compulsory funding in addition to funds already voluntarily donated-or involuntarily donated, for example, by trade union members or anyone else. The Labor Party already receives very large contributions from its trade union supporters. It would be nice to know, in the context of this argument, whether the Labor Party is proposing that it do without that kind of funding in consequence of the public funding which it seeks. I mention here that, even if the Australian Labor Party is advocating a system of public funding in addition to voluntary support, the effect of its accompanying controls, such as the disclosure of sources of contributions, would be to discourage voluntary contributions to other parties.

If public funds are to be made available, they must be used only to supplement, not to replace, private voluntary contributions to parties and candidates. In no circumstances should there be any denial of the right of individuals and groups in society to support the parties and candidates of their choice, whether that support is in the form of their time, their effort or their money. This is an essential form of political participation and expression. Voluntary citizen participation is a key element of democracy. I am reminded of the famous funeral speech of Pericles when Thucydides put words to this effect in his mouth: 'We do not think that a person who takes no part in politics is minding his own business; we think he has no business here at all'. Already we compel our citizens to participate by enrolling and by voting. Many people quite properly would feel some resentment if they were compelled also to participate by financing the campaigns of politicians, especially those whose policies they would not willingly support or those whose policies they find offensive.

The principal advantage of voluntary funding rests on the fact that most people prefer voluntary to compulsory activity and they prefer persuasion to coercion, not just on the matter of funding election campaigns but in many areas of social activity. Even those who prefer compulsion to coercion are rarely willing to argue publicly a case for compulsion. An Australia-wide Gallup poll published in the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial last year showed that 70 per cent of people interviewed were opposed to the public funding of election campaigns. I am aware that last Tuesday the Canberra Times reported that a new poll, compiled by political analysts at the University of Sydney, maintains that the percentage of people opposed to public funding of election campaigns is about 40 per cent. I am not aware whether that was a nation-wide poll but the 40 per cent result of the poll shows that it is a sizeable minority opposed to public funding of political parties.

Our present system of voluntary funding has many positive features. It has features which are important to our democratic system, not the least of which is the political freedom I have already referred to-the freedom to participate in or to remain aloof from what political parties do. Voluntary funding is an important form of participation in the political process. In fact the reduced need of parties for private contributions could adversely affect the participation of citizens in political parties and their activities.

The Liberal Party depends upon the responses of its members and its supporters to assess the merits of its policies. The participation of those members and supporters in terms of voluntary contribution of time, effort and ideas, as well as money, is the best barometer between elections of our political and parliamentary performance. When support is not forthcoming from our party members, our leaders and our policy makers receive an important management message. For all political parties, this is one of the vital, positive functions of voluntary funding. By contrast, public funding would have a very harmful effect on the parties, the structure of the parties, and on politics generally. It would entrench party leadership. It would alienate party leaders, certainly in terms of their answerability, their accountability, from their party members and supporters. It would isolate them from the advice and the ideas they can receive from their supporters. With the assurance of available public funds the parties would become unresponsive, the party hierarchies would become unresponsive, and the feedback that is an essential part of the cultivation of voluntary participation would be lost.
The Sydney Morning Herald, on 10 November 1979, set out what it saw as seven arguments against public funding of political parties. It stated that public funding would:
(1) outrage voters who have strong moral objections to the philosophy and policies of a particular party;
(2) entrench existing parties to the detriment of new and small parties;
(3) weaken the links between politicians and the rank-and-file party members;
(4) not necessarily prevent the continued use of privately raised, devious moneys;
(5) encourage more frequent elections;
The Herald makes some observations about its view of that-
(6) lead to onerous bureaucratic controls over parties;
(7) open up election finance to the future manipulation of successive governments.

Public funding would not eliminate inequalities in the electoral process. In many ways it would aggravate the most undemocratic of them. It would, for example, magnify the very considerable advantages that government and incumbents have now over Oppositions and over new challengers. This would be especially so if subsidies were accompanied by limits on campaign spending. It is nonsense for the Labor Party to argue that public funding guarantees equality of parties, and that it is an essential component of a democratic electoral system. Public funding merely lifts the floor of financial advantage without guaranteeing any kind of genuine equality between the combatants. I note that in New South Wales the proposal put forward by Mr Wran indicates that many minority groups will not get any funding at all, that to qualify for funding in New South Wales a candidate will have to get about 10 per cent of the vote in a lower House seat. How many times can Independents, small parties, or the Australian Democrats look to 10 per cent of the vote in a lower House seat? Not all that often. Under the New South Wales arrangements they may miss out on all chance of finance, certainly in relation to lower House elections.

The dysfunctional qualities of public subsidies for political parties would be further exacerbated by such unnecessary controls as the forced disclosure of voluntary contributions. Disclusure forces up party costs. It produces more complex administration. Disclosure discourages contributions. Many Australians are nervous about having to identify themselves as supporters of any political group. Many new Australians who have had unfortunate experiences overseas are particularly unwilling to identify themselves because they have faced vendettas, revenge and vengeance in the countries from which they have fled. It opens up avenues for political reprisals of the most blatant and undesirable kind. It undermines the privacy of association which is an important corollary of the secret ballot, and it really is not convincing for Senator Gietzelt to dismiss that argument out of hand as he does.

The disclosure of voluntary contributions has been linked with the worst forms of corruption such as the keeping of what we might call 'enemies lists' by those in power; yet such disclosure is the very thing advocated by the Australian Labor Party to accompany its proposals for public funding in New South Wales and in other areas. What is more, forced disclosure of voluntary contributions would be especially damaging to parties such as the Liberal Party of Australia that insulate the policy makers from fund raising processes. Put bluntly, we do not want to know, because want to be able to make policy independently and without any awareness of who might or might not be a party supporter. Under the disclosure provisions, we would be forced to know where the money came from. When contributions are a matter of public record, every party's bank account takes on the character of a slush fund.

To seek or to accept a public subsidy is a political party's admission of failure. That it should need to look to public funding is an admission that it cannot get support from those who should be attracted by the force of its ideas and its ideology. The need for public funding reflects a lack of confidence in the acceptability of the party's objectives, a lack of confidence in its policies, a lack of confidence in its performance and an unwillingness to make the necessary efforts to raise its own funds. It is an assertion by an unsuccessful and failed party, and I might observe here that the record of the Australian Labor Party in the Federal sphere has been one of almost consistent failure. It is an assertion by a failed party that it has little regard for higher priorities and social needs.

In New South Wales the Labor Party is to impose a special tax on people to support the Labor Party in that State and to pay off its election debts. That is what it is. The $1m that the Australian Labor Party will take from the public could be used in other ways. It could be used to pay for a hospital; it could be used to build a school; it could be used to help underprivileged people. Instead, it is to be used to pay off election debts and to fund a party that is a consistent failure in the Federal sphere.

I am not arguing against all public funding in all the circumstances. I recognise clearly, in spite of the general preference for voluntary rather than compulsory participation, that a case can sometimes be made for some forms of public funding. I would observe, however, that the Labor Party in New South Wales had no election mandate for using public funding. Public opinion has not been favourable to the introduction of public funding of the Labor Party. The Liberal Party has maintained consistently that no such steps should be taken in New South Wales-I am sure this applies equally across Australia-unless they are approved by a statewide referendum.

I come back to the point that we can sometimes look for public funding. Indeed, a number of Western countries have found that their political conditions warrant and suit the introduction of some kinds of subsidised politics. Overseas practice, however, is no argument itself for the necessity or the suitability of such policies in Australia. It is something of an exaggeration, moreover, to argue that public subsidies are the trend or are increasing. In Britain, for example, no government has instituted a subsidy system, and Great Britain has our kind of political system. Even the former Labor Government in that country did not implement the recommendations of a committee headed by Lord Houghton, who is a former Chairman of the Parliamentary Labor Party. Even the Labour Government did not implement those recommendations. Similarly, there has been no successful effort to extent American Federal funding programs which have had wide and unintended consequences for the political system. They have produced volumes of regulations, they have demanded constant fine tuning by law makers and they have come under repeated court challenges from both ends of the political spectrum, and they have been challenged by civil liberties groups. The Americans have made no attempt to extend what they first introduced for presidential funding.

In the United States funds are provided only for presidential elections, not for the elections of senators or congressmen. Even then the funds do not come from Consolidated Revenue. In the United States they come from voluntary tax credits paid into a presidential election campaign fund. The main conditions that have resulted in the introduction of public funding schemes do not exist in Australia. The conditions include voluntary voting, which we do not have. That carries with it the need to encourage participation. The conditions also include bipartisan support for funding, which does not exist in Australia. They include the existence of a degree of public support, which does not exist in Australia, and they include, most importantly, evidence of widespread corruption within the political process.

Political conditions in Australia do not warrant the introduction of direct cash subsidies for parties and candidates. Already there are substantial indirect subsidies to political parties and to candidates in Australia. I will list a few of these. In Australia we provide five hours free time on Australian Broadcasting Commission radio and television at the kind of cost indicated by Senator Gietzelt. We provide staff, office and travel entitlements which are maintained during election campaigns. We provide VIP aircraft for party leaders. We provide compulsory voting which removes the cost of getting the electorate out to vote. In addition, the ALP through its ties with the trade unions in the beneficiary of another indirect subsidy-it is not available to other parties-and that is the tax deductibility which is attracted by the subscriptions trade union members pay.

There are also a number of practical considerations involving public funding. It is difficult, if not impossible, to devise equitable formulae for allocating political subsidies. Any set of criteria, whether based upon the number of seats held in parliament, the number of votes received at a previous election or any other formula involves arbitrary discrimination against some contestants in the political arena. There is also a problem of accountability, of ensuring that parties use the funds properly. Nothing in the proposals put forward by the Labor Party so far covers this point. It has not told us how it would do this properly without establishing undesirable government control over its own activities. There is the cost of administering the scheme. The bureaucracy increases. In the United States the Federal Election Commission has a staff of 275, most of whom are accountants and lawyers. It becomes an administrative nightmare for parties and candidates. The United States law had been described in that country as the lawyers and accountants full employment Act.

Today we are discussing an idea about the essentiality or otherwise of public funding-not whether it should be there as an adjunct but the assertion by the Labor Party that it is an essential part of the democratic process. The goal we seek to ensure we can achieve is that we have an electoral process which is fair, workable, equitable and free of corruption. Public funding is not an essential part of such a process. I conclude by making one observation to Senator Gietzelt. He need not think that all the descendants of the nineteenth century liberals are found on his side of politics. My grandfather was a parliamentary member of the Liberal Party in the year 1900. He was as keen and I am as keen as Senator Gietzelt or anyone else to see that we have an electoral process which is fair and free from corruption. The honourable senator will have to devise more arguments and advance more facts than he has so far advanced before we will believe that the arguments he has put up are in any way essential or necessarily helpful to Australia's political electoral system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Baume raised a number of issues, some of which I will deal with during my contribution to the debate and some of which I will deal with straight away. I want to answer his remarks about the New South Wales scheme and voluntary contributions. Under the New South Wales scheme of course there will be voluntary contributions and of course there will be voluntary work done by the thousands of people who support the Australian Labor Party in that State. Senator Baume mentioned also an editorial appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald. One of the points he dwelt upon was that public funding would lead to more frequent elections. I thought that in the New South Wales Parliament there was now bipartisan support for a proposal for fixed four-year terms and that when the next election is held in New South Wales a referendum will be put to the people in respect of four-year terms. Senator Baume in his contribution referred to the political experiences of migrants and how they were suspicious of some sorts of public funding to be introduced in New South Wales. I remind Senator Baume that many people have now come to live in Australia, especially from Europe, and if the countries from which they came are still democratic today some form of public funding exists in those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume mentioned also a matter that has been referred to quite a number of times recently, and that is that the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party is broke and that this whole idea is an elaborate exercise to bail the New South Wales branch out of its debts. That is not the situation. At the last conference of the New South Wales branch of our party the general secretary reported on the financial state of that branch. Our conference is open and it was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian and other media that, in fact, the New South Wales branch is not broke. Senator Baume referred to the fact also that in New South Wales the Wran Government has no mandate to bring in public funding. Some of his colleagues in the House of Representatives referred to the fact that the Wran Government should hold a referendum on public funding in New South Wales. I put it to Senator Baume that, in fact, we do have a mandate. We will have a referendum. It will be called an election. It will be on very shortly and the people of New South Wales will have an opportunity to vote on whether they want the Wran Government. I think most of us in this chamber, if not all of us, know exactly what the result will be.

I shall ask a number of questions. Firstly, why is this Government worried about the issue of public funding? Why have members of this Parliament and the New South Wales Opposition called public funding corrupt? What reasons have they advanced for this so-called corruption? What substantiations have there been of the allegations that have been made? There have been none at this stage. The reason this Government and the New South Wales Opposition are terrified is that under this legislation in New South Wales they will have to account for where the money comes from for their election campaign. We know that $5m or $6m came to the Government parties at the time of the last federal election and that money was completely unaccounted for. We do not know where 1c of that $5m or $6m came from. We do not know what deals were done between businesses and the Government. We do not know what favours are being bestowed on businesses as a result of those donations. According to this Government that is not corrupt. It is corrupt only if governments-they are doing this in many parts of the world-pay out of taxpayers' money amounts much smaller than that $5m or $6m to which I have referred and which are fully accountable to a government auditor. That seems to be what this Government is saying is corrupt. The Government says that that system is corrupt but that private business donations-and what might be attached to them-are not corrupt.

In New South Wales the charges being made at the moment are approaching hysteria because the New South Wales Opposition realises that it has missed the boat as regards obtaining public funding. The New South Wales Opposition is now faced with the situation that the Wran Government will be returned to office with an increased majority or just as big a majority as it received last time. Until recently everybody thought that was impossible. I point out to some of the Government senators that the Liberal-Country Party Opposition received 35 per cent of the vote in the last New South Wales State election and the latest gallup poll shows that it will get about that figure or perhaps even less at the election that is coming up.

Much to the consternation of the Liberal Party in New South Wales it realises that even though it spent thousands of dollars-as Senator Gietzelt has said, it was $7,000 a page-on advertisements in the Sydney Morning Herald trying to promote public funding as an issue, with an election to be held in the near future public funding has proved to be a complete non-issue in New South Wales. When this next State election is over I predict that the Opposition parties in New South Wales will change their attitude on public funding. We all know that the National Country Party in New South Wales was lukewarm in its opposition to funding anyway. The New South Wales Liberals-as Senator Baume would know, it is traditionally the poor branch of the Liberal Party in Australia-will be only too happy to accept some sort of public funding when the next State election is over.

Under the old system which operated and in which there was no public funding at all it helped to be a candidate for the Liberals as is the case in the seat of Manly. That State electorate is situated very close to where I live. The endorsed Liberal Party candidate for that seat of Manly said in an article appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald in May that his campaign costs in the State election would be in excess of $45,000. I point out that the Labor Party won the seat for the first time in history at the 1978 election and properly documented accounts show that it spent $3,449. With public funding in the campaign battle which is about to be fought in Manly I suggest that, bearing in mind the $45,000 to be spent by the Liberal candidate, the Labor Party will still be in a very bad position as regards funds but it will be more of an equal task. From what I have seen in the electorate recently, the Labor Party will continue to hold that seat. The member, Allan Stewart, is a very good member for that seat of Manly.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will hold it, too.

—As my colleague Senator McClelland said, he will hold the seat. The joke is that this Government already supports some form of public funding. Senator Baume referred to it. Let us go back to the campaign for the Grayndler by-election in New South Wales. New South Wales Liberal senators-I suppose Senator Baume was one of them-used their stamps, stationery, telephones and printing to seek support for the Liberal candidate in that by-election. I had a letter from a clergyman in the area who said it was scandalous and that this was some sort of public funding. I was able to point out to him that, yes, it was some sort of public funding. Because of the time, I will not go into matters concerning the Government Information Unit. I think that body is another example of this Government using public funding. The public must know where members of parliament and parties get their donations and what amounts are involved. I question why we have to keep these aspects quiet. What are Australian political parties trying to hide-and especially what have they tried to hide in the past-in regard to donations? This issue goes back a long time. I refer to something that happened in 1932. The Sydney Morning Herald carried an interchange between W.A. Holman, the then Premier of New South Wales, and Justice Halse Rogers. The interchange took place during the royal commission into the 'tin hare' inquiry. A reprint of the article in the Australian Quarterly states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Holman, addressing the royal commission, said that party funds were one of the inevitable by-products of the party system, especially with elections becoming more and more intensive and expensive.
That was in 1932 in New South Wales. The article continues:

- Parties invited subscriptions to their funds, and funds were frequently given in anticipation, no doubt, of favours to come. His Honour asked, amid laughter, whether funds were not almost universally given for this reason, and not merely frequently.
Mr Holman: Well, your Honour, I am endeavouring to be moderate.

What has changed in 49 years? Surely if funds are provided in secret, at a later stage a party can be compromised when a policy matter affects a donor, especially if that donor has made a large donation. At present the situation is just as it was in 1932. I want to deal now with public funding as it applies to other countries and to comparable parliamentary democracies. These countries include Sweden, Denmark, Norway, France, Japan, Holland, Israel, Belgium, Switzerland, West Germany, Italy, Canada and the United States of America. There are others. It is interesting to note that countries that have either conservative or socialist governments-it does not matter whether there has been a change of government-have retained public funding. In Sweden, for example, after years in opposition conservatives won election over the socialist government. Did they change public funding? Of course they did not. I make the point that all of the nations which presently have some form of political funding are among the most democratic in the world. All of the countries remain working parliamentary democracies and, if anything, they have become more truly democratic at a time when the number of true parliamentary democracies in the world is declining.

I ask Government members whether the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), when he talks to the leaders of those countries, when he meets them overseas, tells them that they and their parties were elected under corrupt systems? That is what the Prime Minister has said. He has said that public funding is a corrupt system. Does he say to Chancellor Schmidt or to Chancellor Kreisky when he meets them that he thinks they have been elected under a corrupt system? What does he say to a conservative leader such as President Reagan, who received $21m of public funds for the last election campaign in the United States? Does he say to him: 'President Reagan, I believe that you were elected under a corrupt system'? Senator Baume mentioned the United States system. He mentioned the Electoral Commission in Washington. At the Electoral Commission all the donations made to presidential candidates are open to scrutiny on payment of a very modest sum. I was able to get copies of the records of donations.

In 1962, President Kennedy said that some form of public funding was inevitable with the way that costs were rising then in the United States. He proposed the commission on campaign costs. That proposal was not acted upon by President Johnson but it was acted upon after Watergate. In some of the countries I mentioned a political scandal-such as that which occurred in Italy in 1974, and the one in Japan where the Prime Minister resigned-was needed to create bipartisan support for public funding or for an increase in public funding. It is interesting to look at the Watergate situation and what applied there, and at how acceptance of public funding in the United States came about. It is interesting that the amendments to the Electoral Reform Bill were passed only hours before President Nixon resigned. I ask Government members whether they think those amendments would have been passed in an atmosphere other than that surrounding Watergate and Nixon's resignation? I had intended to compare the systems in operation in West Germany and Canada. Because of the shortage of time I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard explanations of how those two systems work.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
West Germany

In West Germany political parties are recognised by the constitution, which of course is not the case in Australia although I personally feel that there is a strong case that they should be. State aid for political parties takes several forms of which the most important is for election campaign expenses. Payments are spaced over a period of four years, with the greater part being paid during election years. A law introduced in 1967 lays down the rules for subsidy through grants advanced for election purposes based on the performance of the parties concerned at the last election. An agreed sum is fixed for each elector according to the number of votes polled for each of the parties. This system operates in such a way that it is necessary to win seats in the lower house to qualify for aid. Any party donating over and above $6,000 must be specified by the name and address of the donor. This is the only accounting requirement by law for a political party wishing to qualify for aid. Each political grouping is also given a proportionate sum of money to maintain research facilities for its parliamentary representatives. In passing I mention that parliamentarians are also required by law to give a proportion of their salary to their party if they wish to qualify for local campaigning aid. Each party receives a subsidy for the purpose of party research and educational institutions.
Canada

Canada has an Electoral system more like ours than the system in the Federal Republic of Germany. The Canadian Elections Act of 1974 introduced a system of financial aid to political parties. Candidates are partially reimbursed for election expenses if they are elected or receive more than 15% of the total votes cast in their electoral district. The extent of reimbursement is decided by ascertaining whichever is the lesser of the two amounts, namely, the amount of the candidate's expenses as stated on his or her own declaration or an amount which is the aggregate of, firstly, the postage costs of mailing an ounce or less to each elector: secondly, 8c for the first 25,000 names on the preliminary list of electors: and thirdly, 6c for every formal vote cast in excess of 25,000 electors-the National Country Party senators might take note that there is a special allowance for candidates in specified remote electorates which is why the Canadian system is of some importance in Australia where the geographical size of the electorates varies enormously, as it does in Canada. In Canada there are also tax credits for political donations up to a specified maximum which at present is the equivalent of $A435 in any one year for a donation to the political party of the donor's choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume mentioned the Houghton committee report. I know it has not been acted upon but I think the Australian Democrats would be very interested in some of the recommendations in that report. In particular, Senator Chipp would find it interesting because, under the system suggested, Australian Democrats would have been eligible for a significant amount of public funding at the last election, in 1980, having established that their party had considerable electoral support at the 1977 elections. Naturally, following the 1980 result they would have been eligible for a much larger amount of money for the 1983 elections. I think also that we would have to look at a federal public funding system whereby if an Independent such as Senator Harradine received the vote that he did, he would also be eligible for public funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Already in Australia we have had minor scandals on both sides of the Parliament concerning public funding. The Labor Party was involved in the Iraqi loan affair and in recent times three Ministers of Liberal governments-Lynch, Garland and the late Eric Robinson-were involved in one way or another in minor scandals associated with election matters and the funding of election campaigns. We have to compare the small cost of public funding with some of the costs of the Fraser Government's priorities. Compare the cost of public funding with the $40m that has been spent on VIP jets. Compare it with the cost of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, conservatively estimated to be $14m. Some of the most undemocratic countries in the world will be represented at that conference. I wonder whether our Prime Minister will say to some of the military dictators and some of the rulers of one-party states when they come to CHOGM 'Your system is not corrupt', and whether he will say to the Prime Minister of Canada, who is elected under a system of public funding: 'Mr Prime Minister, we think your system is corrupt.'? I will close by quoting what Premier Wran said in New South Wales when he introduced into the New South Wales Parliament the Bill dealing with the public funding of elections. He said:

It recognises the central role of political parties in the parliamentary system. It protects the rights of minorities and new parties. It reduces the gross disparity between the financial resources available to different parties. It removes the risk of parties selling political favours. It declares to the world that the great political parties of New South Wales are not up for sale.
For those reasons I support Senator Gietzelt in proposing this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways, this is a traditional set piece debate. What distinguishes it from a set piece debate is that if ever the Australian Labor Party should achieve office again-that is unlikely, in the present circumstances-it will certainly implement the policy of federal funding of election campaigns. That is what fundamentally changes this from just an interesting debate into something of living reality for us on this side. I would like to mention a couple of things that Senator Sibraa said. If I grasped him correctly, he said--
—How do you grasp him correctly?

—He is long and lean and hard to get hold of, but I think he said that some form of public funding of elections was in existence in many of the countries that many of the migrants to Australia came from. I suggest it is a variation of that fact which has caused many of these people to come to Australia.
—Would you apply that to Scandinavia or Western Europe?

—No, Senator Mulvihill. We will apply it to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and elsewhere. Undoubtedly a number of people in this country came here from those countries because of the problem of one permanent form of government, and one set of official candidates all financed by the public moneys of those unfortunate countries.
—They also migrated to the United States of America and Canada which have the system that Senator Sibraa espoused.

—It is only my very great respect for Senator Mulvihill's length of time in this Senate and my very short time that allow me to listen silently to what he has to say. But I have only a few minutes so I ask the honourable senator to let me use them.
—I am helping you.

—That sort of help I can do without. I recognise that Senator Sibraa excluded countries in Eastern Europe. I also recognise that he has views that are not much different from mine about the sort of suppression that exists there. But I still make the point that many people are here from those countries because of the system, which is all to do with public funding. An enormous amount of work has already been done on this matter. My late friend and colleague-late in a parliamentary sense-from the other place, the Honourable Kevin Cairns, certainly showed the way. He indicated to the people of Australia on a number of occasions just what the attitude of this party and the Government was to propositions for public funding. We dignify this debate by talking about public funding. To me the essence of it is more simply expressed when we say that an attempt is being made to plunder the people's money to secure political permanence for those who advocate these things. I acknowledge the debt we owe to Kevin Cairns. I think it is worth reading into today's proceedings that on two occasions Mr Cairns moved notices and on another occasion moved a Bill. The essence of his position was that he regretted the decision made in Adelaide by the Australian Labor Party in July of 1979 to promote government subsidies directly to political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: He asserted that 'the taxpayers' dollar is not to be given to political parties, whether it be the Communist Party, the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party, independent parties or the National Country Party.' At that stage there was no Australian Democrat in the House or he would have included that party too. He was of the opinion that 'such funding distorts the very nature of Australia's political organisations and their responsibilities'.
He declared that the House should take action to resist utterly any attempt to divert tax dollars, pension payments, family allowances or defence money for such purposes.

I must say in passing that I find it quite peculiar that a party as dedicated as the Australian Labor Party professes to be to the cause of social welfare should be prepared to waste so much of the taxpayers' dollar on such suggestions as we are talking about today. I think it is worth proceeding with what Mr Cairns had to say. On another occasion in the House he said that any proposal to divert taxation or loan revenue to fund a political party--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Cairns is this?

—Will eventually lead to a weakening of the vigour and responsibility which should reside in freely formed political parties. I note what Senator Chipp has said. He is quite right to remind me that we should draw a very strong distinction between the Honourable Kevin Cairns, a former Minister in a previous Liberal Government, and Dr Jim Cairns, who was totally opposed to all of those propositions. Mr Kevin Cairns asserted that 'public funds should be used for the benefit of the Australian people and not to promote the contest for power by political parties'. He also said that 'such funding is contrary to the interest of emerging parties'. I hope that the Australian Democrats will note this. There are strong reasons why they should not support this. He continued and said that it would prolong the power of contrasting political organisations. I think it is again proper for me to thank Mr Kevin Cairns for what he did. I am certain that, with me, other people in this place wish him well in whatever he is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: It was suggested to me some little time ago that I should be in favour of this proposition to come to the public trough. I previously had a fairly tough electorate. Being tough and marginal it was rather hard to get money. Of course it is attractive, when in that situation, to think that a benevolent parliament and the people should fund one's attempt at continuity. But it is quite obvious, on a matter of principle and tradition, as has existed in this country so far, that such a proposition is utterly abhorrent to me, to the party I am in and to those people who were prepared to work voluntarily and to donate their time and efforts in order to get me into the other place. I am quite sure that I speak for the average Liberal voter and the average Liberal supporter in the average Liberal electorate. I also think I speak for a lot of voters in Labor electorates too.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you feel about Lang Hancock's funding of candidates?

—I do not know that there has ever been any definite evidence to support such an assertion. Perhaps in time to come the honourable senator might like to move a substantive motion. Until he does that, I propose to take no notice of any such charges. This is the easiest place in the world to make charges about people who have no opportunity to answer for themselves. I saw it happen in the other place too. One of the things about this Parliament I have always regarded as genuinely reprehensible is the fact that people can say exactly what they like, sometimes with absolutely no evidence. A person's character and good name can be impugned and he or she has no opportunity to answer. I am not saying that we ought to deny ourselves the right to speak frankly and fairly, but I am saying that I would have expected better to come from the honourable senator than a suggestion like that. However, when politicians decide to subsidise their campaign activities they assign themselves a very high priority amongst many of the competing urgent social needs.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, I am surprised that the Australian Labor Party should want to do this sort of thing. Neither Senator Gietzelt nor Senator Sibraa has proven or even attempted to prove that the present system of voluntary contributions to parties from their members and supporters is preferable to a system of compulsory funding from all taxpayers. They have not proved that the present political conditions in Australia warrant, or are appropriate for, subsidised politics. They have failed to prove that the numerous costs of public subsidies and the suggested accompanying controls will outweigh any likely benefits. It seems to me that unless those honourable senators can take up those questions and give very definite answers they have not got a case at all. The mere availability of subsidies and the understandable instinct of people to want to protect privacy of association, which of course would be invaded quite massively by forced disclosure and other controls, could discourage free and voluntary contributions to parties and candidates. Parties and candidates that conscientiously reject subsidies would soon be forced to join their opponents at the public trough. This is what I find so reprehensible about the whole matter. We must not overlook the positive functions of free and voluntary funding.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am very glad to see you in the chair. Allow me before resuming my speech to congratulate you on achieving the highest office that the Senate can offer and to promise you my earnest co-operation in your efforts to keep order in this place. I hope that what I have said is sufficient to indicate to you that I love you and therefore that you will not put me out when I perhaps deserve it.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the luncheon recess I developed a few basic reasons why we should not comply with the suggestion of the Opposition that political parties should be publicly funded. One of the best reasons is that we already have compulsory voting. Some of the countries that were mentioned by Senator Sibraa do not. That eliminates the need of parties to spend money to get out the vote. The Australian Labor Party, instead of whingeing about not getting votes, seats and the right to govern should go to the people, raise money and adopt adequate policies-policies which are acceptable to the people of this country. That seems to me to be a far better approach, but I have given advice to the Labor Party before and it has not been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we will not take it now.

—It is always good advice and worth taking. A long time ago I suggested in another place the sort of candidate the Labor Party ought to run in my old electorate. Eventually it picked one and look what happened to me. I gave good advice in that case. Also forgotten is the fact that considerable and substantial assistance is already provided to parliamentarians. I refer to all of the publicly funded facilities that are provided. I am glad that this is not a broadcasting day. I am not sure that it is the best time to be detailing those facilities, having in mind the recent controversy about parliamentary salaries and allowances, but every honourable senator knows what facilities we have available. They are present in an elegant sufficiency to enable every one of us to have a far better chance of being selected by our parties and returned here than has someone who is starting from scratch. It seems somewhat foolish to advance arguments which eventually may lead to those privileges passing away. The Opposition is arguing about something that is quite insubstantial and quite unreal, probably something that will never come to pass. The very process of arguing strongly in that way may leave us bereft of things that we all enjoy now. The Labor Party is making a grave mistake in bringing forward a proposal that is so full of legislative pitfalls and dangers to the democratic system. That system, even though Labor supporters might not like it, at least gives them a chance. To take up this matter at a time when they are struggling and when the result of every public opinion survey taken is against it is, in my judgment, foolish.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow in debate my close friend and colleague, Senator Martyr. One sometimes hopes that his performance in this place could be as good, as courageous and as exquisite as his performances when wearing wicketkeeper's gloves and crouching behind the wicket as a member of the parliamentarians' cricket team. There his performance is impeccable, but I cannot say the same about his speech today.

SPEECH.PARA: We are grateful to Senator Gietzelt and the Australian Labor Party for bringing forward this extraordinarily important subject in a form which amounts to a mild criticism. I wish that it had been proposed as a matter of urgency so that we could have had a vote on it. That is the newest thing that we can do in the Senate-vote on these issues. This particular issue would not fracture the party system. I know that at least three members of the Liberal Party genuinely believe that this area ought to be more closely investigated. It is the policy of the Labor Party and of the Australian Democrats. One hopes that before this year is out a private member's Bill will be brought down, will be passed in this place and will be sent to the House of Representatives.

We are discussing the proposition that public funding for political parties is an essential part of any democratic electoral system. However, this debate on political funding seems to eke out only the black and the white aspects. The proponent says that everything about it is good. The opponent, as we have just seen in the person of Senator Martyr, says there is nothing good about it whatever. After considering both sides of the question the Australian Democrats believe strongly in public funding. We do so for this central reason: How can a political party remain free and objective if it is heavily reliant on a particular benefactor? With great respect, Senator Martyr did not address himself to that question. He is both an absolutely honourable man and member of a political organisation, as indeed you are Mr President, but how can the hierarchy of your party be objective in any decision that comes before it when it has taken millions of dollars over a three-year period from unknown sources. It is emotionally and logically impossible on questions concerning mining to be objective if one has taken hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from mining companies. With great respect, I ask my colleagues on the right of the Australian Labor Party: How can you possibly be totally objective on a trade union matter or industrial disputation if the bulk of your funding comes from the trade unions?

That is one reason why I admire the Premier of New South Wales, a member of the Australian Labor Party who has had the courage to initiate public funding of political parties. Although the Democrats do not support him in the details of implementation, we admire very much the principle. I am persuaded that Neville Wran has shown himself to be a man who will stand up to trade unions-not all trade unions per se but those unions which every member of the Labor Party feels at times are going too far and behaving unreasonably. He has been able to take them on. After this exercise of public funding in New South Wales has been completed Neville Wran and his party will be able to be objective. They will not have to rely on any particular benefactor within the trade union movement.

I do not want to make a point of this, because the person that I am going to name involved himself in a recent controversy in which I was engaged. I did not name him and did not want to, but the present Leader of the Opposition in a certain State admitted that he had attended a gambling night at which several thousand dollars was raised by the use of equipment owned by criminals. I am not alleging for one moment that a cent of those funds went into that person's pocket, but several thousand dollars did go into the Liberal Party's pockets. Let us assume that the Liberal Party were to win the next election and the person in question were to become Premier of the State. Does anybody really believe that from that point on he could be objective? Would he not be in debt, at least morally or in some other way, to the criminal syndicates who take $150m profit out of illegal gambling in that State? I believe that under the present method of raising funds there is an obvious danger of political parties being put in a position of owing favours to corrupt elements in our society. The Australian Democrats have proved this.

We have all heard the hackneyed cliche: 'There is no such thing as a free lunch'. As honourable senators know, the Australian Democrats is the only political party that has in its constitution the rule that all substantial donations received by it will be capable of public disclosure. The result is that we are very close-perilously close-to being stone motherless broke. Do not members of this chamber realise that in the last six months we have been deluged with offers of funds, with all sorts of people coming to us and saying, 'Look, here is $50,000', 'Look, here is $20,000', or whatever? When this has happened my eyes have lit up and I have said: 'Thank you very much. You realise, of course, that any amount over $2,000 is capable of public disclosure.' They have vanished with a rapidity that would astonish even honourable senators. They do not want a bar of that. I think that indicates the sort of forces that are at work.

I feel very strongly about this, as do my colleagues. If we take anything under the table, if we take a $100,000 donation from the breweries, how can I then campaign, as we are doing, for a tax to be imposed on the advertising of alcohol which is the third largest killer of the human race? Where would my integrity be if I had taken $50,000 under the table from the liquor interests of this country? Yet honourable senators opposite still refuse even to contemplate the morality that is inherent in having everything above the table. Most Western democracies have now introduced some form of public funding. This practice has not been restricted to governments of any particular flavour. I compliment Senator Sibraa for giving examples of the way in which this practice has been adopted by the Social Democrats in Sweden and the Christian Democrats in Italy and West Germany. These are parties of different political persuasions.

Public funding would probably reduce the chances of one party telling lies about the others, as happened during the last federal election. One example is the monstrous, filthy, dirty lies that were told by the Liberal Party against the Democrats in Western Australia which resulted in that--

TALK.START.PARA: —It cost you a seat.

—It cost us a seat in this chamber. Another is the monstrous lies that were told by the Liberal Party against the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales which in my view could conceivably have cost the Labor Party government-lies which were printed by certain newspapers but which were refused by honourable newspapers in this country for being palpably untrue. Two points can be made about this. The first relates to the recent infamous judgment of the High Court of Australia. I disagree with my friend and colleague Senator Gareth Evans on few occasions. However, this is one occasion on which I fiercely disagree with him. I refer to the High Court judgment from those seven venerated and venerable gentlemen who said that from now on virtually it is not essential to tell lies during election campaigns but it is highly desirable to do so.
—They didn't say that.

—I say that the virtual effect of the judgment is precisely that. I think on occasions Senator Evans, for whom I have an unbounded admiration, should take away from himself the shackles of the law that binds him and his legal colleagues and look at problems in the human light rather than from the myopic view of a lawyer, a distinguished lawyer though he may be.
—Sir Garfield Barwick didn't think I had too many shackles.
—If the honourable senator is hoping to impress me by quoting Garfield Barwick to me as an authority, he is quoting the wrong person. I am surprised that the name even crosses his lips.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now entirely possible for a political party with unlimited money to print those sorts of lies against an opponent. It does not have to be a penniless opponent like the Democrats; it can be a party like the Australian Labor Party which, although not penniless, does not have the kinds of resources necessary to reply with equal strength one, two or three days before an election. Such a party does not have the kinds of resources to hire the slickest, sleeziest and slimiest advertising agents it can, give them an unlimited budget drawn from some secret sources and say: 'There is $1m; go away and smear the Democrats, go away and smear this particular party'. This behaviour leaves the other party with absolutely no defence whatsoever.

If Senator Martyr, who is basically and totally a fair and honourable man, believes that that kind of circumstance is one that should remain, I am confounded by the queer process of logic that brings him to that conclusion. A person might agrue-this is a respectable argument superficially-'Why should I pay my taxes to a political party? I hate all political parties and I do not want to pay my taxes to any of them'? Superficially this is a respectable argument. But the argument when refined becomes even more respectable, that is: 'Why should my taxes go to the Democrats whom I despise?' That would be a respectable argument. But there are ways out of that. Hypothecations out of Consolidated Revenue can be made on the basis of performance at the previous election which essentially would mean that overall the situation would be the same. There is another device where a taxpayer can make an option on his income tax return, such as, 'I hereby authorise the Treasury to allot 0.1 per cent of my taxes to the Australian Labor Party'. Such an option could be made in respect of the Liberal Party, the Country Party or the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about individuals?

—I acknowledge that the honourable senator has a point. Senator Harradine would agree with that in a flash. But I refuse to believe that is not something that could not be ironed out. But my answer is that the Australian taxpayer is already paying for a basic proportion of the money going to political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Big money has been offered to me as Leader of the Australian Democrats. When I have said, 'Well, yes, subject to public disclosure', they have run a mile. On occasions they have said: 'Look, what about giving us $100,000 worth of your advertising; what about giving us $50,000 worth of your printing bills; we will pay that'. Then their eyes gleam and they say: 'That is even better still; we can write that off against tax'. God knows how much is being written off in that way. They say: 'You would not be the first political party to have accepted that'. That must mean that billions of dollars of taxpayers' money is not being collected because payments to political parties are being claimed under the subterfuge of advertising or printing expenses. We hope that in the next three years the Senate will become a little more bipartisan over a problem such as this which essentially when it is all boiled down is not one of pure party politics. It is a problem of justice for the political parties of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my speech by quoting an article which appeared in today's Australian newspaper. The article concerns a lady who I believe is heading the Australian Democrats ticket for the New South Wales Legislative Council election which will be part of the State election to be held probably in September. The article quotes her as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: And for public funding of elections, that's a gross invasion of personal liberty.
I do not know how that statement can be related to the situation to which Senator Chipp has just referred. Here is a lady who is standing for the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is showing independence.
—Perhaps she is just showing the independent mind of the Democrats.
—Perhaps not all of what she said was quoted.
—I am trying not to quote her comments out of context.
—Are you vouching for the total accuracy of the Australian at all times?

—If necessary I will seek leave to have the whole article incorporated. But I do not think I have quoted it out of context. We are discussing the fact that public funding for political parties is an essential part of any democratic electoral system. That is interesting because there is no mention of individual candidates. There is no mention of people such as Senator Harradine or myself. We have been in that situation in years gone by. We had to find our own way to raise finance to get into this House. I will say at this stage that I have never had any money given to me towards funding any election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: People in this country do not have a very high opinion of politicians already. Rightly or wrongly they see us as people who do not work very hard, who are highly paid and try whenever we can to get our grubby little paws into the tills. We all know that many politicians in this place, in the three days they are here, work long hours-I say too many hours for the good of their health. I think Parliament should have enough sense to choose reasonable sitting hours. I hope before long we will not be held here at night captive to those bells but will start our day at a sensible time and end it at a sensible time, as most people around this country do. But that is another matter.

We do seem to the public to be highly paid. On top of that we have phones, secretaries and cars and all those things such as overnight accommodation, many of which are still available to us during election time. The Australian Labor Party, following a line it has taken for years, is asking for more. It is trying to have the taxpayer pay for the political party. Already in New South Wales we have seen Mr Wran pass public financing legislation for his election, something that most probably will benefit the Labor Party more than other parties in the election-which I expect will be announced any day. I seek leave to have incorporation in Hansard an article from the Australian that relates to funding in New South Wales. I have shown the article to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is at the table, and to the Opposition.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
DESTROYING LIBERTY TO PAY POLITICAL PARTIES

The concept of using public money to finance the campaigns of political parties is repugnant and undemocratic enough: repugnant because politicians are already feather-bedded to an inordinate degree with high salaries, astonishingly generous superannuation and many other perks; and undemocratic because such funding favors major parties while destroying the chances of independents and parties struggling to become established.

But the Big Brother measures contained in the New South Wales Election Funding Bill, introduced into the NSW Legislative Assembly by the Premier, Mr Wran, will startle-even frighten-most people and cause great worry among those already seriously perturbed about continued erosion of civil liberties. Mr Wran described the bill as 'a pioneering measure for Australia'-implying it will be copied by other States. It is to be hoped not. It must not.

The bill should not become law in its present form. Indeed, it is extremely unlikely that voters want public funding of political parties to become law in any form. If Mr Wran believes they do, let him lay the bill aside and put the question of public funding to the voters at a referendum in conjunction with the next State election. He can then, democratically (which would be welcome) test public feeling.

The requirement that any donation to a political party of $1,000 or more must be disclosed, as must any donation to a candidate of $200 or more, will be offensive to many people. It expresses, in blunt terms, the authoritarian belief that a person's private property is not his, to dispose of as he wishes. His wishes must be subject to the censorship of the State. This is the approach of both fascism and communism.

But the measures contained in the NSW bill to police that requirement and other sections of the bill are horrifying in their scope. Section 110 will give inspectors appointed under the bill power to enter 'at any reasonable time, and place' where they believe records or bankers' books are kept relating to the funding of election campaigns. It also, according to Mr Wran's explanation to Parliament, makes it an offence for any person to obstruct an inspector . . . and 'any person who makes a false declaration or who fails to make a declaration shall be guilty of an offence.'

This means that State inspectors can arrive at, say, the private home of an honorary worker for a candidate in an election, demand entrance and search that home as they see fit. They can also enter any bank which they believe is keeping an election account and demand to see that account-and the accounts of anybody or any firm they think may have made a donation. Mr Wran did not say if the inspectors would be wearing jackboots. They should be.

The powers of the inspectors do not end there. In a complete switch of the concept of justice which requires the State to prove a case against someone it believes has infringed its laws, the inspectors can require the suspect to make a statement to convict himself-if he is, in fact, guilty. If he refuses to make such a statement, or refuses in it to provide evidence of his guilt, he faces a penalty up to $10,000.

Thus, the victim of this draconian law must-if he has given, say, $250 of his own money to a local candidate-admit he has breached the Electoral Funding Act if he has not disclosed the gift and have that admission used in evidence against him or face a $10,000 fine for having refused to provide evidence of his so-called guilt.

The NSW president of the Council for Civil Liberties, Mr Malcolm Ramage, has described Section 110 as 'most offensive', a 'serious erosion of civil liberties', and a reversal of the traditional basis of law, adding: 'The banks should also be interested in this-with one sweep of the pen it makes nonsense of banking law and the principle of confidentiality.'
Everybody should be interested in this-in every State . . . because there is no doubt political parties in all States will be watching the progress of Mr Wran's essay in authoritarianism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it quite clear that not only am I against such expenditure in New South Wales but also I believe politicians get too much assistance at election time. I have already said that we get the use of telephones, copying machines, secretaries and travel and things of that kind which are paid for from the public purse. Just a few years ago none of these facilities would have been available. There has been a gradual and insidious encroachment to assist those already in office. I make it clear that I do not like the use of VIP aircraft by party leaders or others during election campaigns. I suspect that once again my disapproval will fall on deaf ears. I think that when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) spoke he hit the nail on the head when he said that Australians want a voluntary system of party support. That is what I believe. Perhaps my good friend Senator Missen would not always agree. I remember seeing an article by him in which he took the attitude that party costs should be met by the taxpayers, not only election expenses but also other party expenses.
—Yes, Senator, you know I am well on the record in this chamber as saying on many occasions that we ought to be looking at a decent system of public funding. I am certainly not in agreement with you.

—I have great difficulty in accepting that line, even though in that article, just to be fair to the honourable senator, I think he pointed out that nearly all parliamentary democracies have some form of public financing. I think the honourable senator pointed out two examples in that article of how money can be both collected and distributed. I am sure the honourable senator will not take affront when I say that he is once again against the stream of public opinion. It is always courageous I think to run against the stream of public opinion. If the honourable senator looks at the survey taken towards the end of last year he will see that three times as many people are against public financing of political parties as are for it. I would love to be the organiser of the 'No' campaign for a referendum on public funding of election campaigns.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps when we look at any legislation before this House we should ask ourselves who is benefiting. In the case of federal financing of parties, we need first of all to look at where money, mainly for campaigns, comes from. Basically the money is coming in one way or another from the public. Many individuals contribute to the party of their dreams in one way or another and give an amount of money to that party or individual candidate. I believe that is the way it should be in any democracy. A person interested in a candidate or party can democratically contribute at any time and do so in a democratic way; that is, in a secret way. In other words, people can vote with their money. When the public or taxpayers begin to contribute to the political party obviously party supporters will fall away. I think the Minister made this point. Therefore, we reach the situation where a politician would be much less responsive to the thoughts of the party which in most cases have enabled the politician to get into this place. I do not think that is good for democracy.

I do not like the idea of interference by bureaucracy or by those who distribute the funds to the party. Obviously, with public financing there will be some type of interference. If the funding were to individuals those individuals would perhaps be in a very difficult situation. I think another point is important. I do not think that members of parliament should know where their money is coming from. It puts them in a very difficult situation. I think financing parties helps to enshrine the status quo. Usually a person or party weould have to achieve a certain percentage of the poll before receiving any assistance under any legislation that i know of. Why any and every individual who stands for election should not be assisted-if we are indeed to have assistance-is beyond me. Equal treatment for everybody in a democracy is important. When it comes to something as basic as an election, the law should certainly apply equally to all.

The Minister said that it is difficult to devise acceptable formulae that do not protect sitting members. I might be cynical enough to ask: Which sitting member would vote for something if he did not think that he would benefit from it? In that matter at least I think Senator Gietzelt is consistent. In this place he is consistently asking for alterations to methods of conducting elections, to electoral Acts. Usually he calls this 'reform'. That seems to be the Labor Party's favourite word when it comes to electoral matters. It wants to reform everything. Whenever it wants to change the system to its own benefit, not necessarily to the benefit of the elector, it says it wants to reform the system.

Today again we have s en another attempt to reform the system for allocation of money that parties get from the public, to reform the bank balances of parties and to reform the whole situation to the benefit of such parties. If that is what a reformist does I am certainly not one. We have only to look at overseas experience to see that if a system like this is started it becomes very difficult and very expensive to account. A lot of the money in overseas countries given to political parties is spent purely on accounting. Senator Chipp mentioned that in some countries people can contribute via a tax form to the party of their choice. As already pointed out that makes it very difficult for an individual candidate.

I think we all know that in the United States funds are provided for presidential elections but not for election of members or senators. Even with the election of the President it is a voluntary scheme. Our Senate follows closely the example of the United States Senate and our House of Representatives that of the House of Commons. In neither the United States nor England is public assistance given for the running of political parties. The Minister made the point that even though the Labor Party had been in power in England it had not chosen to dip its hand into the public purse to help to run the party. As I have said, I have run a few election campaigns and I have not had a penny for it. I think that it is time we put at rest once and for all these attempts to pounce on the public purse.

Finally, the disclosure of donations and limiting of donations bring with them a tremendous number of difficulties. If a candidate knows where his financial support comes from then he may be, or is, placed under some pressure that he would not otherwise be under. Also it leaves supporters in a situation where they can be discriminated against by a party that they do not support. It can easily look as if a government is responding to an interest of a contributor even if it is not, which would make politicians subject to even more public cynicism. I believe we have dealt with this problem for long enough. Obviously the public does not want to be forced into this area of funding of political parties. It does seem morally wrong to force public expenditure upon the parties when it is quite obvious the public does not want this to occur. This is one Australian Labor Party reform that we do not need. It is certainly in no way essential, as was suggested in the discussion of the matter of public importance which Senator Gietzelt brought before us today. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That unless otherwise ordered-
(1) General Business, Notice of Motion No. 62 standing in the name of Senator Missen relating to proposed amendments to the Standing Orders take precedence of other business and

(2) After the consideration of General Business, Notice of Motion No. 62 standing in the name of Senator Missen, intervening business be postponed until after the consideration of General Business Orders of the Day Nos 14, 16, 31, 41, 46, 50, 54, 55, 56, 63, 73, 83, 84, 88, 102, 105, 107, 117, 118, 122, 131 and 156 relating to Transport and Communications be considered together, and that General Business Orders of the Day Nos 15, 74, 75, 93 and 157 relating to Trade and Commerce, then be considered together and that, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the questions with regard to the consideration of each group of Orders of the Day be put in one motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That Standing Orders 26, 27, 28, 28A, 29, 30, 31, 31A, 33 and 291 be amended to read as follows-

26. At the commencement of the sittings next ensuing after the 30th day of June following each periodical election, or at the commencement of the Session after a general election of the Senate, or whenever any vacancy shall occur, the Senate may appoint a Senator to the Deputy-President (Procedure) and a Senator to be Deputy-President (Committee), who, unless otherwise determined, shall hold office until the 30th day of June following the next periodical election for the Senate, or in the event of a dissolution of the Senate until the date of the Proclamation dissolving the Senate.
27. The Deputy-President (Procedure) and the Deputy-President (Committees) shall be appointed in a similar manner to the President.
28. The Deputy-President (Procedure) shall take the Chair of the Committee at the Table whenever a Committee of the Whole is constituted by the Senate or by these Standing Orders.

28A. The Deputy-President (Committees) shall perform such duties and exercise such authority in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives as the President may determine.

29. Unless and until the Senate otherwise orders, the Deputy-President (Procedure) shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to all proceedings of the Senate, and the Deputy-President (Committees) shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives, until the next meeting of the Senate (whenever the Senate shall be informed by the Clerk at the Table of the absence of the President), and so on from day to day, on the like information being given to the Senate, until the Senate shall otherwise order.

Provided that, if the Senate shall adjourn for more than twenty-four hours, the Deputy-President (Procedure) and the Deputy-President (Committees) shall continue to perform the duties, and exercise the authority of President, for twenty-four hours only after such adjournment.

30. Should both the President and the Deputy-President (Procedure) be unavoidably absent, the Senators present, if a Quorum, may at once proceed to elect one of the their number to act as President in relation to all proceedings of the Senate for that day only, the Question being put to the Senate by the Clerk. Otherwise, the Senate stands adjourned to the next sitting day.
31. The Deputy-President (Procedure) shall take the Chair whenever requested so to do by the President during a sitting of the Senate, without any formal communication to the Senate.

31A. During the unavoidable absence of the Deputy-President (Procedure), the President may call upon any one of the Temporary Deputy-Presidents (Procedure) to relieve him temporarily in the Chair, without any formal communication to the Senate.

33. A Standing Orders Committee, to consist of the President, the Deputy-President (Procedure), the Deputy-President (Committees) and seven Senators, shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament, with power to act during Recess and to confer with a similar Committee of the House of Representatives.

291.
