The President shall be ex officio a member of the Standing Orders Committee, the Library Committee, and the House Committee, and not liable to be elected on any other; and if the Deputy-President (Procedure) or the Deputy-President (Committees) be elected to serve on a Committee, and shall decline to do so, a Senator shall be elected in his stead, in the same manner as the other Senators were elected.
(2) That proposed new Standing Orders 28B and 30A be agreed to, as follows:

28B. The President shall nominate at the commencement of every Parliament a panel of not less than two Senators who may act as Temporary Deputy-President (Procedure) when requested so to do by the Deputy-President (Procedure), or when the Deputy-President (Procedure) is absent.

30A. Should both the President and the Deputy-President (Committees) be unavoidably absent, the senior Chairman of Committees shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives, for that day only, and the appointments so made shall be notified to the Senate by the Deputy-president (Procedure).

(3) That, wherever occurring in the Standing Orders, the term ''Chairman of Committees'' or ''Chairman'', when referring to the office of the Chairman of Committees of the Whole, be amended to read ''Deputy-President (Procedure)''.

Basically the motion seeks to separate functions and to create a new position in the Senate. Of course, it is desirable that we should decide whether we will have these two positions before we proceed to the appointment of people to fill them. This matter has been given a great deal of consideration by a number of people in the Senate, particularly the chairmen of the various standing committees, for more than a year. What is proposed, in brief, is that in future there should be two positions: Firstly, a position of Deputy President (Procedure), to perform the duties which are now basically performed by the Chairman of Committees; and, secondly, a position appropriate to the fact that the Senate has developed a committee system during the last 10 years that must continue to develop. We must see that the future of the committee system is organised so that it does not develop in a haphazard way. The appointed person would hold the position of Deputy President (Committees). This is a completely separate position for the performance of new functions which are not being per- formed at present by any officer, or particularly, by any elected person, in the Senate.

As I have said, the matter has received fairly long consideration. The present situation has developed over a number of years. There has been a very considerable increase in the number of committees that the Senate operates. The Senate is well known not only in this country but also in many other countries for the extent to which in 10 or 11 years it has developed a committee system. I believe that is something of which we can be proud. It is important to realise the changes that took place between 1970 and 1980. In 1970 eight staff were employed within the secretariat of Senate committees. Indeed at that time there were only two standing committees and five Estimates committees. Since that time further developments have taken place. There are now eight standing committees, which cover the whole range of the policy issues that come up within the area of the Senate, and six Estimates committees. As at 30 March 1980 there were 49 full time staff servicing the committees. Consequently this is a very active group, and it is important that there ought to be supervision of the effectiveness of that group of employees of the Senate.

We know that restrictions have been placed on the size of the staff of the Senate. We know that complaints have been made about this. This has been one of the subjects of consideration by the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which was chaired by Senator Don Jessop. This Committee reported during the parliamentary recess. One of the problems has been that we have inadequate levels of staff. We understand that there may be a lack of balance as to how that staff is being employed. At the moment no elected member of the Senate has the primary responsibility of seeing how the Senate committee system is operating. We have a Chairman of Committees but, in a sense, that is a misnomer. He is the Chairman of the Senate when the Senate is meeting as Committee of the Whole, but he is not in any sense a chairman of the Senate's committees, nor does he have close knowledge of the operations of those committees.

In the last year or so a practice has developed whereby the chairmen of the standing committees of the Senate have met, initially on an informal basis and then with some regularity, with the knowledge of the President of the Senate. Matters are constantly reported to the President and as a result we have discussed problems which have arisen in that area. But still the arrangement is comparable to a headless monster. It involves just an informal group of chairmen. Clearly there is a need for someone to whom that group can report and someone who, in return, can assist the chairmen with their problems concerning their committees and staff.

We have had not only that group of chairmen of committees but also a group of management consultants which were appointed by the President to investigate the efficiency of Senate operations, not only in respect of its committees but also other aspects. Copies of its report have been made available to many honourable senators, including the chairmen, and I think to the leaders of the political parties represented in the Senate. What comes forward clearly from that report is that at this time the Senate committee system is not as fully developed as we would like it to be. There are obvious deficiencies in respect of the referral to Senate standing committees by the Senate, of annual reports of government departments, statutory authorities and other instrumentalities. Unfortunately, evidence discloses that only something like 78 of the 455 reports concerned have been reported on by the respective committees.

It surely is important that we report more thoroughly to the Senate on documents which are placed on our tables and which, mainly because of lack of staff, are not being dealt with by committees. Clearly, supervision is needed in this area. Suggestions have been made by the management consultants that, among other things, the staffing of committees should be placed under supervision; that a senior clerk of committees should have responsibility in that respect so that he knows whether the committees are working effectively. However, that alone would not be enough. We need a member of the Senate to have responsibility in that area. We in this chamber place great emphasis on our committee system, and rightly so. That is all the more reason for an officer of the Senate to have the job of reporting to this chamber and to the Government.

If we do as Senator Jessop's committee recommended and establish a separate committee to inquire into the financing of the Parliament, if we are to obtain to some extent independence of the Executive Government in determining the financial needs of the Senate, obviously such an officer of the Senate, who would be aware of the needs of the Senate committees, would be a most important officer in terms of advising such a committee as well as in terms of his other functions.

The Senate chairmen of committees met and, on 18 August 1980, they reported to Government senators at a party meeting. Copies of that report have been made available to the various political parties represented in this chamber. I propose to read the rcommendations the chairmen made in their report because they are basic to the motion I moved. Paragraph 10 of the report states:

(a) That it be acknowledged that the Senate Committee System needs to continue to develop and that some proposals from the Management Consultants could place that development at risk. That in any event the system must not lose its dynamism.

I emphasise that fact. The Senate committees spend a lot of time examining issues. They proceed throughout the country, bringing this Parliament closer to the people. They obtain ideas and they report them to this chamber. There is a great danger that if their recommendations do not gain ready acceptance or helpful acceptance from the Government we might find a decline in the importance of the Senate committee system. Therefore, it must not lose its dynamism. There is a need for an officer who can emphasise and concentrate on that area. Paragraph 10 (b) of the recommendations stated:

That although there has been considerable discussion relating to the Senate Committee System over recent years there has been relatively little follow through and therefore relatively little progress-for instance, the matter of some permanent staffing for, or the re-organisation of the role of Estimates Committees has still not been determined; further, the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees have, after 10 years, still not developed their Legislative role.

It is most important that we get past that situation. The House of Representatives has developed legislative committees-not many, but some. The Senate has the ready-made and properly named legislative and general purpose committees. They are standing committees of the Senate. Yet we have not yet got around to determining how Bills will be referred to those committees, which Bills will be referred or what the procedures will be. Our legislative role in that sense is very inchoate. It is not fully developed. Once again, there is a need for an officer to concentrate on the proper development of that role. The third recommendation of the chairmen of committees was:
That cohesive direction needs to be given to the Senate Committee System in relation to its organisation, administration, operation and effectiveness.

I started with that point. I made it clear that we must have more cohesiveness in order to get the best benefit out of the staff we have. We must have proper systems for promotion and we must know what directions the committees are able to take. The fourth recommendation was:
That subject to the direction of the Senate the Senate Chairman can and should provide that cohesive direction.
Paragraph (e) of the recommendations-this comes to the very kernel of this motion- recommends:

That the Senate should create a new position of Deputy President (Committees). That this Deputy-President should chair the meetings of the Senate Chairmen and, subject to the President, have the administrative responsibility for the Senate's Committee System and Secretariat. The Deputy-President (Committees) should have equal status with the 'Chairman of Committees' whose functions are, in fact, primarily related to the Chamber. That the present office of Chairman of Committees be changed to Deputy-President (Procedures).
The Chairmen do not regard the naming of the officers as vital and acknowledge that other Titles could be regarded as preferable.

We have thrown around other names and suggestions but it seems that this is the most clear way in which we can define the two different tasks, which should be kept separate and which should not really overlap. The next recommendation made by the Senate chairmen was:
That further consideration be given to the question of the development of a system for proposed legislation being referred to Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees or otherwise.
They went on to state:
That future consideration be given to the proposal for abolishing the Estimates Committees and combining their function with that of the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees.

I will not go into that at the moment but it is a matter that needs to be considered. We must consider whether it is more effective to have the two committees working separately or whether these things can be covered by one committee. Again I stress that an officer could guide the chairmen and the Senate by obtaining all the facts on that subject. The next recommendation in the report states:
That we note that a Select Committee is considering the proposal for a Parliamentary budget and the Senate Chairmen will be interested to consider the findings.
The next point states:
That there should, consistent with the creation of the office of Deputy President (Committees) be a Senate Clerk Assistant (Committees) to administer the Senate committee system.
There is an obvious corollary for that: There needs to be someone whose primary responsibility is to co-ordinate with the staff. The last recommendation states:
That the foregoing be implemented forthwith and that further proposed developments be put forward by the Senate Chairmen to the Senate Party Room during this session.

Nearly a year has gone by since that report. It has taken some time and I think it is high time now that we were in a position to elect officers from this Senate. We should take up those recommendations, which I believe are sensible ones. It is important to realise that the proposed new officer will not be somebody who will overlap with or interfere with the job which is being done now by the Chairman of Committees who, under the new title of Deputy President (Procedure), will retain his existing responsibility in the chamber. The new officer will have responsibility for the prestige and development of our system as it operates outside the chamber, for what we do under the committee system. I urge senators from all parties to recognise that this is an important point in the history of this system. We must not let the committee system drift at this stage. Our intention in putting forward this proposal is to avoid that. I do not go into the question in detail. I know that advice has been obtained as to what might be the salary for this office. That would be a matter for the President and the Remuneration Tribunal to determine, based on the number of responsibilities which the President gives altogether to the new officer.

I will not go into the precise terms of the motion because I think it will be seen that they follow logically in changing the Standing Orders to accommodate these two separate positions. It should be borne in mind that we have developed up to a certain stage a committee system which is worthily recognised as one of the best and most positive achievements of the Senate and which is regarded as an example in the democratic world. But I think we must go ahead with it at this stage, realising that it needs a certain amount of co-ordination and an officer, whom we would call Deputy President (Committees). He would help in the supervision of those committees and in the presentation of their reports to this chamber. Therefore, with the greatest of sincerity I urge members of the Senate to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I indicate that we oppose the motion which has been moved by Senator Missen. I should like to indicate some of the reasons why we oppose it. Senator Missen, I think, described the proposal which he is putting forward on behalf of the Government as an important step in the history of the Senate, and said that for that reason we should all regard it with the utmost gravity and indeed look upon it as a highly significant event. If it had been a highly significant event it would not have been popped on the Senate in the circumstances in which it has been by Senator Missen today. I, for one, for reasons which are probably obvious to other senators, was not able to hear everything that Senator Missen had to say. But I think I gathered the gist of his proposal for the first time in listening to most of what he had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposition has been floating around for a year. It has been known as the Rae proposition, because it was conceived by Senator Peter Rae, it has been nurtured by Senator Peter Rae and, surprise, surprise, Senator Peter Rae is the Government candidate for this position if it is created.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is just the chairman of the chairmen.
—I understand.
—That is an untrue allegation.

—I will come to Senator Jessop in a moment. The fact of the matter is that if the Government had adopted the proper procedures in relation to this question, if it had been so concerned about this historical moment in the history of the Senate, it would have consulted with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in some detail and at some length, explaining the nature of the proposal. But let us look at what has happened. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders. Let us look at what happened at the meeting of the Standing Orders Committee on Monday, 1 December 1980, which I think, was the first time I ever heard of this proposition. Under the heading in paragraph 5 'Appointment of Deputy President', the minutes state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee discussed a proposal for the appointment of two Deputy-Presidents.
I might interpolate that the discussion was pretty brief. The minutes continue:
It was agreed that the matter be further considered at the next meeting.

There has been no such meeting. To pop this matter in here today without that meeting having taken place is, in my view, quite extraordinary. But it is quite clear to us on the Opposition side that the Government has not even made up its mind about this important issue; that there is no great burning conviction amongst all the members of the Government parties about it. If there is, how is one to understand the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which was brought down by Senator Missen in the Senate only yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; you are wrong. Senator Jessop did that.

—I am sorry. That is a point of substance equal only to the one raised only a moment ago by the honourable senator. That Committee which brought down a report yesterday seems to use terminology passing strange, very much akin to the terminology which is being used in relation to the Missen proposition. At pages 21 and 22 of that report the Committee discusses what the work of a Senate appropriations and staffing committee would be. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: As a first step, it is recommended that the Senate establish a Standing Committee to be known as the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee.

It is proposed that the Committee would be chaired by the President and would comprise 6 other members-the Leader of the Government in the Senate to represent the Executive, and two other Government Senators, and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and two other Senators not being members of the Government.

I think that is a perfectly proper suggestion if we are talking about the management of the business of the Senate and the management of the committees of the Senate. The report then goes on to state:

The Standing Committee would be charged with the responsibility for the consideration of the proposed estimates for the Senate and the consideration of staffing proposals affecting the Senate and its Committees.
Paragraph 6.10 states:

In relation to staffing, the Committee would examine proposals seeking to vary the organisational structure of the Senate and its Committees, and staffing and recruitment policies and make recommendations to the President. It would report to the Senate on any matter it considered necessary.

I think it would be bordering on the bizarre for this procedure which Senator Missen has introduced to proceed today without a consideration of and debate on that report and an understanding amongst honourable senators as to what it means. What that report recommends is a bipartisan approach to the management of the Senate committees, their staffing and so on.

It may be said that the report does not mean what I have just said at all. Senator Jessop may well jump and say: 'That is an entirely different issue'. Perhaps the new Deputy President will perform some different function. If that be so, then it is a matter which should properly be discussed in the context of this report and in the context of the motion moved by Senator Missen. But that facility, that courtesy, has not been accorded to senators generally. We are not going to embark upon a course which may create a new little cabal of Government chairmen of committees, with a supremo sitting at the head of the table, which discusses the staffing and the financing of the committees, as well as the terms of reference of the committees, how they relate to one another and whether they overlap. We will not be parties to supporting a nice little cosy golden handshake cabal like that without having a much better understanding of the whole proposition than we have been allowed to gain to date or without being given the courtesy of being able to discuss and debate the matter in the Senate.

This proposal by-passes the Standing Orders Committee. In fact it ignores a decision of the Standing Orders Committee, which was that this matter should be discussed in that Committee before, in the normal course of events, going into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only a recommendation to the Senate, is it not? The Senate has control.

—I understand that. But if the Minister is trying to say that because the ultimate power lies with the Senate the normal courtesies of running a chamber can be totally ignored, that is his position, not mine.
—I did not say that. This is where it will be determined.

—That is the implication of what the Minister said. I have been privileged to see one little document that was given to members of the Standing Orders Committee about the function of this proposed new Deputy President (Committees). This is all the document said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy President (Committees) should have equal status with the 'Chairman of Committees' whose functions are, in fact, primarily related to the Chamber. That the present office of Chairman of Committees be changed to Deputy President (Procedures).

That is all I know about the proposal. That is all the Standing Orders Committee has known about the proposal until today. What is happening, of course, is that the Government parties have decided that this is the election season, perhaps they have to accommodate one of their colleagues who hit the fence in some other ballot and they want to create this new position.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not worthy of you.
—That may be an unfair statement. But why the hurry?
—Because this is when we have the election of officers.
—That is right. Why was something not done about it last year, when it was known that the elections were coming?
—Yes, we should have. I agree.

—Yes. You should have. But that leaves us in a very difficult situation. For those reasons I want to make it quite clear that we are opposed to this proposition. We are simply not persuaded of the need or the virtue of establishing this new position. Nobody has been courteous enough to explain it to us. The Senate cannot go on working in a proper atmosphere if these sorts of decision are to be made in club without any discussion on such questions as what the committees will do when the Government chairmen discuss issues of this kind without any Opposition representatives being present and so on. For those reasons we oppose the proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the time I have been in the Parliament this is the first time an attempt has been made to change Standing Orders by bringing in a motion of this nature and having it considered by the Senate in this fashion. Quite obviously no opportunity is to be given to the Senate to consider these very important amendments to Standing Orders in the usual way. What is the usual way? The usual way is that the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders gives consideration to proposals for amendments to Standing Orders. When its report comes to the Senate-to my knowledge there has been no deviation from this practice-invariably it is considered by the Senate in the Committee of the Whole. In other words, members of the Senate need not feel obliged to restrict their comments in their opening speech but can exchange points of view across the chamber in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come to some of the points in the proposition and point out precisely where such consideration would improve the document that is before us. The first time I knew of this proposition was approximately two weeks ago. Mr President, as you and other honourable senators know, having read in the Press of the decision of the Government parties to proceed with a move to establish two Deputy Presidents, I was not prepared to vote in respect of even one of those positions until such time as I knew the functions of both of them if both positions were to be established. The Senate, without dissent, agreed to that proposition on Tuesday of this week. From what Senator Missen has said we still do not know precisely what are to be the functions and ultimately the responsibilities of the new position of Deputy President (Committees). All we are told in the proposition is that under new Standing Order 28A that office holder will perform such duties and exercise such authority as the President may determine.

Quite frankly, I raise this matter with you, Mr President. I am not a lawyer but my view is that you would not have the ability to delegate your authority to such a person because under the Public Service Act you have the ultimate authority in respect of the employees in your Department. From what Senator Missen has said we are given to understand-if we are to give credence to what Senator Missen has said and I see no reason why we should not-that the main purpose is to corral 49 staff at the Canberra Hotel. I assume that other matters would be involved. Senator Missen did mention that there are areas of overlap in respect of committee references and so on.

I will deal with the first point first. Mr President, under the Public Service Act you have authority over those persons in your Department. With respect, you as President of this chamber will be receiving $20,000-odd more than the rest of us to assist you in performing your functions as President of the Senate. You have a relatively small Department compared with other departments. Your Department consists of something like 170 people. Of course, you have to be in the chamber but Standing Orders recognise that your duties will take you out of the chamber. On your own warrant you have the power to appoint, as you have done, at least two Temporary Chairmen of Committees to look after the procedures in this chamber. That enables you to do what Ministers are able to do, and that is to look after your Department.

I suggest that your departmental responsibilities are not as onerous as those of some other Ministers in the Government who have to attend to the Parliament and who have under their authority thousands of public servants throughout the length and breadth of this country. We are being asked to appoint another Deputy President to do what essentially is your job, sir, or the job of the Chairman of Committees. What does the Chairman of Committees do for his extra $8,000? Let us look at what the Chairman of Committees is supposed to be doing. I feel that it is not very good for the Government which is talking about tightening the belt--

TALK.START.PARA: —Austerity.

—Austerity. It is not very good for this Government to come into this chamber and ask the parliamentarians to create another position which will presumably ulti- mately attract another salary from the Remuneration Tribunal and so on.
—It is not the Government; it is the senators who are doing it.
—I make a correction. It is the Government senators who are doing it. We will see how the Government senators vote. I assume that they all have a free vote on the subject.
—I assume so.

—We will see how people vote. There are quite a number of other objections which could be raised at a given stage. The way in which this matter has come before this chamber does not enable us to have that exchange of views across the chamber which we are normally able to have when considering changes in Standing Orders. We are not in the Committee of the Whole at present. If we were we would be pointing to some of the oddities in this proposal, including the oddity which occurs in proposed new Standing Order 30A which talks about what happens should both the President and Deputy President (Committees) be unavoidably absent. It states that the senior Chairman of Committees shall perform the duties. Who is the senior Chairman of Committees? How is he defined? What commitees is he the senior Chairman of? What is meant by senior? Does it mean the oldest or the longest serving chairman? The proposed new Standing Order goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the senior Chairman of Committees shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees . . . , for that day only, and the appointment so made shall be notified to the Senate by the Deputy-President (Procedure).
What appointment does that refer to? An appointment has not been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be an automatic appointment because it will be known who is the chairman.
—If it is known why, under your proposed Standing Orders, does the Senate have to be notified?
—For the very good reason; so that people will know who it is.

—I think the honourable senator had better get back to the drawing board. There are quite a number of these problems and the honourable senator should look at them. I have dealt with the first point; that you, sir, have authority over your relatively small department. The second point relates to the question of the overlapping of references to particular committees. Of course, our function is to ensure in the initial stages, after establishing a select committee or making a reference to a standing committee, that we do not draft the terms with any overlap. That is our responsibility. We do not need a new Deputy President to do that. Also, it is wise at times for the chairmen to get together but in my view they ought to be got together under your presidency because you have the ultimate responsibility and it is to you, ultimately, that questions go. For example, at the moment I understand it is you who determine whether outside consultants are to be appointed to assist the committees in their work. It is you and you alone. If there is any matter for concern, it ought to go to you.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with what Senator Button has said. This matter should have gone through the Standing Orders Committee so that all of these wrinkles could have been ironed out. It has not done so; Government senators have decided to bring this proposal to us in a most extraordinary fashion, in a fashion in which such a matter, from my experience in the Senate, has never been brought to us before. Always a recommendation has been brought down from the Standing Orders Committee and we have then discussed it as a Committee of the Whole so that due debate and cross-fertilisation of ideas could proceed. It should not be done in this fashion, trying to roll it through the Senate in the way that is being attempted today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Missen for his continual concern for the effectiveness of the committees of this chamber. As the Australian Democrats have previously indicated, we do not necessarily disagree in principle with the creation of the position of an extra deputy president. However, having listened to arguments from honourable senators on both sides over the last two days, we are not persuaded that the establishment of such a position is at the moment necessary or desirable. We believe that any proposal which is put forward for the creation of a new position in this chamber-certainly one of such importance as that of a presiding officer-should have an extemely convincing case attached to it. We do not believe that such a case has been presented and therefore it would be wrong of this chamber to appropriate public moneys for expenditure on such a position. The Government has often talked about the need for restraint. We believe this may be another case in which restraint should be exercised. To have three presiding officers in a chamber of 64 members would probably make us unique in the Western world and certainly would overload the administrative element at the top.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major concerns circulated involves the staff of the committees. They are part of the Department of the Senate and, as Senator Harradine has clearly pointed out, come under the control of the President of the Senate. Therefore, they are directly under the control of a senator who fulfils the task of the President. If the Government feels that the load on the President of the Senate is excessive, adequate assistance can be given by the person holding the position of Chairman of Committees. The Chairman of Committees performs the duties and exercises the authority of the President in his absence, and takes the chair whenever requested to do so by the President. Standing Order 28 also specifies that the Chairman of Committees shall take the chair in the Committee whenever the Senate resolves itself into a Committee of the Whole. Relief from these duties, if they are too onerous, is provided by the panel of temporary chairmen appointed to give such relief. The Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 provides, in essence, that if the Presiding Officer dies, is absent from the Commonwealth or is incapable by reason of illness of exercising any powers or functions under the law of the Commonwealth, the Chairman of Committee shall, for the purpose of the exercise of such powers, be deemed to be the presidng officer.

Therefore, it seems that, as has been traditionally established, under Standing Orders, it is highly appropriate that the control of the staff of the committees of the Senate should fall readily under the control of the Chairman of Committees. It seems to us that the efficiency of the committee system will not be necessarily increased by the appointment of a third person. The appropriation of moneys has not been sufficiently argued for. Therefore, we do not see that it would be inappropriate for those additional responsibilities put forward by Senator Missen to be formally referred to the Chairman of Committees and carried out by him. In conclusion, we hope that we may proceed as soon as possible to the election of this chamber's Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments in this debate. I suggest that Senator Macklin is not fully aware of the importance of the committee system in the Senate or of the thrust behind the proposition before us. I believe it is a very important matter. If we are to persist with the committee system it is important that there be some restructuring of the staffing arrangements and the administration generally to give full effect to it. I object very strongly to Senator Button's allegation that this is a 'Rae report'. That is quite untrue. Senator Rae happened to be the spokesman for the committee of Senate standing commitee chairmen. I had a considerable input into that report and other honourable senators contributed in a similar way. It was up to Senator Rae to put the proposition to the Government party room to get approval for the proposition that flowed from many weeks of discussions in the interest and spirit of helping the Senate committee system and helping this chamber, including the new members from the Australian Democrats, to become more effective. I am very pleased to say that Senator Mason is on my committee and has contributed a tremendous amount to it. I am looking forward to continuing the co-operation that has always existed on our committee.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great things about the Senate is that we can submerge personalities in our committee system. We can offer to the government of the day constructive criticism about what it ought to be doing in certain policy matters. I believe that is one of the challenges we can meet here, and so be quite effective. I am happy to offer to a government criticism, constructive as it always is, in regard to what course it should be taking in regard to formulating policy for the future. The committee system lends us that capacity because we go out among the public, we have public hearings and we call evidence from interested people throughout the community on the subject before us. Having sifted through that evidence and having made a judgment on what the electorate at large wants, we present in this chamber, I am very pleased to say in regard to my committee, unanimous, tripartite, tripartisan recommendations. That is important to remember. I, for one, believe it is in that sort of spirit that the Senate should recognise the need to retain adequate staff. That is the reason behind my first recommendation to the Senate chairmen.

I suggested that this sort of structure would be good because in the past, as committee chairmen and as members of committees, we have found that we have lost staff because an adequate career structure has not been provided in this Senate to ensure that the experienced officers who advise and help us with our work are retained. Time and again we see that a senior, very experienced, intelligent officer is attracted outside, either into private enterprise or into government departments. Therefore the Senate loses and the committee system loses as well. It is in that spirit that we have come forward with a proposition that was accepted by the Government parties.

It is untrue to say that the Opposition was not aware of that report because I know for a fact that copies of it were distributed for the information of the Opposition towards the end of last year, certainly before the Parliament rose. In February this year copies were made avialable for distribution to anyone else who cared to examine the recommendations. I am surprised to learn that Senator Harradine says he was only made aware of this report two weeks ago. I think that is incredible because these reports were distributed about this Parliament like confetti. Knowing how one or two documents can be leaked and how everyone in Australia seems to find out about that, it amazes me that 70 or 80 reports floating around would not attract the attention of interested senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody talked to me then.

—I would talk to the honourable senator any time. I have even examined his mother's and father's eyes. I know the honourable senator very well. He may feel free to talk to me at any time if he feels he is being shut off, because I am not the sort of person to ignore him. I think the honourable senator is quite correct in saying that perhaps the Standing Orders Committee ought to have dealt with the matter. That is something I would be concerned about, as is Senator Missen.
—You can still do that. As far as we are concerned you can still do that in the future and bring it back to the Senate.

—Okay. It would appear at this stage that the numbers will be such that the proposition we are putting before the Senate may not succeed. I know that the Australian Democrats are interested in the committee system. I have proof of that by the active work Senator Mason has done on my Committee. I would have thought that the Leader of the Opposition would have been above the sort of unfair allegation he made in suggesting that this proposal was conceived and contrived by Senator Peter Rae. That is totally untrue. I believe it is totally reprehensible on his part to suggest such a thing because a lot of us on the Senate Chairmen's Committee we are talking about had an input. I suggest that if we do not have the numbers to deal with this now, the Standing Orders Committee, through you, Mr President, be called together as a matter of urgency and that the matter be discussed. Then we can come back into this place and vote on it and, I hope, attract the full support of this chamber. It is a progressive move designed to make the committee system in this place far more effective. It is effective now but I believe that we need to provide this career structure. We need to have a Deputy President (Committees) and a Deputy Clerk (Committees). The Deputy Clerk (Committees) would be responsible to the Clerk of the Senate, as the Deputy President (Committees) would be responsible to the President. We need to provide the opportunity for a career structure in this place so that we can retain effective members of the staff to advise us and to make sure our representations through this chamber and our recommendations to the government of the day are taken notice of. I ask the new senators and the more experienced Australian Democrats here to have regard to that point. I know that the Australian Labor Party, which purported to be at the forefront of the establishment of this system, will agree with what I have said and will recognise the importance of it at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no cause to delay the Senate on this matter except to clarify points which Senator Jessop has attributed to my leader, Senator Button. The only reprehensible thing about this matter is the manner in which Government senators have brought it before the Senate. Senator Jessop tells us that a report on a possible extra Chairman of Committees and Deputy President has been around for several months. A report was around, but it was a very brief one containing a very scanty outline of what was in mind. I think it was presented to senators at the end of last year. We considered it and awaited the next procedure, which we thought would have been a fuller report which would have been considered by the Standing Orders Committee.
—It was not presented to this senator.

—It was not presented to Senator Harradine when, indeed, it should have been. It certainly was not presented to those senators who have been here only a couple of days. The correct procedure would have been to go through the right channels and take this through the Standing Orders Committee. But, as Senator Button pointed out, the whole thing has been overtaken by another committee of which Senator Jessop is a member; a committee which recommends a bipartisan group in this House, a bipartisan committee, to do the functions that he wants this new Deputy Chairman of Committees to do.
—That is not so at all.
—Not so.
—Of course it is. Senator Jessop should read the report of his own committee, the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. I quote from that report:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to staffing, the Committee would examine proposals seeking to vary the organisational structure of the Senate and its Committees, and staffing and recruitment policies and make recommendations to the President. It would report to the Senate on any matter it considered necessary.

That is the way to do it. The result of the honourable senator's proposal will be a committee of chairmen of committees of this Senate, who will all be government senators, and a new Deputy President who will almost certainly be a government senator. That is not a bipartisan approach. I believe that that is not the way to go about the procedure. As Senator Harradine and others have pointed out, we already have a Chairman of Committees and a President in this place. We do not have a very big staff. It would seem to us that adequate powers and conditions exist for both those people to conduct the procedures that the honourable senator wants this new office to take over. Therefore, I suggest, rather than as Senator Jessop suggested-that if he does not have the numbers to get this proposition through today we should put it off for another week and see whether we can get the numbers-we should vote on it now and get on and elect a Chairman of Commitees in this place, which we should have done two days ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen has already put forward substantial arguments for this proposal. In response, very clear arguments have been put forward by the Opposition, by the Australian Democrats and, in particular, by Senator Harradine as to the inadequacy of the proposition as far as they are concerned. An objection being raised is that this matter is being rushed. It has not been referred to the Senate Standing Orders Committee and earlier documents in one form or another were not sufficiently circulated on an informal basis. I am of a mind to move that this matter be now referred to the Standing Orders Committee, but I do not do so at this stage. I understand that such was the form of words of the procedural motion moved by Senator Harradine on Tuesday that we would not be able to proceed to the election of the Chairman of Committees if this matter was referred to the Standing Orders Committee. I think it is appropriate that we elect a Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see the Senate consider this matter again but only after the report has been sufficiently circulated for discussion and after the Standing Orders Committee has considered it and the objections that have been raised, largely on procedural grounds, in the debate this afternoon have been taken into account. I return to the very real merits of Senator Missen's original argument. My only regret is that, because of these procedural aspects, which, frankly, do lie at the feet of Government supporters, there has not been a sufficient unanimity of view in the Senate today to enable this matter properly to proceed.

The only reflection that I wish to make, as one Government senator, is that the rush this week has come about almost entirely because of the quite proper procedural motion put down by Senator Harradine, and that before we consider electing the Chairman of Committees the Senate ought to know how many Deputy Presidents are to be proposed. That is a quite proper suggestion. If that had not been moved I do not believe that this matter would have been so quickly, as it were, rushed on to the Senate business paper. That is the error of judgment, if you like, the reason, as I see it for Government members rushing ahead. I do not see it as any intended discourtesy to other honourable senators. In such an important matter it is necessary that all honourable senators of all parties and views be able to give it full consideration. Therefore, as one Government senator, I believe that there has been an error of judgment in regard to timing. It is one which is innocent and easily explainable. I hope that the substantial reasons that Senator Missen has put forward can be revived by the matter, in due course, being reintroduced and referred to the appropriate Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am somewhat amazed at certain attitudes that have been expressed today. I stand strongly behind the motion and propose to reply to the detailed arguments that have been advanced by various senators. I find it difficult to contemplate the attitudes of the Australian Labor Party. I wish I could believe that the Australian Democrats would think independently on this matter, that they would think again about what will be done to the Senate system if some proposal such as I have moved today is not adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party can claim considerable credit for the early development of the Senate system. Moreover, many of its members have served in a distinguished way on Senate committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our participation in the development of this system is what gave this whole place its delusions of grandeur.

—The honourable senator may think that on this side we have delusions of grandeur; that perhaps I have such delusions and he has not. Time will be the judge of that. But, to give the honourable senator the retort courteous, I pay tribute to his work as a member of my Committee.
—It is not your Committee. No senator can lay claim to a committee. He is only its chairman. That is something that the Liberals always do. You speak of them as your committees.
—I do not think that I have ever referred to my Committee as mine.
—You always do; you just did then.

—I do not think the honourable senator could have heard me say that because he was talking at the time. I, of course, did not say it. I do not lay claim to any committee. I say that the glory of the Senate committee is what has been achieved by the bipartisan approach. That is reflected in the unanimous reports that have been brought down and in the agreements reached on them. It has been reflected in this chamber in the much better temper and standard of debate on these matters. Let us not forget that the committee system has achieved something in the last 10 years, or that very easily it could slip away and become something of an irrelevance in this whole parliamentary setup. I fear that we may be on that route if we do not do something now to try to get over the present hump and try to ensure that we have control of the development of the committee system and make the most effective use of the staff. It is with this in mind that the proposal is put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret enormously the earlier snide remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button), who is not usually given to that type of conduct, in suggesting that this was some idea that was dreamed up by Senator Peter Rae and that we were putting him forward. This idea came from the Senate committee. We contributed it and must take the responsibility for it. If it is a stupid idea blame us for it. In a number of meetings we have slowly worked out what we believe would be a better way of running things. This idea has floated around for a considerable time. I regret that somehow Senator Harradine has not seen a copy of the report. So far as I know there was nothing secret about it. I thought that it had been available generally. Senator Harradine has known that this has been mooted for a long time, and especially in the last couple of days it has been discussed. Senator Chipp's research officers have spoken to me about what we had in mind as have other people. I have supplied them with information as best I could, but I have not heard about it from Senator Harradine at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never given me anything.

—I have never given anybody anything about this. I did not say that I had. The honourable senator should have been listening. I said that people came seeking information and that I told them what I thought about the position, what I had in mind and what I proposed to do today. So there was no secret about the matter at all.

—The only thing that you have not persuaded us on is as to why the present Chairman of Committees cannot do the job of the proposed Chairman; but please come back with it in one or two months, through the Standing Orders Committee.
—I come back to it now and talk about it. We have had a Chairman of Committees for a long time.
—What has he been doing?

—He has been responsible in this chamber. Very often he sits in the chair of this chamber for long periods. He has a great deal of responsibility in this chamber. When the President is away or is out of the country he has the supreme responsibility.
—We have not got one at the moment.

—The honourable senator is very quick today. He has realised that. When the President is away, the Chairman of Committees has the full responsibility to preside in this chamber. He has had that task for quite a long time. I say to the new Democrats, who-with one exception-have not had responsibility on committees, that the Chairman of Committees has never taken part in the control of those committees or helped chair them, because his duties lie in this chamber. His responsibility is a chamber responsibility. What is needed is someone who has not had that chamber responsibility and may therefore be the supervising agent for the Senate in the committee system.
—There are now eight Temporary Chairmen.

—Again, the Temporary Chairmen have also a responsibility to preside in this chamber. They are given no responsibility in regard to the committee system. I cannot understand why the honourable senator should be so obtuse in regard to that point. I will be very generous and say that I do not think he understands it; perhaps he does not want to. We have heard made the statement that we have ignored the Standing Orders Committee by broaching this. This is a new Parliament and we have to decide who are to be the Presiding Officers. The Presiding Officers do not include the proposed new Deputy Chairman (Committees). He would not preside in this chamber and would have no responsibility in that regard. His responsibility would be outside the chamber and with the committees. But the honourable senator says: 'It is not raised and it was not dealt with'. I think it should have been raised more vigorously in the last Parliament with the Standing Orders Committee. I agree with that and criticism can be made on that score. I did not have any responsibility for this matter until a couple of days ago. But I have the responsibility as a member of the chairmen's committee to put it forward.
—When did the day of enlightenment start?

—There was no day of enlightenment. We have been working towards this for a year. We have the report of 18 August of last year to which the Chairmen of Committees have appended their signatures and their names and which put forward the proposal. So I can assure honourable senators that there has been no sudden light on the road to Damascus. We have known all about this and the idea has been floated for some considerable time. Sure, the criticism can be made that perhaps the Standing Orders Committee should have gone further into the report during the last Parliament. However, it did not. We now have to elect officers of the Senate. Therefore I think we ought to try to be a little less conservative. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber ought to be more ready to recognise and to deal with the item on its merit and not according to precedent, because it is important that we now deal with this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine in the course of his speech made some criticism of the terms of proposed Standing Order 28A. Let me just read the proposed Standing Order again. It says:

The Deputy-President (Committees) shall perform such duties and exercise such authority in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives as the President may determine.

Senator Harradine wanted spelt out in some detail exactly what the Deputy President should do. To do that would be most foolish. If in fact we spelt out his duties and if other things developed in the course of this Parliament he would be stuck with what was determined. It is obvious from that that the Deputy President's real concern would be the general supervision of the various committees of the Parliament. The President can be trusted--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you have misunderstood my statement completely. I said that the President could not delegate his authority.

—I have not come to that point. I ask the honourable senator just to wait. I will deal first with another point raised by the honourable senator. The honourable senator tried to suggest that the proposed Standing Order did not spell out or give an idea of what the President should do and that it was inadequate. It is not inadequate. The President is fully competent to and capable of giving directions as to where his authority shall end and where it might be extended. The proposed Standing Order sufficiently sets out a purpose which would make very clear what the new officer should do.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come immediately to the point mentioned by Senator Harradine. The honourable senator says that the President should do all this. The honourable senator made some snide remark about the President receiving an extra $28,000 or something. He said that therefore the President should do all these things, that he has the ultimate responsibility. Of course he has the ultimate responsibility. But this does not mean that he has the responsibility for doing everything around the place, nor does it mean he could possibly act in that way. Any officer, whether it be the President or someone else, who cannot delegate, is not competently doing his duty. Of course, the President cannot preside over all meetings of the Chairmen. He cannot do all the things that are necessary. He cannot supervise what is going on in the secretariat and so fourth. It is wrong to suggest that the President should be expected to do that. Senator Harradine went on to say that the President should get one of the chairmen to carry out these duties. Because the Chairmen have to preside in this place they could not perform them either. Therefore I suggest that the honourable senator's so-called criticism of the Standing Order is pettyfogging. There are in fact no wrinkles on this proposal which has been drawn up with the great assistance of the Clerks. I think it competently provides for what is proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it been drawn up with the assistance of Clerks?
—Yes, of course it has.
—What about Standing Order 198? I will leave that until the next time.
—I do not know what Standing Order 198 says.
—You have proposed amendments to it.
—Anyway, the honourable senator has not raised that in his speech.
—No, because I did not have time.

—The honourable senator was very concerned that there should be interchange across the chamber. There seems to be plenty of interchange across the chamber. I suggest that we are in fact dealing with this matter in the way in which it should be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very sorry to see that although Senator Macklin does not disagree in principle he has not been persuaded that there is a need for this position. I think I have explained why the Chairman of Committees cannot do it, why he has not done it, and why he is a responsible officer in the chamber and is therefore not one to carry out the tasks which we suggest are essential now to be done for the committee system.

Finally, as Senator Grimes said, he has known about this proposal since the end of last year. I do not know whether the honourable senator has made any criticism of the terms of this proposal. However, he makes the point that the report of Senator Jessop's Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, of which I was a member, is somehow inconsistent with what is proposed today. It is not. Of course, if that Committee's recommendations about staffing, separating the appropriations and getting control back in the Parliament for these appropriations are adopted I expect that the Deputy President-Committees will be a member of that proposed committee if it is appointed. It would be very desirable for him to be on that committee so that he could advise. I said that in the course of my first speech. So there is nothing inconsistent whatsoever between that report which came in during the recess and the recommendations which we put before the Senate today.

Whether the proposal wins today is not perhaps the question. It may be that unless some members of the Senate do have a second thought about this it may lose. I say to honourable members that I believe they will do a very damaging blow to the future development of the committee system if they reject this proposal because the reasons for rejection have been specious. I can understand that there has been some ruffling of feathers for which, if honourable senators like, I will make an apology. But I suggest that the overall proposal will improve the Senate committee system and it is therefore worthy of support. I urge honourable senators to vote for it.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation. Mr President, as you would well know, Senator Button made a somewhat snide suggestion that the proposal that was supported by Government senators had been put forward because it was to cater for some colleague who hit the fence in some other ballot. SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that for the last two or three days I have felt a bit like that character Hanrahan but now I feel as if I am somewhat like Cazaly.
