DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS RELATING TO TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 November 1980, 2 December 1980, 4 December 1980, 24 February 1981, 26 February 1981, 10 March 1981, 12 March 1981, 7 April 1981, 9 April 1981, 30 April 1981, 5 May 1981, 12 May 1981, 26 May 1981 and 11 June 1981 on motions:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr President, as so many others have done, on your election to the high office of President of the Senate. I am sure that you will carry out your job in an excellent way. On this occasion I address myself to three major areas of the communications network, namely, television, telephone and broadcasting services, which are in dire need of upgrading and strengthening in Queensland. The State that I represent is enormous, stretching some 2,400 kilometres from Brisbane to the islands of the Torres Strait beyond Cape York and westward more than 1,600 kilometres out to Birdsville and beyond. That gives honourable senators an idea of the large area of land I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the population of Queensland is increasing at the enormous rate of 2.29 per cent a year compared with a 1.34 per cent increase for Australia as a whole. In fact, last year more than 50,000 people came to Queensland to settle, many from Victoria and New South Wales. With such distances to contend with and with an ever-increasing population, one can see that Queensland is an exceptional State with exceptional needs when it comes to adequate communication services. Whilst it is true that telephone and other communications needs in many areas of Australia are inadequate or unsatisfactory, the problem is particularly acute in Queensland.

As fellow senators will be aware, over the past 10 or so years I have travelled extensively in the State of Queensland. No matter where I go or to whom I talk, the problem of inadequate and, in some cases, non-existent telephone services is always a major worry. In fact, during the recent parliamentary recess I spent three weeks making an extensive tour of the south-western, western, northern and north-western areas of Queensland where I met with people and talked to them about their problems. For people living outside the major metropolitan and provincial areas, the telephone is very often the only means of communication with the outside world, so to speak. Yet in these rural areas there is still discrimination against families who need and want telephone services. Present charges by the Australian Telecommunications Commission for erecting the required telephone lines amount to approximately $160 a half kilometre. This makes it financially impossible for some people even to consider having the telephone connected. In addition to that, a special rental charge of $380 for those outside the free entitlement area places an unfair burden on those people already disadvantaged by distance. Surely some of the excessive profits made by Telecom each year could be devoted to making a standard installation charge and also a standard call charge available to every Australian.

We must not forget that people living and working in remote areas of Australia are involved in industries which earn a huge slice of export income for all Australians each year, thus contributing towards a high standard of living, which most Australians enjoy-a standard which includes a telephone for an annual rental of $120 for businesses or $85 for private use. Surely, then, the time has come for a complete overhaul and updating of telephone installation policy, aimed at setting a standard installation fee and yearly rental for all subscribers, regardless of residence. After all, postage stamps cost the same, no matter what the cost of delivering the letter might be.

It is not only the people of rural Queensland who are suffering from inadequate telephone services. The Gold Coast and Sunshine Coast areas of Queensland, which are experiencing phenomenal growth rates, are growing in telephone demand much more quickly than any other areas in the nation. The system is so overloaded in both of these areas, for example, that many businesses and indeed some private subscribers do not even attempt to make outgoing calls during the first few hours of each work-day because of the almost continual engaged signals received. Impossible as it may sound, instances have been given to me of school classes going without teachers because, though the stand-by teacher was in the house and near the phone all day, the phone did not ring. Indeed, the principal making the calls for assistance simply could not get through.

Other Telecom charges which should be looked at include those levied as overtime charges on business houses which move their services and request weekend or holiday work. I know of one business house in Brisbane which was charged $3,200 for work done on Anzac Day, when practically all of the work had been completed during normal work-hours before that day. This transfer led to a task force of eight men being employed on Anzac Day. Furthermore, the work was not correctly done and more technicians had to visit the office and fix the system during the Monday, at great inconvenience to the business, not to mention, of course, the added cost. Surely in an age of space shuttle programs, men on the moon and incredible computer feats, it is not too much to ask that taxpaying Australians have access to adequate telephone services.

I turn now to the problems of television and broadcasting services in Queensland. I have received many representations from people, not only in Queensland but also all over Australia, expressing concern at the poor quality of television services available to those Australians who do not happen to live in the golden triangle of Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra or in other capital or major provincial cities. Indeed, for many, there will be no television at all until the satellite program gears up further. I will talk about that shortly. However, for some the service is at best marginal because of the low power of the translator or repeater stations which have been erected. Some complaints have been made that specific area needs were not taken into consideration sufficiently when the height of the towers and the powers of the transmitters were decided. Other complaints centre on the poor quality of Australian broadcasting-television and radio-especially where the Australian Broadcasting Commission is the only service available, which is the situation in much of western Queensland. Whilst I applaud the ABC for its achievements in the field of television programs and in much radio broadcasting, I do feel that the lack of drama and features on ABC Radio 3 in particular is a matter of concern to many rural dwellers. At a time when in Britain and Europe drama and features are considered to be an essential part of radio programming, not only from the point of view of the listeners but also from the point of view of the writing and acting professions, the ABC is allowing a reduction in these programs. What little drama the ABC does have to offer it denies to country people by not broadcasting it through ABC Radio 3.

The ABC, I know, has claimed that cutbacks in government funding are responsible for the continuing reduction in drama and features and the continuing denial to rural people of what some have called intelligent radio. Thus, this week's announcement by Treasurer John Howard that the ABC will receive $234m in this financial year, which is an increase of 22.6 per cent on last year including $12.1m for the Commission as host broadcaster for the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Brisbane and $16m to meet employer superannuation liabilities, is timely, and will certainly be welcomed by the ABC and by rural dwellers. Further, the $9.7m which has been allocated to improve and extend the national broadcasting and television service network, including facilities used for Radio Australia, will be a great help in improving those very services to country areas about which I have just spoken.

However, even with this increase in funds, it will still be a question of priorities in programming, deciding in which areas the ABC feels the greatest needs are. It seems to me that there must be a rearrangement of priorities so that what money there is will be utilised to the best advantage of all people. For most people living outside the capital cities, particularly in areas where there is no television, the ABC radio is their lifeline to any form of news, fine music and drama. There are no professional theatres in these places-no professional orchestras-such as people living in the city and provincial areas are able to enjoy and take so much for granted. What the ABC does not provide, people living in remote country areas simply do not get. It is to be hoped that the introduction of the Intelsat IV satellite system, which forms the basis for a comprehensive program to bring television to remote areas throughout Queensland and Australia, will help to alleviate some of the communication frustrations experienced by western Queenslanders. This program has already enabled approximately 50 remote locations to receive television services during the 1980-81 period, and a further 20 stations throughout Australia will be established in 1981-82. The recent launching of broadcasting stations at Bedourie, Birdsville, Injune, Tambo and Quilpie indeed heralded the start of a new era in communications for remote areas of Queensland. I look forward to seeing similar operations begin broadcasting from other isolated centres in the near future.

During the last session of this Parliament we also saw the launching of the Hills Telesat satellite receiving system, which is, I believe, the first commercial system to improve outback television reception. This system is capable of receiving signals from Intelsat IV and enables a large area right across Australia to receive colour television. Hopefully the introduction of satellite communications will also open up the way for the much-needed improved telephone communications. I suppose one could say that with the introduction of the Government's program remote areas of the State are now only a satellite's throw away from the rest of the world. Indeed, I certainly hope so. I am proud to speak on behalf of the people of the remote areas of Queensland when I ask the Government to consider the facts and to work towards ensuring that these basic needs, which most of us would take for granted, are met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on transport and communications. Firstly I want to reply to what Senator Bjelke-Petersen has been saying about telephone charges. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is actually advocating that people who live in cities and urban towns should have their telephone connection charges upgraded to what they cost in the country. I think she asked a question yesterday--
—No, I did not.

—It must have been yesterday when she asked a question about the matter. She made no mention of the fact that the country charges ought to be reduced to the charges which now apply in the cities. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is saying that they should be equalised. Of course, this Government will not reduce any charges, as we all know. The Government may take up her suggestion and before we know where we are all the people in this country who live in the city will be paying the same as people who live in the country for a telephone connection. I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen of the pork barrelling that went on in Queensland prior to the Australian Labor Party coming into government in 1972 when Lionel Bowen, the member for Kingsford-Smith, became the Postmaster-General. When he went through all the dockets in the Postmaster-General's Department he found that a great many telephone connections were being made in Country Party electorates in Queensland which was costing the Australian taxpayer in the vicinity of $25,000 a connection.
—No.

—That is a fact. I have seen the dockets. It is no use Senator Bjelke-Petersen saying 'no' because I saw the dockets when I was on a committee. That is what the Australian taxpayer was having to pay under a Liberal-Country Party Government. The present Federal Government is wagged by the National Country Party, as it calls itself. As soon as the Country Party falls into disrepute with the electors it changes its name. As I have said in this place on many occasions I am proud to be a member of a political party which has never had to change its name because it has fallen into disrepute with the electors. We are pleased to fly under the flag of the Labor Party come what may, but this is not the case with the people who sit opposite. We can go right back into history: Every time there was a problem and the name of that party fell into disfavour the party changed its political name and tried to hoodwink the people into thinking its whole policy had changed. The policy is the same but the name has changed.

SPEECH.PARA: That is something like what has happened with the Australian National Railways Commission to which I will refer shortly. That matter involved another enormous waste of public money. I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that Queenslanders are very well to the fore when it comes to pork barrelling for their own supporters but not when it comes to the general public who live in Queensland. I hope that Senator Bjelke-Petersen did not mean what she was inferring, that is, that city people should have to pay the same charges for telephone connections as country people pay. We know that the revenue gained by Telecom Australia from the city connections and the business people is far in excess of what it gains from country people. I am a country member; I live in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would like your prices to be reduced, I am sure.

—No, I am not asking for my charges to be reduced at all because I think if the honourable senator follows through the philosophy of her party she will find that it is that the user pays. Why does the honourable senator want the people who live in country towns to subsidise some of the very few people who have to live in the far-flung areas? I have had to work and live in far-flung areas for the greater part of my life. There are certain compensations for those who live in country areas, particularly for primary producers. I was a primary producer. I know of all the concessions that are given to primary producers by way of the Australian Taxation Office. They are not as badly treated as Senator Bjelke-Petersen would have us believe. A booklet is put out by the Taxation Office which shows all the ways people can get remissions on their taxes if they are legitimate primary producers, and, believe you me, they are used to the full. So primary producers are not as badly done by as Senator Bjelke-Petersen would have us believe.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the matter I really want to talk about, and that is the railway system in Australia. I have spoken about it before. I refer to the enormous waste of money by the Australian National Railways Commision. It expended $409,000 recently just to drop the word 'Railways' from the name Australian National Railways. It used always to be known as the Australian National Railways. If I telephone the Australian National Railways what is the answer I receive from the receptionist at head office? She says: 'Australian National'. I then ask the girl on the switch: 'Australian National what? Is it the Australian national health scheme or the Australian national dental scheme?' The girl then has to say: 'It's you again, Senator'. She says that I should speak to Dr Williams because he is the man responsible. I have said to her on many occasions: 'I am not blaming you. It is not your fault'. I have raised the matter many times in the Parliament and Dr Williams has not been drawn into writing to me to point out where I am wrong and he is right. No doubt he reads my remarks; they would be given to him by the Department of Transport. He would have read every word I have said in severe criticism of him.

I have also presented many petitions in this Parliament from many residents and past users of the railways in South Australia complaining about the policy of the ANR in curtailing country rail services and, in particular, increasing rail freights for the delivery of small parcels to country areas. It has got to the stage now where people who operate small businesses in the country cannot afford to trade with the railways. It is cheaper to send their parcels by post. The Australian Postal Commission has a contract with the railways. It charges the user less than what the railways charge, and because of its contract rates it sends all articles in a canvas bag on the railways. So the railways are still carting the articles. The Postal Commission is taking business away from the railways. If people do not send articles by post they are blackmailed by small carriers.

I had an instance of a businessman in my town who had a small parcel sent from Melbourne. He asked for it to be sent by rail but because the railways will not take small parcels as they want articles to be sent in container lots the parcel was sent by road. It went to Melbourne through Murray Bridge at a certain price and was sent with another carrier back to Murray Bridge. The freight cost the man more than the articles he had bought. How did he get out of that situation? He then had to add that freight price onto the cost of the articles before he sold it just to break even, which made the item cost much more than people would pay in the metropolitan areas. Of course, country people do not buy from the small country business people. They go to the metropolitan areas and buy from the supermarkets.

That is the policy of this Government on transport and, in particular, railways. That is what the Government is doing to small business in the country areas, particularly in South Australia. That is where I have the concrete evidence of this happening. The Government puts itself up to be a government which supports the well-being of small business but it is doing its very best to kill it and hand over everything to big business. We all know what will happen in the not too distant future when small businesses, particularly those in major country towns and smaller country towns, will have to close because they cannot make a profit. When the supermarkets have no competition they will not offer cut rate prices and prices will rise to their maximum. Who will suffer? It will be the consumer. Apart from suffering from the cost of rail freight they will suffer again when this sales tax is sneaked in from 1 January. The people who live in country areas in particular are being penalised by a government which always puts itself up to be a government which supports country people.

Senator Messner gave me an answer to a question I asked about what it cost the Australian National Railways Commission to change its name from Australian National Railways to Australian National. It has not even started to work yet. I have looked through the explanatory notes for the estimates of the Department of Transport for this year. I find that they still refer on seven pages to Australian National Railways. Some hundreds of thousands, even millions, of dollars are being expended. The Railways Commission gave $409,000 to a public consultancy company-no doubt a good friend of the Government-just to change its name and to change the colour of the railway wagons and locomotives. They now have green and gold on them. As I said before, that has not attracted any more patronage; patrons are being turned away from the railways.

I have explained before what the Australian National Railways Commission is doing to its wonderful passenger service, the Indian Pacific, which runs between Perth and Sydney, right across Australia. Because of its stupid booking arrangements, many times it runs dead cars and people are told they cannot have a seat. But after talking to other people who have travelled on the train they wanted to travel on, they find there was an empty car. I explained that in detail here before we rose for the winter recess. I had incorporated in Hansard a letter from a person who runs the British Broadcasting Corporation program in London entitled Railways of the World. In that letter he said that because of the way in which Australian National Railways conducts is booking service he might have to put a rider on a film the BBC had made which will be shown in Australia recommending that people do not try to get a seat on that train. As I have said before, I have travelled on railways in various parts of the world and it is my belief that the Indian Pacific service is second to none. The train ought to be full on every night that it runs, from east to west and from west to east. There is no excuse for all those cars on that train not being full. If more people want to ride on it extra cars should be put on. The policy of this Government is to channel as much business as possible into the hands of private enterprise because it is private enterprise that supports this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They keep it empty and save staff.

—That is right. Senator Robertson and I travelled back from Western Australia on the train in February of this year and we had a discussion with the staff. We were told that if they do not have enough passengers on the return trip, because of their stupid booking system, they return with a dead car and the people who might have gone over on the train to service the car come back as staff on 60 per cent of their wages. They just sit there doing nothing but receive 60 per cent of their wages. Yet people have been told that they cannot get a seat on the train. The last time I spoke on railways I asked the Government to do something about it. I understand that Senator Messner was going to inquire and let me know the result. I have not had time to look that up in Hansard. At this time I have had no response from Senator Messner as to whether the booking arrangements for the Indian Pacific are to be changed so that train can run full every time.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter to which I wish to refer received a lot of publicity prior to the last election. This Government said it would fund the electrification of the railway system between Sydney and Melbourne. We hear nothing about it now because it was just an empty election promise. It fooled the people into thinking they would get an electrified system between Sydney and Melbourne. Articles have been written about it. I have a copy of quite a large article here but I do not have time to read it. I remind honourable senators that they can obtain a copy from the Parliamentary Library. They will be astounded by all the wonderful promises made about the electrification of the Sydney to Melbourne rail link. Nothing has been done about it and I very much doubt whether anything ever will be done.

The other project about which the Government has made great play is the railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin. I think it was mentioned in the Budget Speech and there is now a small amount of money available for a study on the construction of that line. If the Government does not have a better booking arrangement for passengers it might as well not construct it. I am very doubtful whether this line will be constructed during this Government's term of office. It is famous for uprooting the line there when it came into office-the Larrimah-Darwin link. In Darwin now one can see rusty wagons lying all over the place. Many have been freighted to Port Lincoln where they are being renovated for use on the Eyre Peninsula railway line. That shows the Government's policy on railways.

Another report under discussion today deals with the sea transport of live sheep. We all know that this has come back into the news to a great extent in the last few months because of the closure of many of the abattoirs in the country areas of Australia. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union lays a lot of the blame on the export of live sheep from Australia. Jobs are being exported. In Murray Bridge in South Australia, where I live-this probably does not relate to the export of live sheep-a week ago the whole beef chain closed down. We now have a situation in Murray Bridge where half the work force that was employed at the local abattoirs is out of work. Those people will have to go on the dole; there is no work to be got there. In Portland, Borthwicks, a major sheep slaughtering enterprise, has closed down. On top of that this Government is upping energy charges after making false promises to the Alcoa company on cheap electricity. Now it cannot deliver and the charges have been increased by 20 per cent. Those of us who watched television last night saw that the town of Portland in Victoria, where I lived for many years, is in a state of utter confusion. If Alcoa pulls out, coupled with the loss of Borthwicks export abattoirs, the town will be in dire straits.

All over the country we find that abattoirs, particularly those that in the main have slaughtered sheep, do not have the sheep now because they are being exported live. Recently a huge sheep liner was docked in Port Adelaide because it had engine trouble. The crew could not get it going to move it away from the dock. What were they doing with the dead sheep? They were thrown overboard and were washed up on the foreshore around Adelaide. They were not even split open so the fish could eat them. The shippers had to bring in another ship to trans-ship the sheep away from the wharf because under quarantine regulations they were not allowed to unload them. Rightly so. This Government needs to have a further look at what is going on with the live sheep export business in this country.

The report deals mainly with the humane treatment of live sheep. It gives death rates and weight losses from the time they are loaded at any of the Australian ports to the time they are unloaded in the Middle East. All of that data is there. No inquiry has yet been held by the Government into what effect live sheep exports are having on the employment of our own people. I say again that it is time this Government stood back and had a close look at what is happening in this country, particularly in the rural areas. The export of live sheep affects the livelihoods of many people employed in slaughterhouses. I guess it will come about that next year, after the flush season we are having, the farmers who now claim they are making a lot of money out of the export of live sheep will have built up their sheep numbers because of increased lambing and the good season. They will have all these live sheep, but what will they do with them? What will the people from Kuwait say then? There will be no fantastic prices. When there is a glut on the market we get back to the old philosophy of the people who sit opposite. Their cardinal policy is observance of the law of supply and demand. We will find an oversupply of sheep. They will be given away as they were before.

I can well remember when one could not sell a lamb because there was a glut. It is possible that this will happen in the next 12 to 18 months. Then the farmers who have been advocating the continuation of exporting of live sheep will find, because they will not be able to sell their product and because of the huge financial commitments they will have through the increased interest rates on everything that they want to purchase, that they are in financial trouble. They will come to the Government to ask for financial assistance. When they ask the Government for financial assistance they are asking the average taxpayer to help subsidise them. Of course, again that is the policy of the National Country Party. It makes no secret of that. It says that profits should be capitalised and losses should be socialised. That is very good when one can get away with it. I can assure the people who sit opposite that the day of that policy is fast coming to an end. I know Senator Button and probably Senator Teague are waiting to speak and time is getting on. I hope that the Government will take notice of my complaint about the bookings on the Indian Pacific line and that it will see that something is done. I hope also it will have another good look at whether the huge amount of $409,000 spent to drop the word 'Railways' from the title 'Australian National Railways' was warranted. I will be pursuing that matter when it comes before the Estimates committees. I will want some answers because I can find no explanation for that expenditure in the Explanatory Notes that honourable senators have been provided with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal first of all with the item relating to Telecom Australia, largely because the matter was raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I shall make only a few points. Firstly, the Government has announced an inquiry into Telecom. We still do not know the terms of reference of that inquiry or who will conduct it. Senator Bjelke-Petersen had a lot of traditional complaints about the provision of telephone services in rural areas. In some respects they are perfectly valid complaints. We, as a political party, are concerned to see that government services are delivered equally to people whether they live in the country or in the city. There are some very real difficulties in the delivery of telephone services to remote areas of this vast continent. If my recollection is correct, last year Telecom installed some 10 or 11 telephone services at Birdsville at a cost of some $36,000 a service. That was done because Telecom was able to finance that sort of operation out of its profits, particularly out of those it makes from the profitable trunk routes around the eastern seaboard of Australia. I hope that Senator Bjelke-Petersen realises that last year Telecom devoted some $220m of its profits to substituting the country or rural network which provides telephone services. I think it is very important that members of the Government parties, like Senator Bjelke-Petersen, determine what their attitudes are to this question of so-called cross subsidisation of country telephone services by appropriation from the profitable area of Telecom's operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year McKinsey and Co. Inc. was requested to investigate Telecom's capital requirements. It is now nearly 12 months-I hope I am not wrong-since the report of the McKinsey inquiry into Telecom was requested. In spite of questions asked by me, which have never been answered, as to when it will be released, it has not been released to us. It has not been released because it is said to recommend greater capitalisation for Telecom and that Telecom should have access to greater loan funds in order that it might increase its capitalisation. The report made the point that there was a need for increased capital to be made available to Telecom for the sorts of reasons I have suggested. It is absurd that an instrumentality such as Telecom, which has a public investment of some $10 billion and which employs some 80,000 people-I think that figure is correct-an organisation like that which is a matter of great public concern, should have a report about its financing commissioned and made available to the Government but not made available to this Parliament for consideration. I think it is outrageous for any government which introduces so-called freedom of information legislation yet does not allow the Parliament to consider the question of the capital needs, based on expert information, of an enormous organisation like Telecom.

I again call on Senators Carrick and Durack to use their influence as Ministers in the Government to see that the McKinsey report on Telecom is made available to this Parliament. Telecom is a big public instrumentality and a report on its capital requirements, which have been the subject of an expert report available to the Australian Financial Review is not available to this Parliament. We need to know more about Telecom's requirements because we want to know how it will relate also to the satellite authority. We are appalled, in a sense, that Telecom lacks both a chairman and a managing director. It has lacked a chairman for some 12 months, I think, since the forced retirement of Mr Bob Somervaille and it now lacks a managing director since the forced retirement of Mr Jack Curtis, who retired a month or so ago at the time of the Telecom industrial dispute. So this vast organisation has been left leaderless and the Parliament cannot debate in an informed way its capital requirements because of the unavailability of this report.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen complains about the slow delivery of telephone services by Telecom and so on. All these issues of cross-subsidisation, of the importance of the profitability of the profitable section of Telecom, of Telecom's capital requirements and of the management of Telecom by the chairman and the general manager, have to be considered as fundamental issues for this Parliament in that sort of debate. Until Senator Bjelke-Petersen is prepared to consider those issues, it is not much good coming here and making complaints about what may, in a sense, be described as relatively minor problems.

I want to say something about the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) report. This report takes us up to 31 March 1980, so it is very seriously out of date. Since then we have had the related issues of the OTC, which I shall briefly enumerate. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission is now the designated interim operating authority for the proposed domestic satellite. We would like to know what has happened to the proposal for a company to operate the satellite. From rumours and from Press reports we know that an interdepartmental committee has been looking at the question of the structure of the company to operate the satellite. We know that various consortia, such as BTS, have been pressing for equity in the satellite. We know that potential small users of the satellite have expressed dissatisfaction with the arrangements that have been made. We know that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) is said to be proposing a listed company under stock exchange procedures but we do not know who will control that company and what limitations will be imposed on shareholdings. The private sector wants to have a hand in assessing tenders for the satellite. We have had no definite statement from the Minister on any of these matters. We still do not know what services will be available for outback users from the proposed satellite. This was one of the prinicipal justifications for going ahead with a satellite when the proposal was announced.

Serious questions are raised here. For instance, if private companies are to be both part owners of the satellite and buyers of space on it, or users of it, how will we, this Parliament and the Government, ensure that there is no conflict of interests in matters such as pricing policy? How is the satellite to be managed, both technically and financially, in relation to the terrestrial system of Telecom, to which I referred a minute or two ago? How is the satellite to be related to the profitable areas of Telecom's work as well as to the eastern seaboard trunk routes which are profitable for Telecom by terrestrial means? It is important that these questions should be answered if an intelligent debate is to take place on these issues?

Another point I make is that persistent rumours are being spread around the television industry that there is to be a second HACBSS satellite-Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite System. This would be commercial and therefore of considerable interest to those already broadcasting, namely, regional television operators. No statement has been put forward relating to the possibility of a second HACBSS satellite. All these issues remain in doubt while the Government apparently carries on some desultory negotiations behind closed doors about these matters of vital importance to the future of telecommunications in this country and of vital importance to thousands upon thousands of users, and particularly to the four million users who live outside the big metropolitan cities of Australia on whose behalf Senator Bjelke-Petersen was presumably purporting to speak. Those are a few of the questions which arise from the report of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, out of date as it is, and from the report relating to Telecom.

I wish to make one or two observations about the report of the Special Broadcasting Service. The report does not justify the existence of that organisation, concerning which there is a lot of discontent. What are some of the reasons? One goes back to the basic philosophical assumptions underlying its creation. The real question is as to the social philosophy which activates its underlying policy, how it is to be implemented, what is to be its structure and who is to control it. In regard to the underlying social philosophy I would argue that we should avoid paternalism concerning the functions of a body such as the Special Broadcasting Service. We should accept that ethnic communities have a right to control their own affairs. The Fraser Government does not accept that fact. The present arrangements represent basically an attempt to make it look as if a liberal approach to ethnic and multicultural broadcasting is being adopted but that at the same time, the service is being kept under tight control.

Secondly, the recognition of ethnic communities is important in relation to acknowledging that we are a multicultural community. Therefore multicultural values should pervade all broadcasting and not be compartmentalised into 'ethnic broadcasting' as a separate and distinct aspect of it. The recent report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in a sense made this point in drawing attention to the defects of the Commission. One of the major points made was that the ABC did not really cater for regional communities as it ought to, that it had a British cultural look and that it ignored the fact that the composition of Australian society was multicultural. That is a very real and valid criticism of the Commission. I would argue that in philosophical terms the notion of multiculturalism should pervade all broadcasting in Australia and not be just slotted aside into a separate section called ethnic broadcasting, as seems to have happened to date.

The policy of the Opposition on these matters flows from those philosophical assumptions. In 1979 the Labor Party adopted as its policy that it would abolish the Special Broadcasting Service and develop ethnic broadcasting as a facility controlled by the ethnic communities themselves, with government funding arrangements which would be administered by existing organs of government. This is still essentially our policy. The abolition of the SBS would not mean the cessation of government funding for ethnic broadcasting programs. There are many other ways in which it could be provided. The SBS is an unnecessary bureaucratic creation. There may have been some justification for it when it was set up, but there is none now. It arose after ethnic radio had been hawked about during the 1976-78 period. It is now incumbent upon the Government to tell the Parliament its intentions regarding the future of ethnic radio and how ethnic communities are to be given greater control of their own affairs; also the future of Channel 0-28. Clearly there is room for some sort of rationalisation in using that channel for multicultural or public television purposes, or perhaps for other news services-those of the ABC, for example. For too long now the Government has turned a blind eye, in a sense, and put complete faith in the Petro Georgiou-Galbally line in relation to ethnic broadcasting-even to the extent now of giving the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs almost half a million dollars, amongst other things, to report on itself. While these sorts of things happen there is I believe considerable rank and file dissatisfaction in ethnic communities about the state of ethnic media in Australia and ethnic broadcasting in particular. I have referred to the report of the Special Broadcasting Service to show that we must be very cautious about the social assumptions which underly the work of that body and about exercising paternalism in the matter. We should be careful to try to ensure that the notion of multicultural broadcasting is diffused throughout the Australian broadcasting system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would not 'multilingual' be a better description than 'multicultural'?

—It could be but I would regard the expression 'multicultural' as much broader for purposes of broadcasting. However, I take the honourable senator's point. The use of the term 'multilingual' has much to be said for it in the context of the diffusion of ethnic broadcasting availability throughout Australia. Unhappily, we have an unbalanced division of the whole broadcasting system as between commercial broadcasting and the public sector, one which makes it very difficult to develop the notion of diffusion throughout the commercial sector. That section is not particularly interested in it. Anyone who has spoken to the proprietors of commercial television stations on the issue will understand what I mean. As they would put it, it does not rate very highly with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish now to make one or two observations about the report of the Dix committee inquiry which was welcomed by the Opposition as opening an important window of light, as it were, on the problems of the national broadcasting service of this country. What is important is that for a long time the ABC has clearly been in difficulties. There have been dire threats of further cuts in funds. The first indication of that recently was the threat of a cut of 10 per cent in real terms in this financial year. That was followed by a considerable outcry and the Government had to back down on the issue, but in many respects the ABC is still in a parlous state. Many things prevent the ABC from carrying out its charter effectively. I do not propose to go into all of them. I simply say that since this Government came to power the allocation of funds for the Commission has fallen by 22 per cent.

I recall what was said by the first Chairman of the ABC who was appointed by the Fraser Government, Sir Henry Bland, in 1976. Sadly, Sir Henry got himself into a lot of controversy over the film Alvin Purple, or some such matter which, in retrospect, seems to have been a silly thing to go out on in a blaze of glory. In the wisdom of hindsight, and looking back at his career through the mist of retrospectivity, it is very sad that he did not remain Chairman of the Commission. Although he was a volatile personality, he was a very capable and distinguished public servant. In the middle of 1976 he said that the funding of the Commission had been cut to the bone; that there was no room to manoeuvre financially. Since those words were uttered by Sir Henry Bland, the funding allocation for the Commission made by this Government has decreased by 22 per cent.

The staff of the Australian Broadcasting Commission has been reduced by 1,400 people. Twenty per cent of its staff has disappeared in five years. The ABC has been forced to carry over millions of dollars in debts each year and this year the figure was about $7m. That is a disgrace for a national broadcasting service and it is a disgrace for a government which has responsibility for the national broadcasting service. Uncertainty now remains about whether the Australian Broadcasting Commission will be forced to reduce its staff by a further 2 per cent this year. That is one of the proposals of the now increasingly ludicrous razor gang. If those cuts are insisted on it is said it will mean the end of the Four Corners program, a reduction in the news services, especially to regional areas, a reduction in the number of overseas correspondents and the closure of television operations in major regional centres. These cuts, it seems, will become inevitable. So the final staff ceiling of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is a crucial question. When is the Government going to make clear to the staff of the ABC what is the true position?

While this tragic situation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission exists, the Government continues to ponder the report by the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission-the Dix Committee. There, of course, has been no response to it as yet and I do not criticise the Government for that. It is unfortunate in a sense that this matter has come on for debate today because I am not making a response in what I am saying now to everything the Dix Committee says. It would be impossible to do so. There is no time for a point by point examination of the Dix Committee's proposals. However, one or two things can be said at this stage. The Dix Committee inquiry was pretty exhaustive. It embraced careful studies of the ABC's audience, its administrative structure, technical services and even its method of accounting. The latter may be a particularly welcome examination. The Dix Committee said that the central problem of the ABC was the state of its management. Dix and his colleagues clearly saw some shortcomings in this area.

The dilemma which the Dix Committee faced was how to overcome these shortcomings in an organisation such as the ABC which appeared to be suffering from certain hardening of the arteries, if I can use that expression. The solution adopted by the Dix committee was to opt for a new group to be known as the national broadcasting organisation which would give policy decision making to a new group of five to seven people who would be responsible for the more detailed and expert management of the national broadcasting service. I think the proposals about restructuring the administration and management of the ABC have much to commend them. I am not entirely convinced that all of the consultative committees and so on which the Dix Committee recommended would not perhaps be a little cumbersome. But that is a matter about which I am open to persuasion.

I have some worries about the Dix report and I think I should identify them pretty early on. The first of those is the proposal for corporate underwriting or sponsorship of programs. What the Dix Committee in essence said about this was that there will be an increasing demand for resources for broadcasting everywhere, that the ABC has to look to that question and one of the ways of the ABC earning for itself additional resources would be corporate underwriting or sponsorship of programs. What I find defective in the Dix Committee's report about that is this: The Dix Committee estimated that if the ABC did go in for corporate sponsorship it would bring in some $5m. That is not a very big sum in terms of the ABC's overall budget. It seems to me that adopting that proposal would be placing at stake a fair degree of principle about the integrity of the national broadcasting service in exchange for $5m, if that is a correct estimate of revenue that would be gleaned.

Secondly, of course, there is no guarantee in the Dix Committee proposal that if the ABC were successful in financial terms with corporate sponsorship and gained an additional $5m, the Government of the day-I am not making any party criticism about this-would not say: 'Well were going to give the ABC $170m, but it has $5m from corporate sponsorship so we will give it $165m'. That, from the point of view of the ABC, is not necessarily a satisfactory arrangement. Perhaps I can just illustrate the point. I have a document which I am not able to brandish about. However, the Sun-Herald of 9 August 1981 contains an advertisement which shows Pablo Picasso in a hat-a boater I think one would call it-which presumably he wore on the French Riviera. The advertisement says:
IBM is proud to be associated with-
Picasso-A Painter's Diary.
Sunday Spectrum
ABC Television.
It goes on to say that Picasso was a famous artist and that the life and works of Picasso make exciting television. It concludes by stating:
We hope you will be able to join us.
IBM

I do not want to single out IBM for particular attention, but I argue that the ABC has to be like Caesar's wife, if I can put it that way-above suspicion in the integrity of its programming. I am not suggesting for one moment that IBM by sponsoring a film about Picasso is going to influence necessarily the overall policies of the ABC. But I am suggesting that in one way or another, at some time or another, if Australian Broadcasting Commission journalists in their news or current affairs department unearth some scandalous conduct by IBM, it would be natural and understandable for the management of the Australian Broadcasting Commission to say: 'Well, look, you had better be very careful how you handle it because last year we got $3m from IBM'. I make it quite clear that in using this example I am not singling out IBM. What I am simply saying is that that principle concerning the integrity of the news service of a national broadcasting body such as the ABC should be preserved at all cost. The ABC should not only be seen to be independent in its operations and its news gathering and dissemination function but also it should not be open to any suspicion or to the allegation by any person of fair mind or unfair mind that the ABC was in some way negligent in its duties about reporting matters or biased in some way as a result of the fact that it receives money from corporate enterprises. So I think there should be very serious concern about that suggestion.

Of course, one of the great sales pitches of the ABC and of any national broadcasting service such as the British Broadcasting Commission is that many people watch their programs because there is no advertising or no reference to advertising at all. Some people like that and those people in society should be catered for. The other thing I would say about corporate sponsorship is that, as Dix says in his report, it only formalises what happens already. The IBM advertisement concerning Picasso is an indication of that. It is true that because of this Government's financial stringency ABC producers have been forced to seek help from outside. But that does not mean that we of a society or a parliament should condone such a practice. A typical example is the sponsorship of bowls by Mazda. Mazda advertising is used heavily in the backdrop. Mazda has produced promotional material boasting of its use of the ABC as an advertising medium. The only danger is that sponsorship could be abused in one way or another.

Another aspect of corporate underwriting or corporate sponsorship of programs on the ABC is that again an inequality is being introduced in a sense into the community because no individual or community organisation, pensioner organisation or organisation of environmentalists or consumers would be able to afford sponsorship of programs in the way that corporate capital can. I think it is desirable that that element of unfairness be avoided and that those groups, such as environmentalists or consumers, do not begin to see the ABC in some way as the creature of corporate capital.

I mentioned that I had qualifications about some aspects of the Dix report. I will mention one or two more of them. The Dix report effectively recommended the merger of news and current affairs programs, which would be effected by the appointment of one person to head both departments. The separation of the news and current affairs departments superficially might seem to be duplication. In my view it is not. The Australian Broadcasting Commission news has a deserved reputation for being comprehensive, serious and, if I might say so, dull. That is probably not a bad thing for a service which seeks to give its news objectivity.

Current affairs is different from news. It is more about analysis and criticism, not about breaking the news. It is about analysing and criticising the news and events and asking critical questions. If the current affairs department of the ABC were to be subsumed into the news department there would be a very real danger in my view that the bland news department approach might subsume, as it were, or stifle, the critical and analysing current affairs approach necessary in any good broadcasting service. It is better to have the service asking the hard questions without its role being confused with the day to day needs of telling the news.

Another aspects of the Dix report which I have qualifications about is the suggestion that Australian Associated Press be used as the news gathering service for the ABC. In my view this would be entirely retrograde. There are few enough sources of news in Australia now and the AAP is increasingly the basic source of news for newspapers, commercial radio and television. The ABC remains the only independent source of news. I think the ABC should remain in that situation.

There are other matters in the Dix report about which one would have qualifications. I do not want to deal with those today because we will have other opportunities. Honourable senators should seriously and lengthily weigh the implications of the Dix report. It is a report whose influence could affect not only the future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission but could also have a profound influence on the whole of the media industry in this country. I think it is absolutely essential that we consider carefully policies related to the Special Broadcasting Service, the Dix committee of inquiry and broadcasting generally and the development of the broadcasting system in the context of the Dix report. It is said that we now live in a society where information is perhaps the most valuable commodity. It is in that context that we ought continually and seriously to discuss issues relating to communication policy and the reports tabled today in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity in the 20 minutes that remain before dinner to talk on the same two areas to which Senator Button has just referred. They are the annual report of the Special Broadcasting Service and, more importantly, the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It was in the second to last day of the last session that the Government tabled volume 2 the Dix report, a very large, comprehensive and nevertheless very readable document. The remarks that Senator Button has just made in continuation of the speech he gave on the tabling of the report are part of the first discussion that the Dix report has had in this new session of Parliament. It is my first opportunity to add some initial comments on my own reflections on the Dix committee findings.

SPEECH.PARA: Volume 2 is a massive report but very happily the committee of review has now published volume 1, which is a very thin and readable 34-page document. It sets out the recommendations of the Committee in summary form. More importantly it poses a very readable set of questions that it believes the Australian public is asking about the ABC. This series of about 20 questions is very frankly and carefully answered in a very helpful way. In referring to volumes 1 and 2 of the report, first I congratulate the Committee for its excellent review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its many activities.

I note in passing that Professor Alex Castles- a very eminent South Australian professor of law at the University of Adelaide-was one of the members of the Committee of Review. I know he heartily took up his own involvement in the review. I think he has contributed very well to its result. By way of introduction I will refer to Senator Button's reservation, as he put it, about some of the matters discussed in the report. He referred to corporate underwriting or sponsorship of programs broadcast by the ABC, the possible amalgamation of news and current affairs services and to a dependence upon Australian Associated Press for international news gathering. I share those reservations. I have not given them the most careful consideration. It is another pointer to the fact that these matters have not been debated in the Senate and have not been sufficiently discussed. Perhaps the most appropriate time will be when the Government responds, setting out a line of action in response to the findings of the Committee. At that time such sensitive issues as these ought to be taken up.

However, having considered the possible commercial underwriting of some aspects of the multicultural television service I have not got a cast iron abhorrence to there being any such intrusion into the ABC. Where I have got a cast iron mind is that there should not be such involvement of commercial interests that would in any way at all jeopardise the objectivity of national broadcasting through the ABC. The three or four matters I particularly want to refer to concern a question raised in volume 1 of the report; that is whether the ABC is used by only a minority of Australians. The very happy finding of the surveys conducted by the Committee of Review is that only about 7 per cent of Australians do not at some time in any given week listen to ABC radio or watch ABC television.

Therefore, 93 per cent of listeners in Australia gain something from ABC broadcasts. Indeed, three-quarters of the population watch ABC television at least once or twice a week. It is a small group of only one in three persons who listen most days of every week to ABC radio. Whilst it has often been surmised in public discussion that the Australian Broadcasting Commission is an elite organisation or that it is the preserve of the more educated, more leisurely members of the community, the facts put a lie to that myth. The ABC is appreciated by just about everybody in Australia. I believe a very careful interest is taken by every section of the community in the kinds of reforms that the Dix Committee of Review put forward.

However, there are deficiencies in the ABC as to the groups in the community that are not sufficiently catered for by present broadcasts. These are set out as being those people who live in country, outback and remote areas and who do not have the same access to the programs that are available in metropolitan areas. There is an urging in this report, with which I wish to associate myself, to bring the second radio service to every area of Australia progressively but in a short interval. Another area where there has been insufficient attention has been in meeting the broadcasting needs of Aboriginal communities and non-British Australians-persons whose native or family language is other than English. With respect to the Aboriginal and ethnic communities of Australia, there is a call by the Dix Committee of Review for more direct programming to meet their needs.

Another bias that is mentioned in the report is a cultural one. An over-emphasis is placed upon some overseas programs, particularly British, and these programs are being broadcast, mainly on television, at the expense of Australian produced programs. The amendments that were passed to the Broadcasting and Television Act last session require the commercial and national broadcasting systems to give greater attention to Australian produced material. In all of these respects, I urge the Government to respond to the findings of this Committee and to respond in such a way that the new ABC will cater for country and outback people, Aboriginal and ethnic people, and will do so without bias in relation to overseas programs.

Some of the deficiencies that have been seen to exist in the Australian Broadcasting Commission have arisen because of a pattern of industrial disputes in the past within the Commission, some fall-off in staff morale and other reasons. One of the reasons that the Committee directly inquired about related to whether the performance of the Commission had declined because of a lack of resources. The Committee of Review found that, generally speaking, whilst there have not been the resources available to the ABC that some may have wished, this has been the case for many organisations in the public and private sectors in Australia. The Committee of Review concluded in a very telling way that it has not been primarily because of a lack of resources that the ABC has not lived up to all of these important initiatives.

Indeed, the Committee concluded that financial restrictions and staff ceilings have provided a convenient excuse for a whole range of shortcomings in the ABC. I find this conclusion immediately plausible. I believe it ties in very well with the debate which took place in the second to last week of the last session of Parliament. On 5 June the Opposition brought forward a matter of public importance. This was only a few days before the end of the last sittings of the Parliament. It was raised at a time leading up to the preparation of the Budget and the bringing down of the Budget this week. It was at that point that rather expediently and mischievously the Opposition brought forward the charge that the Government was about to cut the resources of the ABC by 10 per cent in real terms. As a matter of alleged public importance the Opposition started to debate in this chamber. I remember participating in that debate and trying to rebut the Opposition's allegation by saying that the appropriate time to see the outcome of these matters was when the Budget was announced. I refer to that at this time because there has not been a 10 per cent cut in expenditure for the ABC. There has not been a cut at all. The mischievous allegations, which we said at the time were baseless, have no truth in them at all. A smoke screen was brought into this place quite unnecessarily by the Opposition.

On Tuesday night the Budget Speech noted that $234m would be made available this financial year to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. This amount compares with a pattern of commitment in recent years. In the last financial year the Commission was allocated $215.6m. In 1979-80, the previous year, the figure was $187.8m. Progressively smaller amounts in money terms were allocated in the years before. The Budget decision of this year is in line with the pattern of the Government's commitment to ensure sufficient resources for the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its many services. It may well be argued in the light of the findings of the Dix Committee of Review that for certain purposes the Government will need to consider granting additional resources. One of the areas that has been highlighted by the Committee of Review is the need for quite large amounts of increased capital provision. This is detailed in the report. I am sure that all honourable senators will come to consider these matters carefully when the Government has made its response and when it can responsibly see what amount can be set aside over a pattern of years to meet the sound recommendations that can be proved to be in the best interests of the new ABC.

One of the major findings of the Committee of Review was that there should be a quite different commission-a quite different managing body for the ABC. A discussion was held as to what is termed the National Broadcasting Organisation, the NBO. I have read with great interest the way this has been outlined. I am not at all estranged from the substance of the findings that are detailed in the report about the NBO, but for the life of me I cannot see why we should change the name of the peak management body in the ABC to anything other than the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Why cannot this new NBO be called simply the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the five to seven members of it be called commissioners? I strongly urge such a course upon the Government. Not only will the Australian public not be confused about a new body called the National Broadcasting Organisation but also it will see a steady transition from the old ABC of almost the past 50 years to the newly rearranged ABC still being called the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

I now talk about the arrangements for music to which the Dix Committee, the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, has given careful consideration. Amongst other things, the Dix Committee recommended that the two departments within the ABC which superintend music and concert arrangements be amalgamated into a new unit which will become largely independent within the ABC organisation as a whole. I concur entirely with that change. I believe that the overlapping and even competitive and duplicated functions of the existing concert department and music department can be overcome satisfactorily in the way that has been suggested, namely, that of forming the unit called 'Music Australia'. It is proposed that there be a managing director of Music Australia who will be responsible directly to the board of directors, that is, the Commission.

I urge not only that there be this reorganisation of structure and the injection of a new name but also that very careful consideration be given to appointing new personnel to management positions within Music Australia. It is unfortunate that amongst the general findings of the Dix Committee a criticism has been made that inertia has overcome many areas of the ABC and that a bureaucratic status quo way of thinking has eclipsed some parts of the organisation. It is my view that this situation exists in the concert department and the music department of the ABC. I hope that the new arrangements will allow the appointment of new managers, with a new style of approach, to ensure that Music Australia does not repeat the errors of the existing departments within the ABC.
One of the general findings of the Committee was that the ABC's record had faltered. Referring to the ABC, the Committee stated in volume 1 of its report:

It has not only slipped from the forefront of change but threatens to be eclipsed by it. The ABC has become slow moving, overgrown, complacent, and uncertain of the direction in which it is heading despite the efforts of many talented and dedicated people who work for it.
I hope this will not be a description of the management of Music Australia, even in the first years of rearrangement that will precede the independent body envisaged in the Committee's report.

The final matters in the Dix report to which I refer are the repercussions or implications of the Committee's findings as they relate to the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which inquired into multicultural television services. In the findings of the Standing Committee a recommendation was made to the Senate that a decision on the best way to provide multicultural television in Australia be reconsidered once the findings of the Dix Committee were available. This subject will need considerable discussion now that both the reports are available to us.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Education and the Workforce

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 June on motion by Senator Davidson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of us tonight want to take up the debate that we began, but only in a brief way, on 2 June, when the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was tabled. Senator Davidson, the Chairman, was able to outline in summary fashion the findings of the Committee. I was able to speak for only a few minutes about what I regard as an excellent report, a report which can be regarded not only in the education area but also in other areas, as a very fine example of the kind of fruit that comes from the public of Australia responding to an advertisement of terms of reference for a national inquiry being undertaken by parliamentarians. Six senators from the Opposition and the Government conducted this inquiry for almost two years. We were interrupted by a couple of other references-children and television, and multicultural television-and over those two years we considered the hundreds of submissions that came in. We met in all capitals of Australia and proceeded to this report. Although it is brief, it is brief in order to be succinct and to the point and in order not to repeat the many inquiries that have proliferated over the last 10 years in the education area.

SPEECH.PARA: For me in many ways the point of departure for this inquiry was the widespread interest by the public in the question: 'Are our secondary school sons and daughters gaining sufficient mastery of basic skills that they are in a fit position to go on and find employment? Have they got the essential skills from their education that will enable them to gain jobs satisfactorily?' The parents of many children and certainly very many employers have been very critical of the apparent standards of achievement of school leavers. Some of those criticisms are confused and misplaced; some of them arise from misunderstandings of the school system. Nevertheless it is certain that over the years there has been widespread discussion about 'back to the basics', about the three Rs, about whether or not there is a satisfactory interface between the years 10, 11 and 12 of school and first years of employment, about the whole question of youth unemployment and how we can gain increased skills for those unemployed school leavers that will suit them to go on and find jobs. In that context, one of the statements that was before the Committee was that of Professor Peter Karmel, Chairman of the Tertiary Education Commission, who in his Radford Memorial Lecture in 1979 said:

It is now well recognised that a proportion of young people, perhaps up to one-quarter, are ill-served by the operation of our school system in the present social context. Children who emerge from primary school without a capacity to read, number, and communicate, are so seriously handicapped in their subsequent secondary schooling that they are unlikely to be anything other than low achievers. Similarly those who leave school with poor cognitive skills and without a capacity to work with others will not compete on an equal basis in a limited job market.

The Chairman of the Tertiary Education Commission claimed two years ago that a quarter of the children in Australian schools are ill-served, badly served, by the schooling system. The conclusion of this report, after many submissions and examinations in all States, is that that summary is very close to the mark. Accordingly we have addressed ourselves first of all to trying to express a way of meeting the misunderstandings to which I referred earlier so that we can clear away the red herrings in public perceptions about this problem, and then to go on, if we can, to define the kinds of remedies that all together would lead to overcoming this situation.

It is not good enough, if this claim by Professor Karmel is true. Why should it be that a quarter of our children are badly served in our schools? Surely if we are rational and careful in our educational decisions as a nation, whether in the Commonwealth or the States or in individual schools, we ought to be able to meet that problem and make sure that there is equal opportunity for all levels of achievers so that they may go on to have mastery of basic skills and a fair chance of employment.

Among the misunderstandings that have been discussed very widely in the public is the notion that somehow or other the education system is responsible for unemployment in the community. The Committee found, from many of the submissions made to it, that that is not true, that it is a myth. Unemployment arises in Australia currently because of economic conditions, because although there has been a massive growth in jobs, there has been an even greater growth in those who are seeking jobs. We do not have any simplistic answer to youth unemployment along the lines that in the last decade the schools have slipped in their standards and the graduates of the schools no longer have the kinds of skills they had 10 years ago that led to so many school leavers going on to employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has there not been a scornful attitude to manual skills in some quarters of the education firmament?

—That is getting much closer to the mark, and I will refer to that later. Up to the middle part of this century there were very many unskilled jobs in the community. Those unskilled jobs were often filled by school leavers, in the first instance, who did not have particularly high achievements in their school records but who were able to go on to unskilled, largely manual jobs with relative ease, to learn on the job and to pick up some of the things they may have missed at school. There was a great capacity for unskilled jobs in the community. But in the last decade that sector in the work force has diminished very much. There just are not as many unskilled jobs as there were in the past. It has been the contention of educationists and others who made submissions to the Committee that the school system has always produced low achievers, but whereas in the past those low achievers-perhaps even 25 per cent-were able to find some unskilled job, that area is now so squeezed that the same 25 per cent of underachievers are unable to find employment with which they can cope.

SPEECH.PARA: This is linked with the myth that is still widely discussed in Australia that in the past there was a golden age when everyone went to school, learnt the three Rs, received a basic education, became competent in that basic education and left school disciplined, good at writing, good at numbering and good at all the necessary skills for employment. However, the claim is that because of modern education techniques the golden age has ceased and we now have disaster in the schools. There just is not any evidence to support such a claim; it is a misconception. Because the underachiever is now more prevalent by being exposed as being unemployed it appears that there was a golden age in the past when all of these persons were catered for whereas now it appears that they are not. That is a myth. There was not a golden age.

If comparisons can be made in history it would be found that the earlier systems of education, whilst being very good for some people, left many children without basic skills and, moreover, children learnt by such a method that they were dependent upon an over-authoritarian teacher and they adopted learning by rote, knowledge and narrative rather than by creative thinking or by gaining concepts by the notion of understanding.

The findings of the Committee do not in any way reinforce this myth of a golden age. Neither do we talk constructively in the report about the three Rs or say that we should return to the three Rs. Some newspaper articles have used this caption in their greeting of this report. I believe in doing so there is a danger of oversimplifying the deeper statement we are trying to make. We are not wishing upon Australian schools a return to the three Rs. We do not want to go back to rote learning. We do not want to go back to a narrowly-based education program.

Rather-I think we do this more profoundly, in this report-we are calling for a broad-based education system appropriate to our decade. Within that broad-based system let us ensure that teachers have the techniques and that school curricula are so determined that all children have the chance for mastery of basic skills. As one senator on the Committee I am very happy to wear the phrase 'mastery of basic skills' but I am very reluctant to wear the phrase 'returning to the three Rs'. Therefore, we are not putting in jeopardy what enlightened educationists around Australia are saying ought to be a broadly based education program.

It is true that these days schools are being called upon to give every kind of instruction. To some extent what was in the past taught by families and passed on by those living in the family such as questions about career guidance in many ways atrophied to a father perhaps saying to a son: 'You will be doing what I am doing'. A daughter could be told that because her aunt next door or the neighbour across the road knows about hairdressing she could be a hairdresser. In the past there has been much of that locked-in repetition in the career advice given to children by an earlier generation. Nevertheless, there was some pattern of encouragement that we might have called career advice. At the moment so many young people do not get any career advice at all. Similarly with regard to sex education, many of the Victorians were proud of the fact that sex education did not exist in any area, that it was learnt by personal experience. Not only the women's movement but also so many educationists-

TALK.START.PARA: —Think of the fun you had learning.

—I suppose so. So many educationists in family planning movements and in notions about responsible sex education among teenagers in schools very rightly have made some redress of this. We now require secondary schools to include in the curriculm proper sex education, information on interpersonal relationships, notions about self-awareness, personal development, orientation to the work force, which I noted before, and so on. Along with that we are wanting the children in schools to have some awareness of the community in which they live-the notion of local government, State government, even Commonwealth government, debating, presenting a speech and all the communications skills that were not taught in any way, except to very few, as little as 20 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: So the demands in these marginal or personal areas are heaped on top of all the new areas of knowledge. There is more and more physics, chemistry and mathematics to learn. So the demands upon the primary and secondary school systems in recent years indicate a much vaster series of topics and subjects for children to study and require a broadly based curriculum. We do not want to put that in jeopardy. What seems to have been lost in the last 15 years-in the next 10 minutes I will go on to talk about the reasons for this development in the last 15 years-is that whilst children in Australian schools have become increasingly involved in this broader curriculum, this good curriculum, for the most part they have suffered in terms of mastery of basic skills.

In the first chapter of the report we have set out these areas of disagreement and misunderstanding in the community. We have commended the six or seven pages of that first chapter for wide dissemination in the community. The material could be easily photocopied and distributed amongst a parents' group associated with a school, put in the staff room of a school or given to an industry group in order that these kinds of misunderstandings could be discussed by a small group and so, we hope, be overcome. The Committee discussed whether some kind of national conference could be called between parents, industrialists, educationists and school children but we rejected any such grandiose approach to the problem.
