Rather, by small groups in localised regions discussing these areas of misunderstanding, we six senators are confident that the summary we have given and the kinds of conclusions we have reached will dispel some of these misunderstandings.

I will be much briefer in regard to the other three chapters of the report. They define the kinds of solutions that the Committee put forward to overcome the problem. I return to the problem, that 25 per cent of Australia's school children have insufficient opportunity to gain mastery of basic skills. Perhaps they have suffered that loss in primary school and therefore have had a confused secondary schooling where they have lost self-confidence, motivation and a sense of relevance in what they are doing, and so have become all the more unable to rise to the opportunities of employment, even though now those opportunities are restricted in Australia.

Before I go on to discuss how we can help overcome this problem for this 25 per cent. I note that the problem extends beyond that group of people. There are lower achievements amongst school children not only in the bottom quartile of achievers in schools, by any measure; they extend almost into the middle two quartiles as well. Perhaps about three quarters of Australian school children are not able to say when they leave school that they have mastered numeracy and literacy, that they have mastered the ability to handle basic arrangements of numbers and the basic skills of communication. This is particularly evident in entrants to colleges of advanced education, and not least for teacher education and training. When entrants to some CAEs have been tested for their ability in mathematics and basic English expression or communication skills, it has been found by many colleges in recent tests that the matriculated or highest achiever students coming to them have woeful scores in these basic skills.

One of the problems for many colleges, and even for universities, is that in the first year or two of tertiary study tuition has to take account of this and the colleges or universities have to try to help those students to master the basic skills of writing and of handling numbers. This is particularly serious with regard to trainee teachers of mathematics. As all honourable senators know, all primary school teachers are called on to teach child- ren in mathematics, in the basic concepts of numbers and the handling of simple arithmetic-multiplication tables, the notion of groups of numbers and the notion of fractions. Although the remarks I have to make are not sexist because about 80 per cent of primary school teachers are women the remarks are mostly directed at women primary school teachers. I understand from the evidence the Committee received that the remarks could equally be directed at male primary school teachers. The problem is particularly focused on women because in the Australian society women are still discouraged, unfortunately, from continuing with mathematics studies during their secondary schooling. Therefore they are discriminated against for the rest of their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't count.

—Senator Martyr says that they cannot count. To the extent that they cannot count, they then cannot go on to become accountants, engineers or possibly even doctors or dentists or acquire any of the paramedical skills that require careful numeration.
—All doctors need to be able to add up for is to take their money to the bank.

—Whether or not numeration is a skill directly involved in such a profession or is ancillary to it, the discouragement by parents, even by teachers, and certainly by peers, leads to girls in secondary school dropping mathematics studies and not going on to gain mastery of the concepts involved in numeration. Eighty per cent of primary school teachers, being women and having suffered that kind of discrimination and discouragement, have then somehow or other to pick up the threads of learning these basic concepts of mathematics, along with all of the other subjects that are thrust upon them, in their first year of teacher training. Many of them do not quite cope, so stagger through. Some pick up sufficient skill to become quite competent teachers. However, the feedback and the submissions to our Committee were that it is the case now that a large proportion of the graduates of teacher training institutions-particularly primary school teachers-have inadequate understanding of mathematical ideas and of the teaching of arithmetic.
—It is the teachers in the secondary schools who have let them down.

—There is a chicken and egg aspect in that because of this discouragement in secondary schools they go on as teacher trainees who are inadequate. They then do not help sufficiently those who are in primary schools. The primary school students who are not coping with numbers are easily discouraged in secondary school and this vicious circle goes on and on. I believe it is a national scandal. It is not peculiar to Australia but it is a particular problem in this country. There is a problem of similar dimension in the United States of America, I believe it is because of this fundamental discrimination against women, which we must all seek to overcome. This problem about women, in particular primary school teachers, is an illustration of the extension beyond the 25 per cent about whom I am chiefly worried. Other groups of school children suffer this disability of not mastering basic skills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee addressed itself in turn to the training of teachers. It concluded that the training of teachers is inadequate. There is an emphasis upon educating teachers rather than training them. There is an emphasis in our teacher training institutions on making sure the would-be teacher, in the time the colleges have him-for two or three years-becomes well educated, that he has a lot of knowledge about many things and that he is well read; whereas the priority must be that that person, while in the teacher training institution, be trained in the techniques of teaching. There needs to be emphasis upon method rather than substance. I am not arguing that we should teach just method and not substance. I do not want to be misinterpreted in that way, and neither does the Committee. It is vital that teacher training insitutions right across the country return to training in techniques, in methods, rather than trying to ape universities by giving broadly based arts or science courses that will just 'educate' the students enrolled.

Also the Committee regarded teacher selection to be inadequate. In most cases students who entered training courses were those who had gained the highest points score in their basic matriculation or year 12 exam. It is based purely on academic achievement. Insufficient consideration is given to their aptitude to be teachers-whether they are able to relate to people and whether they are good communicators.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the case for doctors, particularly.

—Yes, it applies to doctors. Are they motivated to apply themselves to the profession in which they will spend much of their lives? So, we have called for personal qualities, what we call non-academic qualities, such as responsibility, motivation, resilience and self-discipline.
—Are you talking about Senator Martyr?

—I am talking not only about Senator Martyr, who is behind me, but also Senator Haines, a former teacher, who reminded me that she was of the earlier school of teacher trainees who were selected along these lines. Seriously, these are the sorts of qualities we all recognise in successful teachers. Whenever we go to a classroom and see the nature of the relationship the teacher has to the students, we see that there are aspects of discipline, responsibility and an ability to communicate. There seems to be an effusion of that teacher's motivation and care about the task he has, the profession of which he is a part. We believe that trainee teacher selection should be oriented more along these lines.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference is made in our report to class sizes. We are aware that essentially it is a State matter to determine class sizes in the State school systems. Independent schools make their own determination. The important point we make is that because year 1 and year 2 in primary school are so important in establishing basic concepts in literacy and numeracy, if any classes are to be smaller they should be those in year 1 and year 2 in primary school. We similarly referred to school size and see some merit in schools not exceeding about 600 pupils. But again, that is a matter for decision by State governments. With regard to school design, we are aware that some of the open plan schools are inappropriately used and abused and lead on to some of the problems that we have indentified in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you recommended that the walls go back?

—We have not recommended that the walls go back in all circumstances, but we have recommended that all trainee teachers be trained in the techniques of teaching with walls about them or in more open space situations. My personal preference is for a more traditional classroom setting with the ability to move classes into open space areas from time to time. But we have no clear knowledge that there is included in the curriculum of trainee teachers the kinds of skills appropriate to the two different situations, or even whether they have the knowledge to distinguish between those activities which are best done in one situation or in the other. One of the obvious features of schools of the 1970s is the fact that teacher aids are more abused than used. Often teacher aids are a distraction from effective learning rather than being of some assistance. Television in schools is often used as pure entertainment, as a relief. Placing classes before the television set is an easy option for teachers.
—Just to get through the next 35 minutes.

—Just to get through the next 35 minutes; to keep their attention somehow. If television is to be used effectively in a school, it must be preceded in the classroom by careful orientation to the program with the television set turned off. Afterwards, the program must be followed up by questions and answers, essays or some kind of activity that makes use of the program. Moreover, the program should be selected along criteria that fit the curriculum, not what just happens to be being dished out by the Australian Broadcasting Commission or a video cassette.
—Does the Committee agree with chalk and talk?

—No, we do not agree with chalk and talk and we do not believe in the 3Rs or any of the over-simplifications of the past. Rather, we want to see the mastery of basic skills. There are two areas for specialist teachers that we point to in our report. One is remediation and the other is school counselling. There is insufficient activity in these two areas in our schools. We believe that every school teacher should have some ability to be a remedial teacher. Every teacher must be able to identify the lowest achievers in the class and be able, by remediation, to help that group under his care. However, we also call for an increased number of specialist remedial teachers in Australian schools, at the primary level in particular but also in the secondary area. The problems in the primary area and the secondary area are a little different. In the primary area some children have difficulties in picking up basic concepts. Because they do not get the basic concept in the first couple of years, they can, therefore, lose out forever after. Some children have specific learning disabilities, some are deaf or are sufficiently deaf not to be able to pick up instruction. Some children are absent from school or move about the country to the detriment of their education and they miss out on something that is vital. In cases like those every teacher ought to be able to identify the need for particular remediation and every school must be able to gain the help of a specialist remediation teacher.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been quite frank about school leadership and morale. We have noted that in some schools in Australia the principals of schools and their deputies or senior staff are deficient in carrying out their duties. They are not careful enough to inspire other teachers but rather can be quite counter-productive in their schools. We call for an assessment of such principals and senior staff who are in doubt. If the result of the assessment shows that they are inadequate or not living up to their duties, we call for them to be given every opportunity to do so and, if they do not, to leave the service. We are aware that more than half the Australian school teachers have been teaching for less than five years. Such was the enormous increase in teacher numbers during the 1970s that the median age of school teachers in Australia is about 28 or 29 years. Such was the great increase in the numbers of staff assigned to schools in the 1970s that many of the present body of teachers are young and relatively inexperienced. Many of them also went through their training at a time when the belief was to educate the would-be teacher rather than train the would-be teacher. Some of the worst deficiencies we have sought remedies for in our report are suffered most by the younger and more inexperienced teachers presently in our schools. To overcome that problem it is essential for us to have an adequate in-service training approach. We have called for the allocation of special grants to schools so that each school can establish a client relationship with a teacher training institution. Then the school can determine which teachers are in need of in-service training and what those needs are. The school can then contact a teacher training institution to define the extent of assistance needed and use the funds available to it to pay that teacher training institution for the kinds of courses it would then go on to provide. We go on in our recommendation to outline this notion of in-service training.

We refer as well in some detail to teaching aids, to the notion of a core curriculum such as that of the Curriculum Development Centre for Australian schools, which was published in recent months, and speak of the perennial problem of the home environment. When any educational assessor looks at a developed country-perhaps even an underdeveloped country-to examine whether there is a correlation between the higher achievers in the school system and any particular factor in the characteristics of those students, the one factor that stands out is the home environment. If a student comes from a home in which his parents encourage him in his studies, in which books are much used, in which there is encouragement to make the most of educational opportunities and discussions reinforce what happens at school, that student is most likely to be successful. So we refer, perhaps briefly and inadequately, to this perennial factor which has been found by all such surveys.

I turn to a remedy which we think is essential and deserving of the highest priority, even if these other half dozen areas of remedy are acted upon. We need to restructure the curriculum for many secondary schools in Australia. It is unfortunate that secondary schools should cater almost exclusively for an academic curriculum. These days all children go to comprehensive schools, in which they progress through years 7, 8 and 9. There is very little division from that point on into what once were called technical schools or anything other than a comprehensive approach. Students in years 10, 11 and 12 do take a range of subjects, in quite a variety of combinations-but essentially they still lead to the year 12 examinations, the Higher School Certificate or matriculation. They are essentially geared to testing students who wish to go on to university or other tertiary studies.

Not only are the schools structured according to this academic bias. School teachers encourage children to stay in the race and go on to complete their year 12 examinations. Parents also encourage them, even if it is entirely inappropriate, to stay with a curriculum that is geared to academic achievement.

It is manifest that less than 20 per cent of Australian school leavers ever go on to colleges of advanced education or universities. I would like to think that in the next 20 years very many of them would but I believe that the present percentage who do is about 15 per cent. A further group of about 30 per cent go on to additional education through the technical and further education sections of each of the States. Therefore, less than 50 per cent of school leavers enrol, at any time in their life, in a course of study which we might call post-secondary or tertiary. Thus, it is entirely inappropriate that our comprehensive secondary school curriculum should be geared to an academic outcome for all student enrollees.

We have concluded that there needs to be a restructuring of the secondary school system to allow perhaps up to one-third of all students to study subjects, courses and disciplines that are more appropriate to their life outcomes in terms of employment and of coping with all the other ranges of activity that they may encounter in their lives.

There are some particularly good examples of innovation to this end. I shall refer to one only. I commend to honourable senators a recent development at Port Macquarie in New South Wales. In the last five years the town's population has doubled. Thus, a couple of years ago there was a need for new educational facilities. There was at the time a State primary school, a State secondary school and an independent primary Catholic school. With the increased number of children going to those three schools an expansion in the States schools occurred and the Catholic school decided to build a completely new primary school and to use the old primary school as a vocational college for year 10 and 11 students. It happened to be across the road from the high school and a very innovative curriculum and procedure both in regard to the appointment of teachers and the acquisition of equipment was established. The activities of the school were geared to the kinds of employment opportunities available in the Port Macquarie area. The school took as enrollees students from the lower half of achievers in year 9 in Port Macquarie and surrounding areas. So in years 10 and 11, at this vocational school, the authorities concentrated on those who had very little likelihood of going on to post-secondary academic training.

To visit that school is a very enlightening and wonderful experience in that the students are self-aware, motivated and, to return to my theme, seem to be mastering basic skills. If they had continued in the secondary school across the road they would have been turned off, would have suffered a reduction in self-confidence and would have lacked motivation. Instead, they were involved in activities in which they could develop and reinforce their literacy and numeracy skills. At the end of the first year of operation of the vocational college every one of the graduates went on to obtain employment in the local area. Again, at the end of the second year of operation every graduate obtained employment. It has been such a success that parents in the area now queue up to have their children enrolled for this quite alternative curriculum. That is the kind of opportunity that I believe ought to be available to all children throughout Australia.

I am not exactly calling for a return to the old technical high school, which was an alternative to the high schools of the past. Nor do I want entirely to get away from the notion of a comprehensive approach to secondary education, but I believe that within comprehensive secondary schools there should be a sector that will be somewhat like an improved version of the old technical school, one in which manual and design skills are in the forefront of the curriculum-subjects about which a mastery of basic skills can be built.

Finally, I have been happy to note that the Press, State Ministers in a number of instances, and many teachers, educationists, representatives of industry and parents have shown a great deal of interest in this Senate report. I hope that we will see from that interest the kind of discussion and decision making around Australia which will lead to these remedies being implemented. I believe the Commonwealth Government should take full account of the report, as it has with all such Senate standing committee reports. Through the Australian Education Council it should require a response from State Ministers as to their views and activities that have flowed from the findings of this report. There is no way that we as senators can call to account State Ministers who are responsible to their own State parliaments. But I believe through the Australian Education Council we can look to the Commonwealth Minister for Education to respond to every aspect of this report even though the majority of it will require action by State Ministers and by the principals and staff of independent schools. Therefore, I anticipate that in due course-I hope within six months-we will see a full itemised response to this report on preparation for the work force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too will direct my attention to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on preparation for the work force which has been so comprehensively dealt with by my colleague Senator Teague. When the inquiry was announced the reaction of some people throughout the community was: 'Well, surely not another inquiry in this area'. We have had the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment-the Williams Report-we have had the Karmel investigation and so on. We found that 65 papers and reports have resulted from inquiries conducted into this vital area throughout the last few years. The fact that our inquiry was welcomed by most of the people we spoke to is reinforced by the interest shown in the inquiry, the number of submissions that were put forward and the number of witnesses that came before us. It shows that there still is a good deal of concern within the community about the ability of the schools to prepare students for the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be worth while reading from the introductory remarks to the report by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Gordon Davidson, on why he saw this inquiry as being a little different from all of those that had taken place. I quote from his comments on page 2 of the report. He said:

The purpose of this inquiry has been to examine the effectiveness of Australian schools in preparing young people for the world of work with special attention to what schools are achieving in providing young people with an adequate mastery in the fundamentals of literacy and numeracy. We have, therefore, set ourselves the task of cutting through this thicket of information and focusing attention on what we believe are important issues that have a bearing on these terms of reference. We also intend to identify and comment on the areas of conflict and confusion which we referred to earlier, since it is these areas that tend to cloud the real problems that confront educationalists.

The bipartisan approach which we had to this report encouraged me to have some discussion today with Senator Teague. We decided to break up the discussion on the report into various areas. Senator Teague was to speak to the background of the report, the conduct of the inquiry and the problems faced by that 25 per cent of the community who leave school some way educationally disadvantaged. I say the words 'educationally disadvantaged' slowly because this term appears in the report. Senator Teague, with his usual enthusiasm, has run a little beyond what he was going to talk about. Nevertheless, I found his remarks very comprehensive. He showed that he has a grasp of the subject which was the topic of the report.

I am going to look very briefly-it will be briefly-at some ways in which the schools and the community could assist in this area. I am going to look briefly also at the selection of training and teachers. I am going to look at those two areas because I understand our colleague Senator Haines will also have some comments to make on the subject. Let us look first at some of those things which the school can do in this area of changing the present situation. When I speak of the school I perhaps should say 'system' because the school in some way includes the community in which it is placed. Of course, it reacts to the community as the community reacts to it. I include also in this system the department which serves the school. I do not want to enter into a debate at this stage on whether schools should or should not be autonomous.

I think we accept that traditionally the government-that is the State government-has accepted the responsibility given by the parents, or perhaps one might say taken from the parents. But certainly the parents have accepted that the State government has some responsibilities. I do not think it matters. The comments I want to make in my very brief remarks will apply regardless of whether we talk about the school being autonomous, making its own decisions, reacting to the community, having its counsel and so on or whether we are talking about a school system which is part of the more traditional concept with the Minister being ultimately responsible and exercising his responsibility through the hierarchy of a department. I am going to direct my comments even more narrowly than that.

I shall refer to some of the ways in which secondary schools could assist, because that is the area we looked at very closely. I make these remarks about what schools and communities and some others might do because I have to make the point that I am despairing of the assistance that might come from the Federal Government. We have not had a great deal of reaction to what was a compehensive report. We have not had any indication from the present Government that it is prepared to enter this field and financially or otherwise do the sorts of things that Senator Teague was talking about, namely, taking the initiative or providing financial assistance. I will come back to that point in a moment.

I do not want to define education, but surely it includes a number of areas such as the changing of attitudes and the creation of appropriate learning experience situations. I am not going to lecture on education. Senator Teague has done an admirable job in this respect and my own expertise has been left far behind. But surely schools must firstly ascertain the needs within the community and then devise ways to meet those needs. I do not want to pre-empt any sort of investigation that might be carried out but need, as indicated by Senator Teague, surely does not mean university entrance for 100 per cent of our students. I used to feel that 10 per cent of students went on to university. Senator Teague put the figure a little higher-perhaps 15 per cent or a little more. Nevertheless, the bulk of students who go through secondary schools are not going towards a university education. In many cases they are not going to a college of advanced education either. They are going to some other form of education.

I suppose we have had a sort of traditional academic approach for two reasons. The first is that teachers themselves are academically oriented. They come through the system. Many teachers never leave school. They go through primary school, secondary school, university or some sort of training institution and go back to school. They never go into the outside world and they are to a degree academically oriented and, like Mr Chips and others, see the academic orientation as being the goal of education. I am afraid it must be said also that we have had this traditional approach because basically it is easier. It is much easier to teach this sort of traditional education because the kids who cannot cope with it are simply labelled as dumb and are off-loaded.

The rationalisation has been put forward quite often that everyone must have the same opportunities. Sure, but that does not mean the same sort of education. I put the point strongly that the majority of students who pass through our secondary schools need a different sort of education than that which is academically oriented. I think this must be ascertained by a study of the needs. We must identify the needs of the students. We must go into the community, we must go to the employers, we must go to the parents and we must go to the students themselves to find out what their needs really are. This can be done only by co-operation between all sectors of the community.

It is most unfortunate that I have to report that our inquiry clearly revealed that this sort of co-operation does not exist at present. There is not a movement between the employer and the school, not a great deal between the parent and the school and certainly not between the broader community, which also has a set of needs, and the school. Some work has been done, I must admit that; but a lot more needs to be done. When we spoke to the people at the schools they said that the employers would not tell them what their needs were. This may not be well received, but I suggest that most employers do not know what their needs are. They do not really know what they want the kids to be able to do when they come to them from school. They cannot pin down the sorts of skills they want. I think this is possibly because over the years employers have had a very high standard of student coming to them. The student has been able to adapt to the employer and to learn the skills of the trade. On the other hand, of course, the employers say that the schools do not ask them about their needs. I say that we need co-operation and that we need the schools and the employers to get together.

I suggest that employer organisations ought to take it as a project right across Australia to try to establish some dialogue between the schools and the organisations and the people they represent, to find out what the needs are so that these can be transferred to the schools and programs can be devised to meet those needs. I make the further point that the education departments have a responsibility in this area. I take up the point that Senator Teague made, namely, that the Australian Education Council has some responsibility. The Federal Government, of course, should be initiating this. I will come back to this later. When these needs have been established, by whatever means-whether by project, by the department initiating it or by the schools becoming motivated to go and find out themselves-we must devise appropriate learning experiences, or 'ways of teaching', in the old phraseology.

I make the point very strongly-this is a point that so many people seem to overlook-that different students learn in different ways. I go back to the old Australian Council for Educational Research publication which stated that each student is different, each one has different needs. Not a great deal was said about the different sorts of learning experiences that ought to be set up to meet the needs of students. I point out that for some students the activity of the learning experience is more important than the content. In other words, the way in which students are taught is more important. I do not like the word 'teach'. I think that we ought to talk about creating a situation where students learn. We do not teach students; we create a situation where students learn. We do not pour it into them like doses of medicine. A situation is created of which the student is able to take advantage and in which he can learn.

We need to establish needs. Having established those needs, we should set up the appropriate learning experience situations or the ways in which the students can learn. In brief, I ask that needs be established and that there be the provision of the appropriate learning experiences. I make the point that it does not cost any more. We do not need any additional money to do this. It can be done and it has been done. I will cite one example from my own experience: Way back in 1954 this sort of thing was done in Western Australia with the old Higher School Certificate courses. So, this has been done before. It simply requires organisation, and, of course, effective teachers. I will come to the matter of effective teachers in a moment.

First, I want to take up a point raised by Senator Teague. He mentioned one of the vocational colleges visited by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. Certainly it was a very effective learning institution. But I make the point very strongly that these sorts of institutions should not be necessary. The work done in these institutions ought to be done in the secondary schools. I am very strongly of the view that we should not say that the school is not doing this work and we ought to set up some other institution. We ought to say to the secondary school that has been given the responsibility to do this job 'You are not doing it. Get on with the job and do it', and not provide an alternative. By all means let us see this college as an interim measure because this job has to be done. We should say 'Let us deal with that group of students who have missed out in the secondary school'; but for goodness sake let us see the prime job as revising our secondary schools so that they will be doing the job for which they were set up; that is, catering for the needs of all students who go there, not 10, 15 or 20 per cent of students who will go on to universities or colleges of advanced education.

I will deal briefly with the subject of teachers. Quite a deal has been said in the report about this and I draw the attention of honourable senators to the recommendations made. To me, as one who was in the teaching service for quite a number of years, one of the most disturbing aspects of the inquiry was the complaints we got from parents, students, lecturers in colleges of advanced education and employers about the inability of teachers to teach, the lack of interest shown by teachers in their students, and the teachers' lack of awareness of the needs of their students and, for that matter, of the outside world. Of course, there is much generalisation. Without any hesitation I say that in a lot of schools a lot of good work is being done. We have some outstanding teachers. Many of the complaints that were made were not justified. But unfortunately enough specific examples were given and there was enough indication from employers and parents for this to be of great concern to someone such as myself and, of course, to the other senators serving on the Committee. I had a special interest because I had been involved in teaching for so many years.

I call on the departments of education to train teachers. I know that there will be much argument from former colleagues of mine, from the Teachers Federation and from academics about the choice of words here. Education of teachers is important, but the teachers must be able to create meaningful learning experience situations; in other words, they must be able to teach. The only way to get teachers is to train them. I know that I will be labelled as old fashioned, but as far as I am concerned teachers ought to be able to carry out the work of their chosen vocation. We ask doctors to be able to do certain things in medicine, we ask carpenters to be able to do certain things in their trade and we ask mechanics to be able to do their things. I am quite happy for honourable senators to say: 'Let us have educated technicians'. I am quite happy with the educated technicians. But let us have technicians and, of course, let us reject elitist comments about technicians. There is nothing wonderful about being in a profession. There is no difference between being in a profession and being in a trade. One does the job that hopefully one is able to do best, where one can achieve some satisfaction and where one can contribute.

I believe that some aspects of the profession are too specialised for every teacher to have the skills. For example, I do not think that every teacher needs to be an expert in curricula. I believe that the education departments or the schools, whoever has the responsibility, ought to be able to provide this expertise and to work with teachers and help them create curricula. For goodness sake, do not let us clutter up the teacher's training time or education time, call it what you like-I prefer 'training time'-with training that person to be expert in curricula development. Not all teachers will want to do this and not all will have the skills or the potential to develop those skills. Again, teachers should be provided with programming assistance, and they should be provided with help in remediation. Of course, all teachers ought to be able to carry out remedial education, but it is a specialised job. Do not let us spend a lot of time making every teacher an expert in remediation. Let us develop experts and develop teachers who are able to follow the advice given to them by the experts and to carry out the jobs themselves. Again I say that this is the responsibility of the school or the department, whichever is the organising core. The teacher has his or her job of relating to the child and implementing school or department policy. I would be happy to elaborate that theme here or elsewhere.

The selection of teachers is important. During the inquiry some scathing comments were made about the situation that existed previously. A lecturer from a college of advanced education spoke of the years of the late 1940s and early 1950s-incidentally, that is the time at which I was recruited as a teacher-when one only had to be 'warm and vertical'. The comments were made in a very scathing manner. I wonder whether the alternative might be to be cold and academic. Surely it is more important to be warm. Obviously a balance is needed. Surely it is not too difficult to say that we ought to be selecting those people who want to teach.

In many cases teachers take on teaching as a second or third choice and because there is nothing else available. Teachers have said to me: 'I selected teaching because of the short hours during the day and the 12 weeks holiday a year'. One can imagine how effective those people were as teachers. Surely the applicant also must like working with children. Yet it is amazing how many teachers said in the course of our inquiry that they did not like children and found it difficult to relate to them; it is almost like a sailor who does not like the sea. If one intends to spend one's entire life working with children one must like children. At the risk of again being called old fashioned, may I say that we want to see some dedication to teaching. I say that without any apology. We need dedicated teachers. We need dedicated people in other areas, but we are talking about education. Of course we need intelligent people. Would it be meaningless to say that we want the best possible people we can get who have an interest in children? Surely it is not beyond the competence of our psychologists and guidance people to devise techniques for the selection of teachers. Let us not have any more scathing comments about people who are simply 'warm and vertical'.

In conclusion, I believe there are four things that ought to happen. Firstly, the Federal Government should take the initiative in two areas-through the Australian Education Council and by asking the State Ministers to look at this problem. We should devise ways of using our present resources-no additional money is necessary-to have different techniques. We should use what we have more effectively. We should be getting more value for the educational dollar, which is also the title of a book that is on my shelf. There is a lot of good sense in that sort of thing. The second responsibility which the Federal Government has is to make finance available to be put through the Schools Commission for innovative programs and so on. I do not have to develop that theme. I make the point again that schools themselves can now do something at no additional cost. Departments and colleges of advanced education can do something, at no extra cost, simply by reallocating resources. Finally, the wide community-the parents, the employers and all of those who have a responsibility in this area-also should accept the challenge and respond to it. I remember a comment made some years ago. Someone who was trying to make a smart remark said: 'Education is too important to be left to teachers'. I do not accept that but I think the thought behind it is something to consider. We ought to accept that the community has a responsibility. The teachers are not the only ones involved. It is a total community responsibility from the grass roots level through to the Federal Government. I, like other members of the Committee, hope that all of those groups will respond to the challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before turning my attention to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I would like the Senate to note that the remarks by the Australian Democrats on this matter were originally intended to have been left to my colleague Senator Michael Macklin whose qualifications, as some honourable senators may be aware, are eminently suitable to the task. Unfortunately, a death in his immediate family called him home to Brisbane late this afternoon. It is a credit to him, I might add, that he stayed on in the Senate as late as he did. It is an even greater credit to him that he spoke in this chamber within half an hour of hearing of his mother's death. It is extrordinary that he spoke as well as he did under those circumstances. I think it is appropriate for me to make that point now.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts is a particular favourite of mine. It was a committee on which I sat as an ex-officio member in 1978 when it was conducting its inquiry into the effect of television on children. I was not able to be an official member of the Committee then but I did take part in its inquiry and deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You made a good contribution.

—I thank the honourable senator. I enjoyed it. I regret that I have less time now than I had in those days to participate in what I consider to be an extremely valuable and indeed vital element of Senate procedure and one which probably contributes more to the Federal Houses of Parliament than any other. I say that with absolutely no bias whatsoever, Mr Acting Deputy President! The inquiry which we are discussing tonight is a report entitled 'Preparation for the Workforce'. It is an inquiry into the effectiveness of Australian schools in preparing young people for the work force and places particular emphasis on literacy and numeracy. Senator Robertson referred early in his speech to the number of inquiries which have been made into various aspects of the education system and the number of reports that have come from them. It seems to me that at the moment the scoreboard reads 'reports 65-action nil'. I look forward to the day when that scoreboard changes substantially. Nowhere is the lack of action more evident than in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to say that I am one of the principals behind an increasing demand in South Australia for an inquiry into the Public Examinations Board of South Australia, which many of us who have been involved in the teaching profession, as have Senator Robertson and Senator Teague, are greatly disturbed by. We feel that the PEB in South Australia has perpetrated nothing less than a giant con trick on parents, students and on the community at large in its attitude to the method of marking, scaling and grading of students who undertake year 12 or the matriculation examination in that State. It argues from the theory that the average IQ of students or people in general does not vary from year to year. Therefore, in any matriculation examination the same percentage of students ought to pass each subject. That seems to me to be a rather quaint corollary because surely the quality of teaching, the sorts of elements within the education system, should have some effect on what students know and on their ability to answer the questions that are posed to them in the only public examination-that is, the only non-internal examination-held in South Australia.

The scheme that has been devised, I am sure, confuses even members of the Board. In effect what the Board does is take a mark, put it through a computer and multiply it by some conversion factor so that it comes out differently and, in most cases, higher. Last year, for instance, a student who received a mark of 17 per cent in the matriculation mathematics examination was in fact given a mark of 52 after the grading and scaling procedure had been used. That student was led to believe, as were his parents and so would be his future employer, that his ability at mathematics-I suggest to Senator Teague that I am assuming wrongly that the student was a male; but possibly I am not wrong-was greater than it actually was.

It pleases me that this report paid extreme attention to the elements of literacy and numeracy and the factors affecting them. Early in the report it was noted that attitudes of parents, of the teaching profession and of the community generally are important in the education system, in the way students see the education system and in the way in which society sees it. The report drew the conclusion that often those attitudes of parents, the teaching profession and the community generally are unrealistic. It came to the very accurate secondary conclusion that those attitudes are basically inconsistent.

Most of us who have been in the teaching profession, whether as skilled technicians or as some sort of esoteric elite, will say that parents in particular have rather strange ideas of the capabilities of their offspring. Their ideas of the capabilities are either too high or too low, either way most teachers can not win. It has been my misfortune to have in my classes young lads whose only aim in life has been to become motor mechancis and whose parents aim for them to become surgeons general. The reverse, of course, is also the case but that is more predominant with regard to girls. Far too high a percentage of parents of girls are still of the belief that if girls do shorthand and typing they will always get a job. Of course, that is fallacious. It is becoming more and more fallacious. The situation is becoming tragic for a large number of girls in the education system at the moment who are being ill-prepared for the employment world for which they are heading.

The inconsistency between attitudes of various sections of the community causes problems in coming to conclusions of the sort contained in this report because they tend to muddy the water in an area in which a clear view is essential if we are to solve any of the very evident problems inherent in the education system at present. Indeed, there are many problems of literacy and numeracy. I share with Senator Teague his determination not necessarily to go back to the old 3Rs system, to the old chalk and talk system. We do not look on education simply as something that we pour inside a series of students' ears and expect that to make them capable of carrying on in later life as adults in the work force or in society generally. That will not be the case at all.

Unfortunately, however, the conclusion remains that students are becoming less and less literate and practically non-numerate. Of course, this is not to say-Senator Teague pointed this out too-that the changes in the education system and the consequent changes in the sorts of things that young people these days know are necessarily all bad. In many ways these young people are more self-assured and more aware of social issues than we were at their age. That is a very good thing. In many ways, too, they are more flexible than we were because they are more self-assured and more aware.

However, in other ways they are much less flexible. To begin with, they have absolutely no conception of their own limitations and ability. Unfortunately, this is a situation which has occurred because, through the education system, they have not been trained in any sort of analysis-self-analysis in particular-or trained to accept any form of criticism, constructive or destructive. It has been a myth-I say myth advisedly-in the last decade or so in the education system-certainly in South Australia and for all I know in other States as well-that to correct a student's work would in some way diminish that student; that one must not interrupt a student's creative flow to point out that the sentence he has just written does not make sense, that his essay has no beginning, much less a middle or an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would give the little darlings a complex.

—That is for sure. The myth continues; if we ask students to write an essay on Wordsworth and they choose to do it on Byron because they know his work better, we ought not to penalise them for this because, after all, they have every right to discuss Byron notwithstanding the fact that it is not the answer to the question. Such students leave the school system ill prepared to front up to the sort of competitiveness, the sort of criticism and the sort of analysis which is thrown at them, not only in the work force, if they are fortunate enough to get a job, but also in the general social sphere.
—Is it really like that?

—Indeed, it is very much like that. I draw the attention of senators present to a theory of which some will be aware. I imagine Senator Teague is aware of it. I refer to Bernstein's theory of restricted and non-restricted codes. He argues-I am sorry that Senator Chipp is not conversant with the theory--
—I am not in your league on this. I go to the bottom of the class.
—I am not only Senator Chipp's tennis partner; I am also in league with him on this matter.

—For the information of those honourable senators, I will briefly elucidate. Bernstein argues that people fit into a number of coded areas for communication skills. Scientific jargon is one such system. The codes are rather esoteric and are limited to rather small 'in' groups of people. Beyond that, there is a non-restricted code; that is general language used by most people within the cultural group. Clearly, the drug sub-culture has its own restricted code; one has to be a member of the sub-culture to be aware of the jargon used. A restricted code serves a purpose. It gives people within the group a certain sense of identity. I suppose the Masonic lodges would be an example.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not being at all critical of the use of restricted codes. The trouble comes when the codes become so restricted that only those within the group can understand them and when those within the group cannot make themselves understood to the wider group. Scientists have their own jargon. Lawyers are even worse, but they do somehow, sometimes, manage to come down to the level of us ordinary mortals. However, often-this is happening more and more-we find students who are simply unable to communicate at all outside the very restricted area of the school environment. They have been subjected to teachers who have read their work and said: 'I understand what the student is getting at; therefore I will mark it on that basis'. The teacher considers it irrelevant that the student sitting next door may not have the faintest clue what the first student is going on about. That kind of attitude from teachers is doing, and has done, a grave disservice to many in our student population. A specific case in point occurred in the 1979 public examination for matriculation English. The second paper is the literacy paper. I will explain for Senator Chipp's benefit that in South Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you giving me a bad time?

—Senator Chipp was the first person I saw. The situation in South Australia is slightly different from other States in that we have two English papers and all students who do English have to do both papers. The first paper is the literature paper and it accounts for something like 75 per cent of the marks. The second paper is the literacy paper and it accounts for 25 per cent of the marks. The first paper really demonstrates only the capabilities of the teacher. A good teacher can tell any class of students all they need to know about Tess of the d'Urbevilles so that they can answer any question they are likely to get on it at the end of the year. The second paper consists of one or more unseen passages of prose which students are asked to read, to think about and then to discuss in an intelligent manner. They are very rarely difficult. In 1979, the two passages were, firstly, a newspaper report, and secondly, the transcript of a school broadcast by Colin Thiele. As any good journalist would tell us, they pitch most of their articles to an average reading age of about twelve. Colin Thiele's report was directed at lower secondary high school students. The average mark gained by students that year was five and a half out of thirteen. Not only could they not read it accurately but they had no hope of communicating accurately what they had read. To me that was an absolute tragedy. It was made worse by the fact that through the machinations of the PEB this effect was masked under the scale and grading system.

SPEECH.PARA: This inability of students to communicate will cause enormous problems when they move from the limited sphere of the school environment to the broader world. As the report pointed out, this inability to communicate is aggravated by an excessive reliance in many schools on the electronic media, a situation which is further aggravated by the student's own reliance on television and other elements in the electronic media outside school hours. It must be patently apparent to most people that the fewer senses one uses, the less one derives from a situation. Television viewing teaches most students that if they do not hear something on the television they can usually work out what happened by looking at it. If they turn their heads away to look at something else, they catch the general gist from what they hear. They are not taught to rely in any way at all on a combined set of senses. They are certainly not taught to rely in any sense on their imagination.

Unfortunately, as the report points out, many of the teaching aids provided in schools have an excessively American oriented influence. This of course is a bad thing too because it destroys Australian culture. I pointed out in 1978 in a question that I asked of the then Minister for Education that teacher training was suffering from the vast numbers of educational psychology text books in the libraries of colleges of advanced education which emanated from United States or British based authors-countries whose social system bears very little real relation to our own when it comes to educational psychology. We do not have the sort of class structure that Britain does. We do not have the sorts of racial problems to contend with in the classroom that the United States and Britain have. The reliance on overseas based technological aids can only be a further damaging influence on the system.

Finally, I would like to say a word or two about something that Senator Teague raised in his extremely comprehensive discussion of this report, and that is women mathematics teachers. It is an unfortunate fact of life that women, or girls really, are discouraged actively by both their parents and the school from embarking on science or mathematics oriented subjects or courses. They are discouraged from this by parents and schools because society generally does not encourage it. This is, as Senator Teague pointed out, reflected in the fact that very few female teachers are conversant in any way with mathematics courses. They therefore serve only to reinforce to their female students and their male students that mathematics and the sciences are outside the normal province of most women.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it perpetuates the fallacy.

—Indeed, it perpetuates the fallacy. There is no reason at all why women cannot be as competent in figuring as are men. I am therefore forced to say that I am somewhat disappointed in the report-I would ask Senator Teague to correct me if I am wrong in this-in that it did not recommend a positive encouragement for a change in this attitude. The Committee skirted about it in its section on the teaching profession. It looked at the primary teachers' inadequate understanding of mathematics. It looked at the problem of young married teachers, almost entirely from the point of women, but it did not front up adequately, it seems to me, to the fact that we need to positively encourage young girls and women to take their full place in all courses available within educational institutions. In that way, and only in that way, will preparation for the work force, which is the title of this report, be at all relevant to something like 51 per cent of the population.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Alternatives to Petroleum Based Fuels: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 June on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke very briefly on this matter when the report entitled 'Alternatives to Petroleum Based Fuels: Government Response' was tabled on 2 June. I want to add just a few comments. The thrust of the report by the Committee and the Government's response to it, of course, is concerned with fuel conservation and alternatives to liquid fuels. I will make two observations about the existing Government policy on liquid fuel conservation. One observation is that, as everyone would have known without any doubt, in the long term the policy of pricing liquid fuels at higher prices would ultimately have some effect on consumption, and it has been shown that it has already had some effect on consumption. In fact, the import parity pricing policy of the Government is more a revenue raising policy that a fuel conservation policy. In addition, since it was first imposed in 1978 it has had the highly undesirable side effect of substantially lifting the inflation rate. If the Government were concerned solely with the use of the price mechanism as a fuel conservation policy it would have been possible to achieve that objective while having a neutral effect on inflation if commensurate reductions in other areas of indirect taxation had accompanied the introduction of the import parity pricing for crude oil.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point, although relatively small in terms of potential fuel savings, is important insofar as it demonstrates the spotty nature of the Government's commitment to a fuel conservation policy. Each week some thousand empty seats are available on Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft in both directions operating between Perth and the eastern States. As a result of long-standing Government policy reconfirmed for a minimum period of eight years only two months ago, that ludicrous situation will continue. Apart from the potential to offer interstate air travel to Western Australians at very much lower rates if the Government were to deregulate the industry at least to this extent, there is also the potential for saving 250,000 litres of aircraft fuel each week if those empty Qantas seats were to be occupied and the services provided by the domestic operators reduced accordingly. I will comment briefly on several of the specific recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and/or on the Government's response to them. Recommendation 9 of the Committee states:
LPG be made eligible for the rural freight subsidy.
The Government's response reads:
In view of the subsidies already announced for household and traditional commercial and decentralised industrial LPG users, it is not considered appropriate to act on this recommendation.

Given that the main thrust of the Committee's report was concerned with fuel-this is the case with all reports concerned with petroleum fuels-there are two inadequacies or obfuscations in that Government response. Firstly, the subsidy provided for liquefied petroleum gas at the moment is most significant. Indeed, the only area in which the subsidy is at all relevant is LPG used for industrial purposes and, in particular, for crude space heating-the crudest of all possible purposes. No subsidy is paid on LPG used for automotive fuel. As a result of administered pricing LPG is made available for automotive fuel at lower prices than it is made available for some other purposes. However, no explicit freight subsidy is paid on LPG. Whether it ought to be is, in my opinion, a matter for legitimate debate. Indeed, whether a freight subsidy ought to be paid on any type of petroleum fuel is a matter for legitimate dispute.

The stated objective of the Government policy is to compensate people for the disadvantages of living in remote areas. That policy continues a long-standing and irrational tradition in Australian policy making, that tradition being that where there is a professed desire to compensate people for the high costs of living in particular areas or any other form of disability, the all too common and irrational response of Australian Governments has been to subsidise the commodities bought by those people instead of applying the far more logical, obvious and cost-effective mechanism of subsidising those peoples' incomes if they are thought to be particularly disadvantaged. I note that this view was endorsed in somewhat stronger language by the Liberal Party member of the House of Representatives for Moore, Mr Hyde, in the Australian on 11 August. Speaking on the fuel freight subsidy he said:
The fuel freight subsidy flies in the face of the Government's import parity pricing policy and is an incentive to waste a scare resource.

Obviously there are significant differences of opinion within the Government parties on that matter. I observe in passing that reason and common sense are on the side of the honourable member for Moore and not on the side of the official Government policy. Recommendation 18 refers to shale oil and, specificially, to the Rundle project, although the Government response and the Committee report referred in particular to the environmental aspects of the Rundle shale oil proposal. Since that Committee's report was published the environmental implications of that proposal have become somewhat more hypothetical because the proposal, at least for the present, has failed-and by 'the present' I mean at least for the rest of this decade-on purely economic grounds, notwithstanding the gallant attempt by the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, to talk up the shares over a period of 12 months.

Recommendation 19 to recommendation 22A inclusive are concerned with the production of liquid fuels from vegetative sources and from crop production. The Committee recommended that there be a continuation of research into this area of alternative fuels. Whilst it would be prudent in the long term selectively to breed plants which may have some potential for liquid fuel production, this whole area of alternative fuels produced from vegetative sources is one which has spawned a great deal of woolly thinking, some of which has been exhibited in the Parliament from time to time and a great deal more of which has been exhibited outside the Parliament. The plain fact is that, given present plants and present technology, liquid fuel produced from these sources is not price competitive at present prices, by a factor of 20c to 30c a litre, with local fuel produced from crude oil from the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. World oil prices would have to double at least before these alternative sources became cost competitive with present technology.

A particularly woolly proposition in this area has recently been canvassed by the Western Australian Government. The Premier, Sir Charles Court-who was the prime architect of the Ord River scheme, which has to this date absorbed more than two hundred million present value dollars in public investment for no public return-made a very disturbing announcement earlier this month that before the end of 1981 it would be announced that a sugar production enterprise on the Ord River scheme entailing an investment of an additional $200m would be entered into. The Premier added that it had not been decided at this stage whether the project would produce crystal sugar or ethanol.

Given the fact that two hundred million present value dollars of public capital has already been sunk into the project and is irretrievable, it is possible that at the Ord River crystal sugar could be produced which is cost competitive with any increased crystal sugar production in Queensland. The question of ethanol production is in an entirely different category. A Bureau of Agricultural Economics study almost two years ago showed that before ethanol could be price competitive with alternative liquid fuels, cane would have to be available at about half the going price for sugar cane for export. Moreover, if significant quantities of ethanol were to be produced in the remote Kimberleys area, it would be necessary to ship it south or, at the very least, north-east to Darwin before a market for that volume of production could be found. The cost of doing that would add enormously to the production cost of the ethanol. If the Western Australian Government is seriously considering investing-or, more accurately, wasting-an additional $200m on sugar production in the Ord River for the production of ethanol it has abandoned, forsaken, any remaining credibility which it may have had in the area of rational economic management. Unfortunately, given the whole sorry history of the Ord River scheme and in particular of the Premier's irrational commitment to it, the possibility of the Government embarking on a major ethanol producing project in the Ord River area cannot be entirely dismissed.

As a final comment, I observe that Sir Charles Court is extremely lucky to have escaped from the private sector into the public sector almost 30 years ago, because nobody with such a record of managerial blunders of the magnitude which he has had, and nobody who manifested the same level of managerial incompetence that Sir Charles Court has manifested in respect of the Ord River scheme, had he remained in the private sector could possibly have remained solvent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Jessop:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as this is the first speech I have made since you assumed your high office, I take the opportunity to wish you a successful term of office. The report from the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on Australian marine science is unique in that it is the product of the brains of three component parties of this Senate. In addition to Senators Jessop, Townley and MacGibbon, from the socialists Senator Melzer and I were on the Committee. The Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Mason, was also a member. Time is not on our side in regard to this report. We had a very fine debate in this place some time ago about whale protection. Again we had a cross-fertilisation of ideas.

SPEECH.PARA: When we assumed the responsibility of the 200-mile off-shore zone, as I said earlier, we did not want to be in a position where we were over-liberal-I use that word not in the political sense-in the way we extended the franchise to foreign nations to have their trawlers operating within our 200-mile zone. One or two misguided Latin American governments found, to their cost, that their fishing grounds were virtually eliminated in such a situation. I would not like to see that develop here. I know we are regarded as a relatively fat cat nation in terms of the living standards of some Asian countries, and there will be growing agitation to let more and more foreign trawlers come in. I would not like to see us in the defensive position in which the United Kingdom was placed during the cod war with Iceland. As with all issues, there are two points of view. I know the recommendations that the Committee made provided for an updating of modern marine research so that, among other things, if we had the misfortune to have some other nation complain to the United Nations that we were a little narrow in the administration of our fishing resources we would want to have the technical data to refute it and not be in a defensive position. My prime contribution is in relation to page 52 of the report, where the Committee's recommendation states:

. . . the declaration of the 200n.m. Australian Fishing Zone should be accompanied by research into the fauna of this zone, especially mammals, and how they can be adequately protected from the over-exploitation of their foodstocks.

From our possessions in the Antarctic we know of the problem concerning krill. Its utilisation to feed the growing populations of certain portions of the globe has to be reconciled with the protection of the habitat and needs of mammals, including whales and dolphins. It is an area that has to be monitored very closely. To me the vision splendid conjured up in my mind is that the 200-mile zone will give protection to mammals. Anyone who has seen films, documentaries or books on the subject would feel proud that in this Australian Parliament we achieved a bipartisan policy that set the pace, even in deliberations of the International Whaling Commission.

The fact that there has been a further advance in relation to the protection of some varieties of whales does not ignore the fact that two major powers, Japan and the Soviet Union, have reservations about the restrictions on hunting sperm whales. I know the Sydney Press, and doubtless interstate newspapers, have indicated that some Australians have endeavoured to expose any breaches or cribbings by these two countries. Apart from those countries, maverick pilot whalers endeavour to breach the conventions. I know it is difficult to get a unanimous decision. I have always been one of those who believe in gradualism, as long as we are getting something all the time. Canada is letting its membership of the Commission lapse. I know both the countries that I have mentioned could argue, to a point, about food stocks. I believe there will have to be tremendous vigilance, although marine mammals probably have some particular inbuilt mechanism in their makeup which will allow them to learn quickly where these protection zones are. Australia lacks effective coastguard services and our Navy is not large, and there will be a profit incentive for these maverick trawlers.

I make the point that the Government will very quickly take on board some of the recommendations that have been the product of a tri-partite approach. I say that because I can remember attending a hearing last year dealing with the estimates of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I think Senator Puplick was involved in the dialogue too. We raised the matter of the beaching of whales on some parts of the Australian coastline. I know it is very difficult to control this. I do not say that it is like the lemmings in reverse but, conversely, there has been some success with some salvage operations in the United States of America and Norway. I think it is an area in which the Marine Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation should be encouraged to do a lot more. There is no question about that.

We had evidence from outstanding people like Dr Ling, the curator of the South Australian museum, one of the foremost authorities on seals. He has had extensive experience in North America, including Canada and Greenland. We are very fortunate to have people like him. We also heard evidence from Dr Guiler from Tasmania, another man whose reputation in the fauna and conservation field is beyond question. These people felt that we had to be extremely vigilant. I know that in some fishing areas there has been a lot of clamouring about seals being serious competitors. Actually, the evidence to the Committee was to the contrary. We heard in other evidence that we are losing certain squid trawling to Japanese interests. The question is whether the fairy penguin and the fur seal could be affected by this trawling. Extensive evidence was given-I think Senator Peter Rae would appreciate this-by Victorian and Tasmanian conservation groups which was not refuted by anyone.

The point I am making is that a very well co-ordinated effort has to be made by the States and the Commonwealth to block any poaching. The other great danger is oil spills. What happens if we have tanker disasters of the magnitude of the Torrey Canyon disaster or the Oceanic Grandeur disaster? It is true that successive governments have tightened up the Navigation Act and certain compensation laws. Honourable senators have probably noted that some odd things happen with these Liberian registered tankers. On investigating one recent mishap in the Atlantic Ocean it was discovered that the officer of the watch had written away to a correspondence school and received a document which stated that he was a first officer. He bought this document for $51 in New York. These are the sorts of situations that have to be faced. I believe it is stupid to say they will not occur.

Without getting too political or ideological on the matter, we did get evidence from some of the oil companies. I am not altogether satisfied that some of the research carried out by Esso-BHP is put at the disposal of Australia as a nation. I think that over a number of years the information is fed back but I have always had a feeling about where the benefits of the research go. Does it go to the board room first or to the Australian Government's specialised services? These are the things we have to face up to.

This is a report which is extremely comprehensive in its recommendations. I have not noticed that the Budget contains a lot of hope as far as the implementaion of these recommendations is concerned. When we reach the Estimates committee stage we may be able to get information about the finer points in the recent International Whaling Conference report.

To wind up I would say that we probably have five years at best to implement an effective monitoring system for the conservation of our fishing resources and effective protection of our mammals. I would hope that during the Estimates committee hearings, if we cannot get a statement from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), we will be able to debate these issues. Quite frankly, I am one of those people who believe that when poaching or transgressions occur it is not a question of flogging people with feathers. Recently an Indonesian vessel as well as one Taiwanese trawler breached our fishing rights. We are certainly not as tough as we ought to be. More punitive measures ought to be taken. I simply repeat that I hope that when we get on to the Estimates we will receive an IWC report which we can relate to the recommendations made in this excellent report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
