DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines: Staff Superannuation Provisions-The Senate: Answers to Questions

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My purpose in speaking tonight on the motion for the adjournment is to ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who represents the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), to make a clear statement to the Senate about the superannuation provisions for Trans Australia Airlines staff. I do not, of course, expect the Minister to make such a statement this evening but I trust that he will be able to do so in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: When, earlier this year, the Government decided to repeal the Australian National Airlines Act and transfer TAA's operations to a public company, many TAA staff members became justifiably concerned about their security. At the time I was approached by a number of staff members and subsequently asked two questions which had been raised by some of them. On 7 April I asked the following question on notice:
(1) Will Trans-Australia Airlines' staff be given first option to purchase shares in a TAA public company, should they become available.
(2) Will the superannuation entitlement of TAA staff be affected.

The answer that I received did not properly address itself to the two questions that I had asked. Whilst this is regrettable, it is not unusual in this Parliament for Ministers to be deliberately evasive. Senator Messner reported that the Minister for Transport had provided the following answer to my two questions:

The Parliament recently passed legislation to repeal the Australian National Airlines Act and transfer TAA's operations to a public company. Provisions included the transfer of all staff on the same terms and conditions on which they were employed by the Commission. All the shares in the new company will initially be held by the Government. The Government has also decided to commission private consultants to examine the practicality of selling some or all of the shares in TAA including how this might be done in light of the Government's domestic aviation policies. The consultant's report is expected to be completed within 12 months.

Really, that answer means nothing. It does not say whether or not TAA staff would be able to obtain some equity in the company for which they work. All that it reveals in relation to the share issue is that some unknown consultants are to report to the Government on how some or all of the shares in TAA are to be sold. As well, the question of the superannuation entitlement of TAA staff was not specifically answered. One could infer from the answer that their rights would not be affected. In part the answer said:
Provisions included the transfer of all staff on the same terms and conditions on which they were employed by the Commission.
But if one were to infer from that part of the answer that the superannuation entitlements of staff would not be affected, one would certainly come to the wrong conclusion.

I have been given some information about a new superannuation scheme which has been offered to TAA employees. Even so, I do not properly understand the vagaries of the new scheme. This is not surprising, as many staff members also feel confused. One employee remarked to me that the staff no longer spoke about football during their lunch break; that all conversation related to the new superannuation scheme.

What I am asking the Minister to do is bring down in the Parliament a statement outlining the full details of the new TAA superannuation scheme. In particular, I would expect these points to be covered: What were the basic details of the superannuation scheme covering TAA employees prior to TAA becoming a public company and what are the basic details of the current scheme? What benefits were available for employees under the old scheme and what are the benefits under the current scheme? Do TAA employees of long standing have to transfer totally to the new scheme? If they do, how are their prior superannuation payments to be taken into account in determining benefits for employees? If they do not have to transfer, does it mean that they will stay totally within their old scheme, or will they become members of two separate schemes? Are there different superannuation schemes for different levels of staff? How will TAA save money out of the new proposals and how much does it expect to save? What is the role of the Australian Mutual Provident Society in TAA's superannuation plan? Were companies other than the AMP Society also allowed to submit plans about how they could become part of the scheme? Is the chairman of TAA, Sir Robert Law-Smith, also a director of the AMP society? If he is, does there seem to be some conflict of interest in the AMP Society's becoming involved with TAA? Were any funds contributed by TAA employees for superannuation purposes used to help pay for TAA's Airbuses? If so, what are the details of this financial exercise? If the Minister for Transport chooses not to make the information available for his colleague in this chamber, I urge officers within the Minister's Department to take these questions on notice because it may be pertinent to pursue them in depth at the forthcoming meetings of the Senate Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that an answer to a question has not been included in Hansard. During the recess we were given answers to questions which we raised during the autumn session. I notice that a couple of mine have appeared in Hansard. But one, the most important, is not there. I wonder why. On 2 June I directed a question to Senator Carrick. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: In what years, if any, has South Australia not received its proper entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement.

I asked that question for a specific purpose. Statements had been made in South Australia by Mr Arnold, the Minister of Water Resources, accusing the New South Wales Government of thieving water from South Australia. I was very pleased when I got the answer to that question but very displeased that it was not published in today's Hansard. Senator Carrick's answer proves that Mr Arnold was drawing a long bow when he claimed that New South Wales was thieving South Australia's water. The answer reveals that only once since the signing of the River Murray Waters Agreement has South Australia not received its water entitlement. That was in 1944-45. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in today's Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SENATE QUESTION
(Without Notice)
RIVER MURRAY

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2413), Senator McLaren asked me the following question without notice:

SPEECH.PARA: In what years, if any, has South Australia not received its proper entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement.
The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

Information from the River Murray Commission indicates that annual flow to South Australia has only once, in 1944-45, been less than that to which that State is entitled under the River Murray Waters Agreement.

During the severe drought in 1944 and 1945, the water passed to South Australia amounted to 938,000 megalitres, some 608,000 megalitres less than South Australia's annual entitlement at that time. However, the volume actually available to South Australia in 1944-45 was 1,272,000 megalitres, some 274,000 megalitres less than entitlement, as South Australia decided to hold back 334,000 megalitres in reserve in Lake Victoria in case of a continuation of the drought into the following season.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is in the chamber, to see whether the other answers I received during the recess can also be incorporated in the next Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.18 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was presented, pursuant to statute:
Customs Tariff-Orders 1981-Developing Country-Nos 4, 5.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2790) Senator Martyr asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that, apparently without reason, some cottage owners on Garden Island, now better known as HMAS STIRLING have been asked to quit by 30 June 1981 while others are being allowed to stay until September this year? Will the Minister give the reasons for the difference or, better still, will he make all the notices to quit uniform to September this year?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The new armament depot at Garden Island, Western Australia, is scheduled to open early in October 1981. For safety reasons, all cottages on Garden Island must be removed by then, and notices have been served directing that they be removed by 30 September 1981.

A small number of cottages in the Luscombe Bay area will be removed by an earlier date in order to complete the armament depot and a demolition and burning area by the planned date. The Department of Housing and Construction has been requested to let those cottages remain as long as possible, but I have been assured that their removal in the near future is necessary to meet the project schedule.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2034) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: By way of preface, I refer to the recent statement by the Government deploring the escalation of violence between Iraq and Israel. Whilst we accept that what has been said is largely correct, why was there no comment about the acquisition of nuclear facilities by a Middle East power. Surely it is a threat to world peace. Why did the Government not say so in its statement.
The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Many countries see benefits in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy and acquire nuclear facilities to realise these benefits. The acquisition of a nuclear facility by a country does not in itself constitute a threat to peace provided that the facility is used exclusively for peaceful non-explosive purposes, for example, in the production of electricity.

To provide assurances that the nuclear facilities of countries are used exclusively for peaceful purposes, Australia has long advocated that all non-nuclear weapon states, whether in the Middle East or elsewhere, should become parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Under the NPT non-nuclear weapon states accept obligations not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices and to place all of their nuclear installations under International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3193) Senator Colston asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the Government's propensity to hand over Government enterprises to the private sector, is the Government considering replacing all or part of the defence personnel at the Enoggera base in Queensland with personnel from Metropolitan Security Services?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the following document, which was included in An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy, an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney 1972), now being published: (No. 73-Commonwealth Council for National Fitness (initial) survey).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

(2) In which of these centres is smoking prohibited in the lifts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 March 1981;

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the proposal to discharge sewage into Magela Creek from Jabiru, Northern Territory, just above the Gulungul billabong states that there should be no discharge until there is substantial flow in Magela Creek.
(2) Does the Minister believe that this should be quantified in a similar way to Ranger's attempt to quantify their original discharge proposal from retention pond No. 2.
(3) Who will decide when the effluent will be released.
(4) How will the effluent be dispersed into the creek.
(5) What is the mixing/dilution pattern in the creek.
(6) Have any dye studies been made regarding the proposal.
(7) Under what hydrological regimes will effluent enter Gulungul billabong and other billabongs.
(8) What criteria will apply to the cessation of discharges at the end of the wet season.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Yes. Flow rates in Magela Creek appropriate to quality and volume of effluent will be specified.
(3) The Controller of Water Resource.
(4) By discharge to a part of the main channel where flow conditions occur as specified in the authority to discharge effluent.

(5) A dye tracing study has shown that even under low flow conditions (15 cubic metres per second) a dilution ration greater than 400:1 can be achieved within 300 metres of the outfall when the discharge is equivalent to that of a population of 3000 persons.
(6) Yes, as indicated in answer to question (5).
(7) Effluent may enter Gulungul billabong under conditions causing backflows, and further dye studies will be needed to define those conditions.

(8) The general criterion will be that discharge will not be permitted when flow conditions fall below the limit given in the Fox report of 20 cubic metres per second. This would be applied particularly towards the end of the wet season.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will not the Gulungul billabong, Magela Creek, be a most important monitoring site for potential impacts from the Ranger Mines operation as it is the first backflow billabong downstream from Ranger (excluding Connjumba) and as such will be the first to show adverse effects should they occur.
(2) Has the Office of the Supervising Scientist shown concern to the Minister of the present proposal to discharge sewage from Jabiru just upstream from the Gulungul billabong.
(3) Has the Minister received any other representations of such concern.

(4) Will it be difficult to apportion the amount of change due to the effluent and that due to the operations of the Ranger uranium mine if this billabong is changed in any way by the sewage effluent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised as follows:

(1) Gulungul billabong is an important monitoring site for the potential impacts of discharge from the Ranger Uranium Mine. Research is being carried out to determine how any adverse effects, should they occur, might best be measured.
(2) The Supervising Scientist is seeking information on the proposal to discharge sewage from Jabiru so that an assessment of its potential environmental effect can be carried out.

(4) Distinguishing the effects on the environment of the discharge of sewage effluent from Jabiru from any possible effects from mining operations at Ranger could prove difficult. The ability to do this successfully will depend on the results of the environmental studies being carried out by the Supervising Scientist through the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that it is a matter of some public concern that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is without power to restore ownership of broadcasting interests to the status quo ante where it orders a party before it to divest itself of a previously obtained interest.

(2) Is the Minister for Communications aware that the Tribunal itself has referred this problem questioning 'whether it really accords with the Parliament's broad intentions on the matter' in its decision on the TEN-10 Sydney takeover handed down on 10 August 1979; if so, has anything been done to remedy the problem; and if not what action is proposed to remedy the problem.
(3) Will this problem be rectified by the current review of the Broadcasting and Television Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government was aware that the powers available to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal prior to the recent amendments were a matter of public concern.

(2) and (3) The Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1981 provides a new set of share transaction procedures and more effective powers for the Tribunal in dealing with unapproved interests. The Tribunal may give a wide range of directions under new sections 92M and 92N, which may be enforced in the Federal Court. It has not been considered appropriate to provide for a return to the status quo ante in the event that a transaction is unapproved. However, the Tribunal now has the power to ensure that a party does not divest itself of an interest by passing it to another party which would be ineligible or unlikely to gain approval to keep it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what circumstances are management consultants engaged by the Government to hire ministerial staff.
(2) What fees are payable to management consultants and on whose authority is a decision made to engage management consultants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's quesiton:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The selection of personal staff is traditionally a Minister's prerogative. As a general rule staff selections are made from applications received in response to press advertisements or from nominations by a Minister's own department of suitable departmental officers or by direct approach to persons known to the Minister.
Occasionally management consultants are used where there involvement is judged to be likely to be of particular value in the recruitment of suitable personnel.

(2) Fees payable would depend on the circumstances of each consultancy arrangement. The engagement of a consultant would be authorised by the Prime Minister or the Minister for Administrative Services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government and/or the Prime Minister aware of the whereabouts of Richard John Seary, the New South Wales Special Branch undercover agent who implicated members of the Ananda Marga Sect with the Hilton bombing in early 1978.
(2) Has the Government information regarding his residential address; if so, what is it.

(3) Did Richard John Seary have plastic surgery performed on his face prior to his leaving Australia; if so (a) who performed this operation, when and where; and (b) did the New South Wales Government pay for this operation.
(4) On what date did Richard John Seary leave Australia and from which port and by which carrier did he leave the country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) I have nothing further to add to the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs in reply to Question No. 649 (Hansard, 2 June 1981, page 2495).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Qantas seek to impose fare increases during the year 1979-80, but was prevented from doing this for some time by the Department of Transport.
(2) What was the period of time taken by the Department to process Qantas' application.
(3) How long was the delay produced.

(4) Did the Government approve a larger increase than the initial application called for to allow for forgone revenue during the delay, as it has just done with TAA and Ansett; if so, what are the details; and if not, why not.
(5) What was the total revenue forgone by Qantas in 1979-80 due to delays in approving fare increases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) Most of Australia's bilateral air services agreements provide for fares on a particular route to/from Australia to be jointly approved by Australia and the other country concerned.

However, the practice followed for many years has been that international airlines consult and agree on fares which are then recommended to relevant governments for approval. The very large majority of air fares on routes to/from Australia have been and continue to be set in this way.

Improved procedures became necessary in recent times when airlines began to incur frequent and often large cost increases, particularly in relation to fuel requirements. Streamlined procedures for formulating and approving fare increases were developed among airlines and have been endorsed by many countries, including Australia.
In the period while airlines were formulating the new procedures, there were some delays in lodgment of fare increase applications by airlines and subsequent approval of these by governments.

Comprehensive details are not readily available, but it is believed the total time that elapsed between airlines incurring higher costs and applying for compensating fare increases, exceeded the time taken to process and approve their applications for fare adjustments.
Each application by Qantas for fare increases is considered on the basis of supporting information provided by the Company.

As the Minister for Transport has previously indicated there have been a large number of different fare increase applications lodged with the Department of Transport in the period from 1 January 1979 to 31 December 1980. These have related to both specific routes and groups of routes. The most important of these have been the six general fare increase applications lodged by Qantas on behalf of other carriers and associated with the substantial increases in fuel costs. The proposed and actual effectiveness dates of fare increases in relation to the fuel cost increases over this period are as follows:
Effectiveness Decision Actual
date sought announced effectiveness Fuel increase*
by Qantas to industry date
* Qantas filings based on IATA worldwide conferences convened to consider cost increases.
* Delay due to requirement at that time for ASEAN Government approval.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) adult males; (b) adult females; (c) junior males; (d) junior females; (e) total males; (f) total females and (g) total persons were unemployed at the end of April in the following towns, cities and areas: Atherton, Ayr, Brisbane, Bundaberg, Cairns, Charleville, Dalby, Gladstone, Gold Coast, Gympie, Ingham, Innisfail, Ipswich, Longreach, Mackay, Maryborough, Mt Isa, Nambour, Rockhampton, Roma, Sunshine Coast, Toowoomba, Townsville, Townsville West, and Warwick.
(2) What percentage of the appropriate workforce do the figures for 1(a) to (g) above represent.
(3) How were the figures for 1(a) to (c) and 2(a) to (e) determined.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics there were an estimated (e) 12,000 males; (f) 11,800 females and (g) 23,700 persons unemployed and seeking full-time work in the Brisbane Statistical Division in April 1981. Unemployment data disaggregated by adult and junior cross-classified by males and females are not available for the Brisbane area. The information sought in respect of towns, cities and areas other than Brisbane is not available.
(2) The figures provided in (1) above for the Brisbane Statistical Division represent the following percentage of the appropriate labour force: (e) males 4.2%; (f) females 10.4% and (g) persons 6.0%.

(3) The source of the figures provided in (1) and (2) is the Australian Bureau of Statistics monthly labour force survey. For further details see the ABS publication 'The Labour Force, Australia'-Catologue No. 6203.0.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the average period of delay for the installation of telephones in (a) Byron Bay (b) Ballina and (c) Tweed Heads areas of New South Wales.
(2) How much has been spent in each of these areas in the last twelve months by Telecom on telephone installation works.
(3) What is the total number of outstanding applications for telephone installations in each of these areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia advises that, where telecommunications plant and equipment is available, the average period of delay for the installation of telephones is as follows:
(a) Byron Bay-11 weeks
(b) Ballina-8 weeks
(c) Tweed Heads-9 weeks

Where telecommunications plant and equipment is not currently available delays of 3 to 12 months can be expected. The number of outstanding applications that falls within this category are as follows:
(a) Byron Bay-97
(b) Ballina-37
(c) Tweed Heads-144
These applications are included in total outstanding applications listed in (3) below.
(2) Expenditure in each of these areas in the last 12 months has approximated:
(a) Byron Bay-$117,200
(b) Ballina-$427,500
(c) Tweed Heads-$661,200
(3) The total number of outstanding applications at 20 May 1981 for telephone installations are as follows:
(a) Byron Bay-116
(b) Ballina-143
(c) Tweed Heads-440.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Australia Post Courier service sell none of its assets, and stand down none of its employees as these will be used in the new Australia Post Express service which will perform all or almost all of the services previously carried out by Australia Post Courier except those involving non-standard articles; if so, is the so-called 'abolition' of the courier service really a ruse.
(2) Can the Minister for Communications give assurance that no Commonwealth money will be expended in changing the name of Australia Post Courier to Australia Post Express.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The new Australia Post Express service. which is to be introduced on 1 July 1981, will be quite different, operationally, from the Courier service and will carry postal items only, as part of the mail service. Exact details of the form the service will take are still being developed.

At this stage, Australia Post has no definite plans to sell any of its assets as a result of the abolition of the Courier service, although some redeployment of existing Courier vehicles may occur and some may well be sold.
It is Australia Post's objective, in introducing the new Express service, that there should be no retrenchment of regular Courier staff. Staff retraining and redeployment is expected, however.
(2) As the Express service will operate quite differently from the Courier service, the question of 'changing the name' of Australia Post Courier to Australia Post Express does not arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the General Manager of the Australian Broadcasting Commission approached the Federal Police to conduct an investigation into allegations that senior members of the ABC Public Affairs Radio staff utilised ABC resources, labour, power and equipment to make private profit.
(2) Have the Federal Police agreed to undertake such an investigation. If so, (a) which officers are to conduct it; and (b) when will it be completed.
(3) What action may be taken if the allegations are proved to be substantially or partly correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. (a) Detectives attached to the Eastern Division of the Australian Federal Police; (b) The investigation is expected to be concluded shortly.
(3) Until the report of the investigation is received and considered no decision can be taken regarding possible action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what regulations and conditions are first issue commemorative envelopes made by Australia Post.

(2) Is there any limit on the number of any one issue that can be purchased by, or on behalf of, any one person, in one or several purchases; if not, would the Government consider implementing some limit.
(3) Are 'first issue' commemorative envelopes issued by Australia Post copyright. If not, will the Government consider doing this.

(4) In view of the story in the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial on 23 March 1981 would the Government consider amending such statutes and/or regulations as necessary to make it mandatory on any person producing and/or printing commemorative envelopes to have printed on the face of the envelope 'Not official issue by Australia Post. Printed privately by . . .'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia Post is responsible for the issue of commemorative pre-stamped envelopes and the authority to issue these and other postal stationery items is provided under Postal By-law 248 (1).

(2) Yes. Postal by-laws allow Australia Post to limit the quantities of commemorative pre-stamped envelope issues which may be purchased by an individual. It is Australia Post's policy, however, to apply this limit only if supplies are insufficient to meet the demands of philatelists.
(3) Stamp designs which are commissioned by Australia Post, and which appear on pre-stamped envelopes, are the copyright of Australia Post.

(4) Australia Post's experience is that there is little confusion among collectors in distinguishing between pre-stamped envelopes issued by Australia Post and those which are subsequently over-printed or printed by other persons or organisations. I do not consider that the situation warrants legislative intervention at this time but the matter will be kept under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent does the Department of Industry and Commerce monitor the level of foreign ownership of companies which manufacture groceries, toiletries and small household items sold in Australia.
(2) What up to date information does the Department keep on which companies manufacturing such items are Australian owned and/or controlled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department does not monitor the level of foreign ownership of companies manufacturing groceries, toiletries and small household items.
(2) No up to date information is maintained on the level of Australian ownership in companies manufacturing such items.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what way will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so how much is it estimated that it will save.
(3) In what way will those savings break down into component savings.

(4) Can the Minister give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the Government more than would the same services provided from within the public services by salaried officers.
(5) If the Minister cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the Government more money than they would save and if so what are the details.
(8) Has the Minister received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the Government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (8) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government has directed that the operations of the Baseline Air Pollution Station, operated by the Department of Science and Technology are to be contracted out. Potential contractors include private organisations and stautory authorities. At this time it is not possible to make comparative economic assessments between the two modes of operation of the facility.

In accordance with Government directions consideration is being given, within the Department and statutory authorities responsible to the Minister for Science and Technology, to the possibility of contracting out other activities. The detailed information sought by the honourable senator is not available at this time as the investigations have not yet been completed and specific recommendations have not been formulated for consideration by the Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the inquiry into ownership of newspapers being held in Victoria received a number of submissions calling for the inquiry to be conducted on the federal level.
(2) Does the Minister share the Victorian Liberal Government's concern about concentration of ownership in the media.
(3) Is there any action at the federal level to set up an inquiry or royal commission to investigate this problem, as has been done several times in Britain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of whether any submissions to the Norris inquiry in Victoria have called for the inquiry to be conducted on a federal level.

(2) Within my responsibility for the development of radio and television services, I am, of course, concerned that control of these services should not fall into too few hands. The Broadcasting and Television Act provides effective limitations on undue concentration of ownership, and the Government regards these limits as necessary and sufficient to achieve a reasonable diversity.

(3) The Commonwealth Government has no constitutional responsibility for the print media. Accordingly, there are no plans for action at a federal level along the lines of the inquiry currently being conducted in Victoria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Communications received a letter sent to him by a small firm called All Seasons Home Improvements; if so, (a) does that letter refer to a dispute between Telecom, the unions and the Department of Communications which has prevented the installation of PABX telephone systems with less than 50 extensions; and (b) when did the dispute first occur.
(2) Since when have there been difficulties in obtaining installation of PABX systems as a result of the dispute.
(3) When was the Minister informed of the dispute.
(4) What actions have been taken by the Department and the Minister in order to resolve the dispute.
(5) When were each of those actions taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. (a) The letter referred to work bans applied by staff of Telecom Australia which prevented the connection to the telecommunications network of a new PABX for the firm All Seasons Home Improvements. (b) The bans were first applied by the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association (ATEA) in December 1980.
(2) Some difficulties have occurred between December 1980 and May 1981.
(3) The Minister was first informed of the dispute on 23 December 1980.

(4) and (5) Telecom met with the ATEA on a number of occasions since December 1980 in an endeavour to have the bans lifted and the Minister met with ATEA officials in late February 1981. Following that meeting with ATEA, the Federal Executive of the Association recommended to its members that the relevant PABX bans be lifted. In all States other than New South Wales that recommendation was accepted, the bans lifted and PABX connections proceeded since early March 1981.
In New South Wales the State Branch of the Association did not accept the recommendation and maintained the bans until 27 May 1981.
The PABX for All Seasons Home Improvements was connected to the network on 2 June 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In August 1977, before the Federal election in that year, did the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications say that plans were being devised for television translator stations to service Western Australia's north-eastern wheatbelt.
(2) Have any of the translator stations been built.
(3) On present estimates when will such stations be completed and operating.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications met with the representatives from Shires in the north-eastern wheatbelt area of Western Australia on 4 August 1977 to discuss the question of funding extensions to the national television services in the area. However, as far as I am able to ascertain the discussions were based on the concept of a single wide coverage national television service centered in the Becubbin area, rather than a group of translators. At that time a series of commercial translators was being proposed for the Eastern wheatbelt area.

(2) Yes. A commercial translator station to serve Merredin was constructed late in 1980 and ran on a test basis for several weeks. Difficulties experienced in providing an adequate input signal from the parent station VEW-8 Kalgoorlie to the translator prevented the licensee from commissioning the service. The licensee is currently negotiating with Telecom Australia for the provision of microwave link facilities to provide the program to Merredin and the other proposed translators.
(3) On the basis of the impending availability of the link facilities, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has directed the licensee to commence the services by the following dates:
Merredin-no later than 30 September 1981
Baandee-no later than 30 November 1981
York-no later than 31 December 1981
Tammin-no later than 31 December 1981
Kollyanobbing-no later than 31 January 1982
Southern Cross-no later than 28 February 1982
Meckering-no later than 31 May 1982.
Plans for the extension of the national service to the area are subject to a Government decision concerning levels of funding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the agreement worked out between the Premier of Queensland and the Federal Government concerning funding of the Queensland hospital system.
(2) Was it a condition of the agreement that the free hospital system in Queensland be dismantled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the health grants arrangements to apply in 1981-82, as incorporated in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981, each State except South Australia and Tasmania will receive 10 per cent more than the amount payable to it in respect of 1980-81 under the hospital cost sharing arrangements, less 60 per cent of the amount of revenue which it is assessed by the Commonwealth as being capable of raising in 1981-82 at certain levels of charges. Under this arrangement it is estimated that Queensland would experience a proportionately larger reduction in health grants in 1981-82 than any other State. Accordingly, the Commonwealth Government agreed to provide, for 1981-82 only, a $16m grant to help 'cushion' the changes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Member for Herbert recently give public approval to the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee to abandon a major Commonwealth building project in Townsville.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There has not been a decision to abandon the Commonwealth building project in Townsville. In pursuit of its objective of reining in Government expenditure the Government has taken a decision that no funds will be made available in the coming financial year for a number of building projects, including the Townsville Commonwealth offices.
The Member for Herbert has informed me that he is intensely disappointed that there has been delay in the funding for this project.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has a decision been taken to abandon some of the work on the international airport in Townsville; if so, did the member for Herbert give public approval for this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The extent of works necessary to enable the introduction of such services was identified by working groups led by officers of my Department. However, in order to achieve the deadline for commencement of the Qantas service, it was decided to broadly divide the project into those works needed immediately to enable the service to commence and those which could be deferred and undertaken while the service was operating.
I have had the utmost co-operation of the member for Herbert in developing Townsville as an international gateway.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Communications in answer to Question on Notice No. 417 say: increased investment in the trunk network for both circuits and switching is planned to progressively improve the situation but it will be some two years before a standard grade of service can be re-established generally (see Senate Hansard, page 2051, dated 14 May 1981).
(2) What are the details of this proposed 'progressive improvement'.

(3) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that waiting lists in Penrith, Gosford, Kempsey, Lismore, Rockhampton, Cairns, Townsville and the Gold Coast will not grow and that in fact they will progressively improve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Telecom has programmed funds for improvements in the trunk area of the network in 1981-84 which represents a significant increase in expenditure over that of past years. The new trunk switching and transmission equipment is designed to increase the trunk network capacity and to reduce network congestion and bring about an improvement in grade of service to the customer. The program includes major expenditure on main route systems, extensions to capital city trunk exchanges, minor switching centres and the provision of additional short distance trunks at many points throughout the network. Local problems will remain as it will take some two years before a standard grade of service can be re-established generally.

(3) No. Demand for Telecom services has been running at very high levels over the past two years and this trend is expected to continue. Special attention is being given to high growth areas including those mentioned in the question. However, having regard to the level of demand and the necessity to restrict the level of borrowings available to Telecom, the waiting list is likely to grow over the next twelve months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Health recognise acupuncture as a legitimate method of medical treatment; if so, why does the Department discriminate against this form of treatment by requiring acupuncture patients to claim under Item 980 in the Schedule of Benefits.
(2) Does this procedure limit the benefit payable to $8.50, while a prolonged consultation involving acupuncture will cost a patient many times this amount.
(3) Does this situation have the effect of discouraging people from seeking acupuncture treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department has reservations about the role of acupuncture in medicine and about the manner in which it is being practised. Nevertheless, because of its widespread use, acupuncture rendered by a legally qualified medical practitioner is recognised as a legitimate medical service for the purposes of payment of medical benefits. This form of treatment is not discriminated against by the Department. In fact a new item (Item 980) was introduced into the Medical Benefits Schedule on 1 April 1981 specifically to cover this service.
(2) The fee for Item 980 has been set at the level of a standard surgery consultation by a general practitioner which is as follows:
New South Wales-$11.20
Victoria-$9.90
Queensland-$9.90
South Australia-$9.90
Western Australia-$9.90
Tasmania-$10.40

The reason for equating the fee for this service to that of a standard consultation was that a review of recent literature indicated that the effect from acupuncture does not depend on a lengthy attendance by the practitioner.

(3) No. It is expected that this action will tend to overcome the abuse of the previous medical benefits arrangements where it had been found that some medical practitioners had been providing treatment to more than one patient at the one time and where there had been frequent charging for acupuncture treatment under prolonged consultation items when the practitioner had not been in constant attendance with the patient for the times specified in those items.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the biographical detail of Mr McManus, a member of the Ethnic Radio Implementation Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The composition of the Ethnic Radio Implementation Committee was altered in July 1980. Mr McManus was not appointed to the new Committee. It would therefore seem inappropriate for me to disclose Mr McManus's biographical details.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Female Carriage Cleaners: Sydney Metropolitan Railway System

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role is the Department of Industrial Relations playing in the investigation of allegations that sexual harassment is applied to female carriage cleaners in the Sydney metropolitan railway system.
(2) Which Conciliation Commission has been entrusted with any investigation contemplated into these allegations.

(3) Have any (a) assessors; (b) advisors; or (c) consultants been appointed to assist the Conciliation Commission assigned to this mission; if so, (a) what are the names of such advisors and what are their qualifications; (b) what remuneration will they receive for their services; and (c) what authority will pay such remuneration to them.
(4) Will the proceedings of this inquiry be open to the public and what is the venue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The investigation is being conducted by a Local Industrial Board established under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Department of Industrial Relations is not involved in that investigation.

(2) Commissioner Walker of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is entrusted with resolving the dispute. He established a Local Industrial Board pursuant to section 44 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 on 9 April 1981 to assist him in this matter.
(3) (a) The Local Industrial Board comprises:
Ms Suzanne Jobson, Chairperson
Ms Dorothy Buckland, representative of employees
Mr Harry Shirlaw, representative of the State Rail Authority of New South Wales
Ms Jobson is a member of the Anti-Discrimination Board of New South Wales
Ms Buckland is a Commissioner of the Ethnic Affairs Commission of New South Wales
Mr Shirlaw is a retired associate manager, industrial section of the State Rail Authority.

(b) The Chairperson is paid a fee of $100 per sitting day by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If the sitting is for less than three hours in any day, the payment is $50. Payments for fees and expenses to Ms Jobson have totalled $2,677.63 to date.
The other members are, as far as is known, paid by the organisations they represent, but do not receive fees from the Commonwealth Government for their attendances at Board meetings.
(c) See (b).

(4) The Local Industrial Board's proceedings were not open to the public. A report of the Board's findings is due to be presented to Commissioner Walker on 16 July 1981. The course of the dispute and the question of whether the Board's report will be made public will be within the Commissioner's discretion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When approval is given for a domiciliary nursing care benefit is the benefit paid in arrears.
(2) Is the payment calculated on a daily basis.
(3) How many days' benefit does the carer receive if the person being cared for is put into hospital for four days in the fortnight.
(4) If payment is not made for each day the cared person is at home, what is the reason for non-payment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The benefit is paid in arrears in the sense that the care provided in a fortnight precedes the relevant payment.

(2) No. Following an amendment to the National Health Act (effective as from 4 September 1980) the benefit is calculated and paid on a fortnightly instalment basis. However, the legislation makes provision for the Permanent Head of my Department to direct, at his discretion, that a pro-rata payment (calculated on a daily basis) will apply, in individual cases, in lieu of the fortnightly instalment arrangement.

(3) If the period of absence falls entirely within a fortnightly pay period the carer would (other than in certain exceptional circumstances) receive a full fortnight's benefit payment. However, if the period of absence extends from one fortnightly pay period into the next fortnightly pay period, the carer would normally receive a full fortnightly pay period for the first fortnight but would not be paid for the remaining days of care in the second fortnight. In these circumstances benefit entitlement would recommence from the beginning of the next succeeding full fortnight of care.

In effect, where a period of absence extends from one fortnightly pay period into the next fortnightly pay period, the carer stands to gain payment in the first fortnight for days on which care was not provided but to lose payment in the second fortnight for the days on which care was in fact provided (following the patient's return).

The exceptions to these arrangements relate to the exercise of the discretionary pro-rata payment provision. The pro-rata provision would normally be exercised in circumstances where, by reason of regular breaks in continuity of care, the normal fortnightly instalment arrangements act to either maximise or minimise payment of the benefit to an extent considered inordinate.

(4) The reason for non-payment in certain circumstances, for individual days on which care is provided, is in the nature of the benefit being basically a fortnightly, rather than a daily benefit. It will be seen that, under the arrangements for payment of the benefit by fortnightly instalment, beneficiaries overall are in a break even situation although, individually, they may stand to gain or lose some days' benefit throughout their period of eligibility.

Should the honourable senator have a particular case in mind he may wish to provide me with further details in order that the question of exercising the discretionary pro-rata payment provision, to the carer's benefit, may be examined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Program of Aids for the Disabled

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Program of Aids for the Disabled (PAD) be in operation before 30 June 1981; if not, what will happen between the end of June and the allocation of 1981-82 funds in the forthcoming Budget.
(2) How many people does the Minister expect will be eligible for the PAD scheme and how are these figures arrived at.
(3) If the original allocation of $700,000 was intended to cover a 3 month period is an annual allocation likely to be four times that amount.
(4) How will the total be divided among the States.
(5) What proportion of the original allocation has been offered to the States to cover administrative costs.
(6) What sort of consultation was undertaken with disabled persons organisations before the program was announced.
(7) What consultation is planned for the future.
(8) Is it intended that the aids and appliances become the property of the user or be supplied on loan.
(9) Will the Minister supply a full list of approved items under the program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As announced in my press statements of 8 and 17 June 1981, the Program of Aids for Disabled People (PADP) has already commenced in four States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. I am hopeful that the other States will agree to participate without further delay. As is usual practice in relation to ongoing funding programs, funds will be available for disbursement to participating States and Territories from 1 July 1981, in respect of the 1981-82 financial year.

(2) It is not possible to estimate with precision the likely level of demand on PADP, which relates to disabled people who are not eligible for assistance under existing Government programs. However, the recommendations for the establishment of the Program were based on estimates that 40,000 disabled people would be eligible for assistance over the period 1 July 1981 to 30 June 1983.
(3) The 1981-82 Appropriation will be determined in the Budget context.
(4) Generally on a population basis.
(5) The States and Territories have been offered a loading of 15 per cent on the cost of aids issued.

(6) Before the PADP was announced, contact took place over a number of years with a variety of organisations concerned with disabled persons in an endeavour to obtain estimates of the numbers of persons in need of aids who are not eligible for assistance under current arrangements and details of unit costs for the various aids. Advice was also received from an expert committee consisting of specialists in rehabilitation of the disabled.
(7) It is proposed that regular consultation take place with the Australian Council on Rehabilitation of Disabled.
(8) Insofar as the Commonwealth is concerned aids issued under PADP become the property of the recipient, except in the case of:
wheelchairs, which are issued on indefinite loan;
equipment supplied in connection with the provision of domiciliary oxygen, which is hired;
home modifications in cases where the recipient is not the legal owner of the premises modified.
(9) The following is a list of aids available under PADP:

Home modifications: access ramps; door widenings; modification of toilets, baths and laundries; provision or modification of shower recesses, wash basins, cabinets, shelving, benches, taps, handles, power outlets and light fittings; provision of internal and external hand rails or grips.
Wheelchairs: manual and motorised.
Orthoses: braces; splints; calipers; surgical corsets and surgical shoes.
Domiciliary oxygen
Surgical wigs
Artificial breast forms
Electrolarynxes
Aids for incontinence: urinals; catheters; tubing; connections; drainage bags and bottles; waterproof covers.
Walking aids: walking frames; walking sticks and crutches.

Personal aids: the following items may be custom built or specially modified-crockery; cutlery; cooking utensils; toilet articles; tables; chairs; stools; portable steps/ramps; commode and shower chairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the revised position of the Australian domestic satellite east of Australia result in a lower signal strength at Western Australian receivers.
(2) Will the 'footprint' still include Western Australia's southwest.
(3) Is it intended that the new position of the satellite will facilitate use of the satellite by other nations in the southwest Pacific.
(4) Will the new position of the satellite facilitate the transmission of data between Australia and the US.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In early preliminary planning for an Australian satellite system the orbital position of the satellite was postulated to be 128 degrees (above the equator, approximately in line with the Western Australian/South Australian border). As planning firmed, a position at about 160 degrees E was preferred and this was the basis for the Request for Tender (RFT) for the satellite system issued in October 1980. The selection of this orbital position was supported by two overseas satellite system consultants engaged to evaluate the RFT documentation prior to release.

From the more easterly position Australia (and Western Australia) 'looks' smaller so that the signal transmitted from 160 degrees E can be concentrated into a smaller beam. As a result the strength of signals received in Western Australia under clear sky conditions will be increased by some 35 per cent (and by 17 per cent in the eastern states) compared with signals from a satellite positioned at 128 degrees E. Despite any increased signal attentuation by path loss and rain, there will nevertheless be a net gain in signal strength received in Western Australia. Moreover, the signal strength received in Western Australia will be comparable with that received in eastern states, which would not have been the case with a satellite at 128 degrees E.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Request for Tender called for coverage of the Australian mainland, Tasmania and certain offshore territories. It also asked for information concerning the possibility of providing coverage for Papua New Guinea should this be required. The possibility of providing services to South Pacific countries was investigated during the preliminary design phase. It was decided, on the grounds of increased cost and diminished services to Australians, that it would not be practicable to provide coverage for South Pacific countries in the first generation Australian satellite system, but these needs would be considered in planning for later generation systems.

(4) The national communications satellite system is designed to provide communications services within Australia. International communications are provided by OTC (A) through the INTELSAT satellite system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government providing any relief to the famine stricken regions of the Hebei and Hubei provinces of China affecting some five million people; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In Hubei and Hebei provinces a total of 43.2 million people were affected by natural disasters with over 20 million most seriously affected.

The Chinese Government sought international aid through the United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation (UNDRO) which approached the Australian Government for assistance for the flood and drought victims concerned.
In response to the appeal the Australian Government agreed to the provision of medical supplies, valued at $100,000 and 10,000 tonnes of wheat currently valued at $1.5m.

In accordance with the wishes of the Chinese Government the gift of medical supplies was delivered to Peking and handed over to the Chinese authorities on 17 June 1981. Arrangements are being finalised to ship the 10,000 tonnes of wheat in July 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a shortfall of skilled technical staff in Telecom for 1980-81. If so, approximately what is this shortfall.
(2) Why has it occurred.

(3) Are demands for technical services met at present by increases in overtime. If so, what money has been paid in overtime and approximately how much of that amount could be saved by employing more technical staff.
(4) Is the exchange network depleted and if so what are the details and what areas are worst hit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Shortfalls of suitably qualified Telecom technical staff have been experienced in two States, New South Wales and Queensland, during 1980-81. In New South Wales actual levels were up to 90 below plan but the shortfalls had been largely overcome by the end of the year as a result of concerted recruitment and training efforts. In the case of Queensland there were shortages in the order of 180 during the first two quarters but there was a downward adjustment of staffing levels at mid-year owing to demand levels, whilst still very strong, being lower than initially predicted.
(2) The main reason for the shortfalls has been the unprecedented level of demand in New South Wales and Queensland.

(3) There has been some increase in the usage of overtime as a result of the shortfalls outlined above but it is impossible to quantify precisely what proportion of overtime expenditure is attributable to this factor. In view of the fact that the shortfalls have occurred despite all possible recruitment and training initiatives it would not have been possible to reduce overtime payments by employing additional technical staff.

(4) The exchange network has not been depleted as a result of the shortfalls in Technical staff experienced in New South Wales and Queensland. The initial impact of any shortfalls in Technical staff would be in the new customer services area rather than in the exchange network area. Unprecedented demand can also affect the exchange equipment installation programme when equipment ordering programmes take a short time to catch up with actual requirements. This can also result in delays in the provision of new customer services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 149) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the letter in the opening part of Volume 1 of the Holcroft report. The third paragraph states:

In your initial meeting with us in June 1980, you emphasised that you had been assured by both airlines that the inquiry could expect to receive their full and willing co-operation and that the same could be expected from your own Department.

The next paragraph stated that the Department of Transport was unhelpful and that the Bureau of Transport economics failed to make a submission. What disciplinary action is the Government proposing to take against this lack of performance by its two bodies?
The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The letter in Volume 1 of the Holcroft report to which the senator referred expressed the view that the committee found it unhelpful that the Department of Transport's submission was not received until 10 December 1980.

The committee also mentioned in the letter that the Bureau of Transport Economics did not make a submission to the inquiry. The question of assistance to the Holcroft inquiry was a matter which the Bureau itself decided. The BTE has advised that the possibility of a submission was canvassed with both members and the Secretary of the inquiry on separate occasions. Inquiry members were told that a submission would only be made if the BTE was convinced that its work would significantly contribute to the inquiry's task. In the event, the BTE executive was not convinced this was the case and decided not to make a submission.
However, the BTE did hold wide ranging discussions with the inquiry and its staff. In addition, two BTE officers joined the inquiry staff on secondment.

Officers of both the Department and the BTE co-operated with the inquiry and its staff whenever asked. Both bodies responded to all requests made of them by the inquiry as soon as was possible within available resources. The Government believes that in its acceptance of the broad principles contained in the Holcroft report's recommendations comments brought against it on this matter have been effectively countered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 317) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: No doubt the Minister representing the Treasurer is aware that in some countries a personal income tax return is required to be submitted only once in every two years. The income tax paid in the second year is based upon the tax paid in the first year and an adjustment is made when the next return is submitted. No doubt the Minister is well aware that Switzerland is one such country. It is a country whose economy and inflation rate Australia could well attempt to copy. Will the Minister therefore ask the Treasurer to consider implementing a similar system in Australia with a view to the obvious economies it would bring within the Australian Taxation Office?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A system of submitting personal income tax returns on a biennial basis would contrast markedly with our taxation system which, in common with those of most Western countries, requires tax to be paid on income in the year in which that income is derived.

A biennial lodgment system would give rise to complications in the well established arrangements for the completion, lodgement and processing of income tax returns, and the assessment and collection of income tax and would involve a substantial first year cost to the revenue. It would not appear to provide significant administrative economies.
In the circumstances I would not wish to disturb the Australian taxation system in the manner suggested.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 493) Senator Gietzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the seizure of doctors' files by Australian Federal Police.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

Yes, my attention was drawn to the article headed 'Scandal over Police Seizure of Doctors' Files' in the issue of the Bulletin of 17 March 1981. The Commonwealth Crimes Act empowers the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to obtain and execute search warrants for the purposes of obtaining evidentiary material. The arrangements under the Act apply in respect of material and records relevant to any suspected fraud involving Commonwealth moneys, including those arising under the Health Insurance Act.

No-one wishes to cause any increased worry or suffering for patients, and the issue has been the subject of a number of separate Government considerations. When documents have been seized the AFP are very conscious of the need to maintain confidentiality and security of those documents.
The procedures followed by the AFP were set out in the answer provided by the Minister for Administrative Services to Question No. 172 asked by Senator Colston (Hansard, 25 February 1981, page 142):

'I am informed that the Australian Federal Police are not empowered to confiscate medical records; but by virtue of a search warrant issued vide Section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914, they are empowered to seize records which may be of evidentiary value relating to the commission of an offence. Documents of evidentiary value are maintained in police custody until the conclusion of any subsequent court hearing.

(a) and (b) I am informed that in view of the confidential nature of the doctor/patient relationship, the following specific instructions relating to seized medical records have been issued to all members of the Force.
(1) All records seized are to be marked and entered as an exhibit and stored in safe storage.

(2) All records will be photocopied, the photocopies being given to the doctor concerned as soon as possible. If before the supply of photocopies, a doctor urgently needed records for patient treatment, every effort is to be made to respond to the need by supplying photocopies of the required records.

(3) A patient whose medical record has been seized may wish to seek information as to why his/her record was seized. A request for this information is to be directed through the Commissioner's office.
(4) All original records are to be kept in lockable cabinets.
(5) Keys to cabinets holding the records are to be restricted to no more than two persons.
(6) Records which are no longer required are to be returned to the doctor as soon as possible.
(7) The contents of all records are to be treated with the utmost confidentiality.
(8) Any movement of the records is to be recorded.
(9) A member or other person is to sign for records given into his/her possession.
The President of the AMA has seen the above instructions and has expressed his agreement with them.'

The Minister for Administrative Services has also supplied information on discussions between the President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr L. L. Wilson, and the Commissioner of the AFP, Sir Colin Woods, on 20 August 1980 on police procedures relating to the enforcement of the Health Insurance Act. These discussions took place following representations made to the AMA by psychiatrists through the Royal College of Psychiatrists in Australia.
A joint press statement was released after the discussions. The Statement includes:

'Dr Wilson and the Commissioner said: ''Both the AMA and the Australian Federal Police accept that the primary consideration is the protection of the public (in this case doctors' patients) and not that doctors should have any special privilege or protection in regard to the enforcement of the law.''

Dr Wilson said: ''For the first time I have had access to the internal guidelines adopted by the Police for the procedures police officers should follow if they are directed to make inquiries of a medical practitioner, which, if complied with, will help to reduce anxieties held by practising doctors.''

''I have been reassured that the guidelines will be strictly adhered to and, in addition, Sir Colin has advised me that he will take careful account of the representations we made and further ensure that the confidentiality of patient records is respected and not jeopardised by Police action.''

''This is our main area of concern and, in cases involving Police inquiries, there is the need for the police to recognise the importance of a doctor being able to continue to meet the needs of his patients.''

Dr Wilson added: ''We are not out to protect doctors from the normal processes of law if they are committing frauds and it is not the AMA's wish to hinder Police in their efforts to detect such cases.''

Sir Colin Woods said: ''The Australian Federal Police have agreed to look closely at the existing guidelines with a view to amplifying any points that require emphasis in our efforts to reduce-if not remove entirely-the causes for concern by the medical profession and the AMA in particular.''
''It is vital that Police Officers conducting an inquiry in no way impinge upon-or are seen to make-clinical judgements.''

''It is equally important that any Police enquiry should be strictly confined to specific matters and the relevant records so as to remove complaints about widespread seizures and the consequent upheaval in the doctor's practice.''

''I am anxious that the police should be responsive to the needs of the profession-and those in its care-and I have invited the AMA to be represented at the next meeting of the Australian Federal Police Divisional Heads, set down for mid-October when I shall reiterate both the guidelines and the agreement reached today. I am delighted that Dr Wilson has accepted the invitation and will attend personally.''
Dr Wilson addressed the meeting of Federal Police Divisional Heads on 16 October. His address was reported in pages 12 and 13 of the AMA Gazette of 6 November 1980.

In his address, Dr Wilson reaffirmed the Association's condemnation of health insurance frauds committed by doctors. He referred to a genuine conflict of interest situation between the roles of doctors in maintaining the confidentiality of their doctor/patient relationship and those of the police in investigating frauds. He said that if the guidelines laid down by the police for handling seized patient records were strictly adhered to 'they will go a long way toward reducing the anxieties held by practising doctors.'
The Attorney-General, in referring the matter of privacy to the Australian Law Reform Commission in April 1976, included a specific request in relation to health insurance records.

The Chairman of the Commission, Mr Justice Kirby, said in an address to members at a conference of the General Practitioners' Society in Australia on 23 March 1981, that the 'Commission has proposed a uniform regimen, requiring normally, judicial authorisation before such powers of entry, search and seizure may be exercised.'
He also said:

'It would appear to me to be too facile to say that a doctor's records should not be examined without his consent (or even his patient's consent), when investigating an offence alleged against the doctor or patient himself. Otherwise, we could be committing investigation and enforcement of the criminal law and breaches of statute to the consent of the very person under suspicion or other persons upon whom he may sometimes exercise influence.'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1981 (Hansard, page 658), Senator Townley asked me the following question, without notice:
