ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that in the area already proclaimed in the Kakudu National Park in the Northern Territory and in the area known as Stage 2 of that park there is possible mineralisation along a strip some 400 kilometeres in length, and that to date a very small proportion of that 400-kilometre strip has been fully examined for mineralisation? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the area will be fully examined and that mining with sensible safeguards will be allowed before any further proclamations are made to enlarge that park to an area which would be over half a big as Tasmania?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The full extent of deposits in the park is unlikely to be known for some time, although current estimates indicate that the Alligator Rivers Region contains about 80 per cent of Australia's known uranium reserves or some 13 per cent of estimated non-communist world reserves.

Government policy on further exploration and development in the park is that exploration in Stage I should not proceed for the time being. With respect to the Stage II area the Government's policy is that before this is incorporated in the park it will be declared a conservation zone and a strictly controlled exploration program under Commonwealth supervision will be allowed to proceed to identify the resources of the area. These arrangements are subject to meeting Aboriginal interests; a recommendation on the granting of the Aboriginal land claim over the Stage II area is currently being prepared by the Aboriginal Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 877) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Adminstrative Services aware of criticisms of the low standard of paper used by Government departments, in particular its acidic content which is causing the early deterioration of government records and which in future will seriously restrict the preservation and retention of archival material? Will the Minister investigate this situation and see whether higher standards can be required of paper manufacturers and suppliers to overcome this problem?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Contracts for supplies of paper are arranged by the Purchasing Division of my Department. These contracts are intended to service the needs of user departments where a substantial usage has been identified. A report recently brought to my notice indicates that the paper purchased under the present contract is of good quality and will last some 70 to 80 years. Retention after that time frame would require use of alkaline paper and it is expected that the alkaline paper would cost some 12 per cent more than the paper currently purchased.

With a view to extending the current contract to include alkaline paper an opinion has been sought from Australian Archives whether substantial usage of the paper is expected. This matter is still under review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 April 1981 (Hansard, page 975) Senator Mason asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Whatever the future prospects for uranium mining, I think it is pretty well established that with falling prices there is a difficult time ahead. Will the Government ensure that sufficient sums of money are deposited by Pancontinental, if it commences mining, in order to ensure that in the event of it encountering financial difficulties funds are available for environmental rehabilitation?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

In accordance with Government policy, if at some time in the future approval were given to the Jabiluka project, it is envisaged that development would proceed pursuant to the terms of a mining title granted under Northern Territory legislation. Insofar as uranium is concerned, the Commonwealth has a reserve power to ensure that, when granting a mining title, the responsible Northern Territory Minister acts on and gives effect to the advice of the relevant Commonwealth Minister. This means that the terms and conditions of any mining title granted for the Jabiluka project would be those determined by the Commonwealth in consultation with the Northern Territory Government and other organisations. These conditions would of course cover environmental rehabilitation with recourse to the supervising authorities to ensure that they are carried out.

In addition, pursuant to the provisions of the Northern Territory Uranium Mining (Environment Control) Act, the Northern Territory Government has wide ranging powers including requirements for the lodging of securities to ensure that mining operations are undertaken in a responsible manner.
I do not expect in this context there would be any difficulty in regard to future development at Jabiluka.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1387) Senator Mason asked me a question, without notice, relating to possible marine contamination following a leakage at the Tsuruga Power Plant in Japan.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) reported to the Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission (NSC) on this incident on 18 May 1981.

MITI's report concluded that inadequate design and construction of the storage structure as well as improper management of radioactive waste water were the main causes of the leakage, and the seriousness of the incident was compounded by human error. As a result, MITI has announced that the power company involved (JAPCO) must close its Tsuruga plant for six months and will not be permitted to resume operations until defective facilities and safety measures meet acceptable standards.

With respect to possible fish contamination, the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) and its Science and Technology Agency (STA) have advised the Australian Government that no fish caught in Tsuruga Bay were required to be impounded following the accident. An STA report filed on 18 May stated that neither edible fish nor sea water was contaminated by radioactivity, although an infinitesimal amount of radioactivity, well below safety standards, was detected in non-edible marine life.
Japanese officials have advised that they know of no instances in which fish caught in Japanese waters have been found to be contaminated by radioactive substances attributed to nuclear leakage.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April (Hansard, page 1452) Senator Douglas McClelland asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Treasurer or the Minister aware that a company calling itself United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd is widely canvassing investment partners in a film fund partnership venture which purports to give approximately a 400 per cent deduction on outlays using section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and states in its circulated document:
It is anticipated that a contribution of $10,000 this financial year will result in a deduction of not less than $37,500 and not more than $45,000.

Is the Minister aware that this type of proposal, which involves an arrangement precluding assignments, is disadvantaging those who are trying to work within the Government's proposed framework of a 150 per cent deduction on film outlays and is causing concern to those who are interested in investing in the viability of the Australian film industry? Will the Minister look at this type of partnership investment venture and others that are circulating when drawing up the Government's film investment legislation to see that those who want to assist in genuine investment in the Australian film industry and who want to work within the Government's guidelines as outlined at the last election are protected?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the matters referred to by the honourable senator.

Without commenting on the activities of particular companies or individuals, I can assure the honourable senator that care was taken in the development of the new taxation concessions for investment in Australian films to guard against their exploitation. In particular, the availability of deductions is to be limited to expenditure for which the investor is at true risk of economic loss. The concept of limiting the availability of income tax deductions to amounts actually at risk has not previously been adopted in Australia. Whether, and to what extent, it might prove appropriate to apply an 'at risk' concept across a wider range of provisions which give rise to income tax deductions is another question to which consideration would need to be given at the appropriate time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1551) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Ministers for Employment and Youth Affairs, Business and Consumer Affairs and Industrial Relations. I refer to the continued reported shortages in skilled tradesmen, particularly in the metal and engineering industries, and the effect on business of inter-union disputation and wildcat strikes. I ask: Is it not a fact that one of the consequences of such strikes has been to bankrupt many small businesses? Is it not a fact that in the case of the Newcastle State Dockyard, Evans Deakin dockyard, Brisbane, and Walkers Dockyard, Maryborough, such disputation was responsible for the closure of those yards and the loss of thousands of jobs at the yards and in supporting industries? Can the Minister say whether the militancy and disputation of certain unions has been a cause in the failure of employers to attract sufficient numbers of apprentices to make successful tradesmen? Can he tell the Senate whether it is a fact that the armed forces have no difficulty in attracting applicants of the required calibre for the same trades?
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

Inter union disputation and wildcat strikes can certainly cause financial losses for small businesses. Obviously, many small businesses do not have reserves available to protect them against this type of unexpected loss. In this situation bankruptcy can often be the inevitable outcome, with its attendant loss of employment opportunities.

The Newcastle State Dockyard, Evans Deakin Dockyard, Brisbane, and Walkers Dockyard, Maryborough all ceased the building of new ships several years ago, although some ship repair, (and building of fishing boats in the case of Newcastle) is still carried out. New ship building activities became uneconomic several years ago, and a major factor was rising labour costs compared with overseas competitors. The decreasing activity in the yards has indeed led to a great drop in the numbers employed.

While there is no shortage of apprenticeship applicants, there is certainly a shortage of apprenticeships offered by employers to meet this demand. Employers' ability to offer apprenticeships depends to a considerable extent on their financial situation, and employers facing the problems of militant unions, and industrial action are not always in a position to make apprenticeships available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1567) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Government considered negotiating with the union movement to introduce a 35-hour working week in return for the abolition of all penalty and overtime rates.
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No, the Government has not considered entering into such negotiations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1640), Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. How much will it cost to change the name on stationery, buildings and vehicles of Australia Post Courier to Australia Post Express, as has been proposed following the review of Government functions? How will the taxpayer be helped by this expenditure? How will the taxpayer be helped by the allocation of Australia Post Courier's non-mail business to less efficient private operators?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australia Post Courier service, which ceased operation on 30 June 1981, provided a messenger pick-up and delivery service for letters, documents and most classes of goods. The Express Mail service which commenced operations from 1 July 1981, will carry postal items only, as part of the mail service, providing lodgment at post offices (with an optional collection service) and an express delivery.

Because the Express service will be quite different, operationally, from the Courier service, the new service will have different requirements for stationery, buildings and vehicles which are not comparable with those facilities used for the provision of the Courier service.

Identifiable costs associated with the abolition of the Courier service include the removal of the external identification signs from Courier buildings, at a cost of approximately $1,000. As the removal of Courier decals from vehicles involved only the 'peeling off' of the word Courier, a cost has not been calculated for this exercise; however any cost would be minimal. No replacement identification signs are planned either for buildings or vehicles.

The cost of printing new stationery will depend largely on the form the Express service takes and the use which the public makes of the service. An interim supply of new forms has been printed at a cost of $17,000.

The expenditure involved must be viewed in the context of the overall purpose in abolishing the Courier service. In many instances the Courier service was handling goods not normally carried by the postal service. It was therefore competing in an area which the private sector can properly service. It is to the benefit of the taxpayer that Government withdraw from inappropriate involvement in commercial activities as this enhances the opportunities for private sector activity and real growth in the Australian economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1642) Senator Coleman asked me a question without notice. I undertook to check whether the Western Australian Government has formally approached the Minister for Trade and Resources or the Prime Minister in relation to the possible construction of a nuclear power plant, and to clarify whether there is any constitutional impediment to the possible construction of a nuclear power plant in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
Neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister for Trade and Resources has received a formal approach from the Western Australian Government in relation to the construction of a nuclear power plant.

I am not aware of any constitutional impediment to the possible construction of nuclear power plants in Australia. However, a recent review indicated that the Atomic Energy Act in its present form does not provide an appropriate basis for the development, regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia, whether in the Northern Territory or in a State. The Government therefore announced on 5 June 1981 that new legislation would be developed for this purpose, in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May 1981 as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, (Hansard, page 1957) Senator Colston asked me a question without notice concerning the greater provision by the airlines of direct flights between cities, thus by-passing Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The major operators were consulted and both have advised that direct flights have been introduced whenever traffic allows. Direct services between Melbourne-Brisbane; Melbourne-Coolangatta have been increased, while direct services between Tasmania-Coolangatta and Adelaide-Coolangatta have been introduced.

Direct Brisbane-Canberra services were introduced but were withdrawn when they failed to attract sufficient patronage. Nevertheless traffic on this route and on the Adelaide-Brisbane route is being monitored by the airlines and direct services could be expected to be introduced as soon as they became economically viable.

In recent years the airlines have taken positive action in the planning and construction of timetables to minimise the difficulties at Sydney as far as possible. Essentially, frequency of services to and from Sydney has been stabilised by the increased use of aircraft with larger seating capacity to match growth in originating and terminating traffic. In fact over the past two years the frequency of scheduled services between Melbourne-Sydney and Brisbane-Sydney has marginally reduced and will reduce even further with the progressive introduction of larger Airbus aircraft later this year.

I am sure every effort will continue to be made by the airlines to further develop city pair flights, obviating the need to transit Sydney, as and when market demand can economically justify direct services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2060) Sentor Walters asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, follows a question which I asked recently about tourist facilities for the disabled. Following the success of the pilot study conducted in Tasmania, I ask the Minister what progress has been made towards the compilation of a national directory of travel accommodation facilities for the disabled?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The contract for a nationwide survey and compilation of the national accommodation guide for disabled travellers has now been awarded to consultants, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled and the Australian Automobile Association. These organisations have established expertise and reputations in this field.
This guide, the first national directory of its type to be produced in Australia, will complement existing accommodation directories such as those produced by the automobile associations.

The guide will detail the accessibility of hotels and motels around Australia and will provide disabled people with a useful reference to those places where they can find suitable accommodation. It will also stimulate the tourist industry's awareness of the valuable contribution it can make to the integration of people with disabilities.
It is expected that the guide will be published early in 1982.
Reaction to the Tasmanian pilot study has shown that the national guide will be welcomed by disabled travellers from Australia and overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2068) Senator Mason asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice.

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of controversy in the United Kingdom as to the future of the $400m aircraft carrier Ark Royal, launched this week by the Queen Mother? Although the British Defence Minister says that Ark Royal will be completed as planned, speculation continues about the ship being converted to serve other purposes, mothballed or even scrapped. Does the Minister not foresee a similar controversial destiny for the Australian aircraft carrier now planned, because of the increasingly obsolescent nature of this class of vessel? In what way can a single aircraft carrier adequately protect the Australian coastline while at the same time requiring considerable periods out of duty for maintenance and refit? Why is the Government persisting with plans for this largely useless vessel, at a cost of at least $700m, when that sum could provide a complete flotilla of modern attack craft, such as the United States Pegasus class vessels, which are hydrofoil vessels, which can attack at 60 miles an hour and which have the very considerable strike capability of eight 'Harpoon' missiles to each vessel?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Platforms with capabilities for anti-submarine warfare are seen to be an important component of Australia's defence force.
The Government has announced plans to acquire a purpose designed helicopter carrier for anti-submarine warfare. Studies to assist the selection of a design are continuing.

The new vessel is to have potential for operating short take-off and vertical landing (STOVL) aircraft. The Government has not yet made any commitment to acquire STOVL aircraft. It does not plan to consider their purchase before 1983.
A new helicopter carrier will be one element-albeit an important one-of a much larger defence force with extensive maritime capabilities.
Small surface ships such as hydrofoils, armed with anti-ship capable missiles, are not alternatives to anti-submarine helicopters which will be deployed with any new carrier.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2070) Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction noted an article in today's Daily Telegraph under the title 'Our Rate of Home Ownership is Rising'? The article states that home ownership in Australia has reached 71.9 per cent compared with 49 per cent in 1949. Can the Minister provide the Senate with the figures of home ownership in other Western countries for the same period?
The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Yes, I have seen the article in the Daily Telegraph of 4 June 1981, titled 'Our Rate of Home Ownership is Rising'.
The information you requested is not readily available. However, the United Nations Statistical Year Book provides the following figures for comparative home ownership levels in recent years.
Home Country
ownership level
Per cent UK (1976) 51 Canada (1975) 62 USA (1970) 63 Japan (1973) 59 New Zealand (1976) 70 France (1975) 45 Federal Republic of Germany (1972) 34 Greece (1971) 71
The UN Statistical Year Book also shows a home ownership ratio of 67 per cent for Australia in 1976.
A special survey of housing occupancy and costs carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in August 1980 revealed a home ownership ratio in Australia of 72 per cent.
Although it is difficult to make direct comparisons over time and between countries the Australian level of home ownership is one of the highest in the industrialised Western World.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2071) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice, concerning the national conservation strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government fully recognises the importance of the development of a national conservation strategy incorporating the proposals outlined in the world conservation strategy. On 5 November 1980 the Prime Minister announced that he had written to State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and, following their responses, agreement was reached to establish a steering committee to co-ordinate the development of the national conservation strategy. The committee met on 16 June 1981 and approved an outline for development of a national strategy. Work on the strategy is now proceeding, co-ordinated by a Task Force established in the Department of Home Affairs and Environment.
To date one pamphlet has been issued on the world conservation strategy, announcing the intention to develop a national strategy. The public will continue to be fully informed as work progresses.
It is proposed that draft sections of the strategy will be prepared by experts, following wide-ranging consultations as appropriate, and presented at a National Seminar in December 1981.
It is planned that the strategy will be re-drafted and reviewed throughout 1982. The actual timetable will be determined by the national steering committee.
The community has a significant contribution to make towards the development of the strategy and non-government organisations will be fully consulted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2073), Senator Kilgariff asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications give the Senate any information concerning reports received of a rapid pulse-type radio interference, named the Russian woodpecker, to high frequency radio bands due to an over-the-horizon experiment being conducted by the Soviet Union? If this is the case, is there any possibility of having the interference, which has a considersble nuisance factor, countered as it could also possibly cost lives if at any time it coincided with distress calls in the outback of Australia, where this radio interference is most marked?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the radio interference caused by OHR systems. Recent reports from my Department's monitoring stations indicate that the interference is much less harmful in Australia than it is in other parts of the world. In fact, very little specific information is available that the transmissions are causing harmful interference to operating radio services in Australia, particularly to outback services.

The responsible authorities for safety communications in Australia have not observed any circumstances of significant interference on any of the internationally recognised radio distress channels. On the other hand, there has been some observation recently of OHR signals occurring on the Australia Inshore Boating Radio-communication safety frequency 27.880 MHz, though the extent has not been serious. However, on the basis of these observations, my Department has initiated communication with the USSR seeking their co-operation in avoiding interference to the 27.880 MHz safety channel. Further recent monitoring of this frequency throughout Australia suggests that the approach to the USSR has been successful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2614) Senator Button asked me the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and the Minister for Communications. Has the Government told the Australian Broadcasting Commission that its funds for the next financial year will be reduced by between 10 and 13 per cent in real terms? Will this occur through reductions imposed as a result of the so-called razor gang report, plus a 3 per cent reduction in non-salary allocations? At the same time has the Commission also been told, by the Department of Administrative Services, that it must vacate the offices at 164 William Street, Sydney, which are used as the headquarters of the ABC's news departments? Will it cost $600,000 for the ABC to vacate these premises? Will additional allocations be made to the ABC in respect of this cost? Where will the news department be relocated?

I have already answered aspects of the honourable senator's question concerning funding. The Minister for Communications has provided the following response to the remainder of the questions asked by the honourable senator:
Office accommodation at 164 William Street, Sydney is being extended on a month-by-month basis.

It has been proposed that the News and Federal Music Divisions of the ABC would move to a new building at 124 Pacific Highway, St Leonards. The St Leonards building has, however, recently been sold and is no longer available to the ABC. The ABC in conjunction with the Department of Administrative Services is examining other possible accommodation arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2200) and 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3027) Senator Sibraa asked me questions, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The questions concerned Lebanese migration. The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of reports that residents of Lebanon have travelled to Damascus to enable immigration applications to be processed. The Australian Embassy in Damascus reported on 18 June that it could not identify any religious or geographic group which had not been able to travel to Damascus.Indeed, many applicants found travel to Damascus more convenient and less dangerous than to Beirut. On 16 June 1981 the Australian Embassy in Beirut reported that few Lebanese were experiencing difficulty in travelling to Damascus.

Instructions have been issued by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to all posts likely to attract applications by people normally resident in Lebanon that they be considered promptly under normal migrant entry policy. This applies particularly to persons sponsored under family reunion policy to whom relaxed criteria apply.

There is reason to believe that the situation in Lebanon has improved considerably since the period of great tension in Zahle and Beirut. It is hoped that the continued efforts of external mediators and the Lebanese factions themselves will open the way to a peaceful solution.

I am aware that the number of Lebanese who unsuccessfully apply for migrant entry is relatively high. This is because few independent applicants have work skills and qualifications in demand and recognised in Australia. Many would be unable to find work here and would face long-term settlement problems if permitted to migrate.
The situation in Lebanon will continue to be closely monitored.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2203) Senator Tate asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question, without notice, concerning the duration of the Government's commitment to subsidise air fares between Melbourne and Tasmania by some $5m per annum.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
One of the results of the new air fare structure that was introduced in April was to redress the previous situation whereby long haul passengers had been subsidising short haul passengers.

Recognising the major increases in fares that the new air fare formula would bring on routes operated by Ansett Airlines Limited and Trans Australia Airlines between Melbourne and Tasmania and that alternative land-based modes are not available, the Government has set fares on these routes at 90 per cent of the formula and, in accordance with the approach recommended by the Holcroft Inquiry into this arrangement, but it will be reviewed when further changes to air fares are considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2251) Senator Elstob asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning burning products of aircraft cabin furnishings.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The investigation of aircraft furnishing materials by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) was carried out at the request of a working group set up by the Department of Transport to study the flammability, smoke and toxicity characteristics of aircraft cabin interior materials. The major airlines and CSIRO were represented on the working group. The CSIRO investigation added to the knowledge of the behaviour in fire of different cabin materials in aircraft, but in fact made no recommendation on those which should or should not be used.

The working group found that toxic gases as such were not the major hazard and that flame, smoke and superheated gases were more important considerations, bearing in mind the exposure times and concentrations generally involved. The research assisted the airlines in the future choice of materials yielding minimum smoke and toxic gas, for which there is no prescribed standard at present, either here or overseas.

I am informed that as aircraft are refurbished, the airlines, including Ansett Airlines of Australia, are using the latest materials available to reduce flammability and minimise production of smoke and toxic gases. However, at present there is no practical alternative to organic materials, either natural or synthetic, and as such it is not possible to develop a cabin interior that does not burn and produce some smoke and fumes. Other safety measures have been aimed at reducing possible ignition sources and facilitation of speedy evacuation of passengers in an emergency.
My advice is that the airlines are conscious of the dangers of post-crash fire and are applying the information which flowed from the CSIRO investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2411), Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the exchange rate. I undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer.

ANSWER.PARA: I note that a very similar question without notice was put to the Treasurer by Mr Kerin on 9 June 1981 (House of Representatives Hansard, page 3333) and I refer the honourable senator to the Treasurer's response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2413), Senator McLaren asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In what years, if any, has South Australia not received its proper entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Information from the River Murray Commission indicates that annual flow to South Australia has only once, in 1944-45, been less than that to which that State is entitled under the River Murray Waters Agreement.

During the severe drought in 1944 and 1945, the water passed to South Australia amounted to 938,000 megalitres, some 608,000 megalitres less than South Australia's annual entitlement at that time. However, the volume actually available to South Australia in 1944-45 was 1,272,000 megalitres, some 274,000 megalitres less than entitlement, as South Australia decided to hold back 334,000 megalitres in reserve in Lake Victoria in case of a continuation of the drought into the following season.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2504) Senator Grimes asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning funding of women's refuges.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government's concern for the provision of services for women, such as those mentioned by the honourable senator, has been clearly evidenced by the level of funding provided for them under the Community Health Program since the Government took office. For 1981-82, the States will be provided with increased general revenue grants which will include components equal to Commonwealth expenditure on such services in 1980-81, plus 10 per cent. Thus, the States will be provided with a level of funding adequate to make allocations to maintain current levels of activity of such services.

As I have already announced, the Commonwealth will not be attaching any specific conditions to these increased payments to the States for 1981-82. It is therefore a matter for the States to determine their priorities in the allocation of funds to services such as those mentioned by the honourable senator and, on that basis, it is not open to me to provide any guarantee such as that sought by the honourable senator. However, the Commonwealth expects the States to allocate an appropriately high priority to services for women. Indeed, the Prime Minister has specifically requested the Premiers to allocate funds to ensure that needs in this area are met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2922) Senator Young asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport a question without notice concerning photographic drivers' licences.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Despite the claims made for the inclusion of a photograph on drivers' licences, such a requirement, which would be both costly to the licensing authority and inconvenient to the licence holder, offers no more protection against fraud than the present system which relies on comparison of signatures. Moreover the means exist to fraudulently alter photographic licences and those most likely to do this are the very ones at which the proposal is aimed.
I am aware of the survey to which the honourable senator referred. I understand it was conducted for one of the organisations concerned with the production of photographic licence materials.

In July 1980 the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) endorsed in principle a report entitled Guidelines for Driver Licensing and Driver Improvement Programs in Australia prepared by a special sub-committee of its Advisory Committee on Road User Performance and Traffic Codes. The sub-committee had addressed the matter of photographic drivers' licences but did not recommend their introduction. Nevertheless, the matter will be kept under review by the specialists advising ATAC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2926), Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Government received the Dix Report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission? Will that report be tabled before the Parliament rises? If not, how many recess days can be expected to pass before it will be made available?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Report of the Committee of Review of the ABC was tabled in the House of Representatives on June 10, and, as honourable senators by now will be aware, it was tabled the following day in the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3021), Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the recent judgment in a defamation case of Bingham v. Australian Broadcasting Commission, relating to a report broadcast on the 'Nationwide' program, in which the jury found against the ABC to the tune of $35,000 damages. Has the Minister yet obtained an estimate of the additional costs to the ABC for its own and the plaintiff's legal fees and other expenses in the case? In the light of the finding of the jury that the 'Nationwide' report deliberately defamed the plaintiff, notwithstanding his protests, without bothering to conduct the most elementary of checks about its material, what disciplinary action is the ABC taking against Mr Hale and Mr Olle for their part in the proceedings? If no disciplinary action is being taken, why not?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
As yet there is no estimate available for the additional costs to the ABC for legal fees of either party, or other expenses in the case.
Disciplinary action against staff is a matter solely for the ABC. The ABC is considering this case, but as yet no decision has been reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3022), Senator Thomas asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the provision of information to Parliament and the public on the activities of the Australian Institute of Sport.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

During the establishment of the Institute in 1980, almost 50,000 information pamphlets, providing details of the Institute concept, location, organisation, sports available and facilities, were distributed throughout Australia. Organisations and agencies to which pamphlets were sent included:
2200 secondary schools and tertiary institutions
all national sporting associations
all Commonwealth members of Parliament
State-Territory Departments for recreation and sport
State-Territory Ministers responsible for recreation and sport
State-Territory Departments of Education
Careers Reference Centres in each State-Territory
Regional offices of the Commonwealth Department of Education
Press (sports writers), television stations and parliamentary journalists.

Pamphlets were also sent in response to the many enquiries about the Institute from members of the public. In addition, the establishment of the Institute received wide coverage in the print media over several months.

The Institute is currently working to produce an updated general information pamphlet and a sport-specific pamphlet for each of the eight sports offered by the Institute. These will be available to the general public.
Under the Companies' Ordinance, the Institute is required to prepare an Annual Return which, although not presented to Parliament, is available to the general public.

Officers of my Department are currently liaising with officers of appropriate Departments with a view to preparing a financial agreement between the Commonwealth and the Institute. This agreement will include provision for the Institute to prepare an Annual Report and financial statements for submission to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment for tabling in Parliament. These reports will also be available to the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3188), Senator Sibraa asked me a question without notice concerning mail delivered in the Belwood Aboriginal Housing Estate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Belwood Housing Estate comprises 12 houses and is situated a distance of some 3.4km road travel from the Nambucca Heads post office. Although the Estate is located within the street mail delivery boundary of that office, the 14 Aboriginal families who reside there have not been receiving deliveries of mail or telegrams.

Deliveries have not been provided to the Estate because one of the elders of the community indicated to the Postmaster, when approached two to three years ago about the introduction of a street mail delivery service, that the majority of residents preferred, for various reasons, to collect their mail at the post office. Since that time, residents have collected mail, and telegrams, from the post office and none has requested that mail be delivered to the Estate. Australia Post is not aware of any delays occurring to telegrams. Delays would be unlikely given the very frequent collection of mail from the post office.

There is no reason why a mail delivery service should not be provided to residents, if required, although at present, there are no mail boxes at any of the houses in the Estate. The Postmaster, Nambucca Heads, has contacted a member of the local Aboriginal Council, Mr Jarrett, who has undertaken:
to provide Australia Post with confirmation of details and addresses of all residents;
to ensure that house numbers are provided and displayed at each residence;
to ensure that mail boxes are erected at each house.
Telegrams, addressed to residents of the Estate, are now being delivered and Australia Post proposes to commence mail deliveries as soon as mail boxes are installed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: 'Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many copies of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75 were put into circulation before an injunction was granted against the publishers, Messrs Walsh and Munster.

(2) How many copies of the early editions of the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald containing extracts from the book were put into circulation before injunctions were granted against those newspapers.
(3) How many and which other Australian newspapers and magazines have published extracts from the book.
(4) How many and which radio broadcasts in various parts of Australia have transmitted material from the book.
(5) How many and which overseas publications have published and circulated material from the book.

(6) Is it the case that copies of the book are in the possession of (a) the Indonesian Government; (b) the United States Government; and (c) other governments whose relations with Australia are dealt with in the book.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am unable to say precisely. It would appear from documents produced under subpoena by the distributors of the book that approximately 660 books had been distributed to some 71 booksellers. It is believed that only a small number of those books have been sold.
(2) (3) and (4) I do not have this information.

(5) I am informed that the New Statesman published in the United Kingdom, the Papua New Guinea Times and the New Zealand Nation have published extracts or excerpts from the book. I am not aware of any other overseas publications that have published extracts or excerpts from the book.
(6) I am not in a position to say.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: 'Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75'

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Commonwealth officers, from the office of the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor or elsewhere, on or about 11 November 1980 deliver copies of a court order prohibiting publication of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75 to booksellers in Melbourne and elsewhere.
(2) Who were the booksellers so contacted, and by whom and when were they contacted.
(3) Were there other booksellers who were merely notified orally of the court order; if so, who were they, and by whom and when were they contacted.

(4) Were the court orders in question directed only against Messrs Munster and Walsh, the publishers, thus lacking any legal status as against anyone else; if so, was this fact made completely clear to the booksellers in question, or any of them.

(5) Were the booksellers in question, or any of them, requested to sign undertakings that they would not dispose of copies of the book; if so, what, if any, was the legal basis on which such undertaking was sought.
(6) Were the booksellers, or any of them, threatened with legal action, for breach of copyright or otherwise, if they persisted in selling the book in question.

(7) What was the justification for this intimidatory behaviour when the Government knew, or must have known, that many thousands of copies of the material in question were, in one form or another, already in circulation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On or about Tuesday, 11 November 1980 officers of the Crown Solicitor's Division in Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Perth, Hobart and Canberra contacted all booksellers whom it was believed had received copies of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75. Some booksellers in Melbourne were shown copies of the court orders obtained by the Commonwealth again the publishers of the book, Richard Walsh and George Munster.

(2) and (3) Contact was made with approximately 71 booksellers whose names appeared on invoices produced by the distributors of the book under a subpoena issued out of the High Court on Monday, 10 November 1980. I understand, however that copies of the court orders were shown to only a small number of those booksellers. All contacts were made on or shortly after 11 November 1980 by officers employed in the Crown Solicitor's division.

(4) The documents shown to some booksellers in Melbourne were, at best, copies of court orders that had no legal effect against anyone other than Walsh and Munster. The officers concerned were instructed not to represent them as having any other effect.

(5) Most of the 71 booksellers were requested to sign written undertakings that they would not sell, distribute or otherwise deal with the book until the resolution of the proceedings commenced by the Commonwealth. The request was made in an endeavour to avoid having to initiate proceedings against a large number of booksellers. The undertakings did not have any other legal effect.

(6) In some cases the booksellers were informed that the Commonwealth maintained that sale of the books amounted to an infringement of its copyright and that the further sale of the books could involve the Commonwealth in taking legal proceedings.

(7) Undertakings were requested to avoid the necessity of having to institute proceedings against a large number of booksellers. A substantial majority of booksellers in fact signed written undertakings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 25-Report of the 1969 Workshop on Health and Nutrition of Aborigines; (b) No. 29-Departmental Manual of composition of Proprietary medicines; (c) No. 37-Financial details of medical and hospital funds; (d) No. 38-The register of health funds; (e) No. 39-Departmental surveys of medical fees; (f) No. 40-Departmental calculation of an index of health costs; (g) No. 41-Report 'Geriatrics Including the Frail Aged'-May 1966; (h) No. 42-Report 'Nursing Homes and Care of the Aged'-October 1966; (i) No. 43-Reports 'Nursing Homes'-January, September and December 1967; (j) No. 44-Report Nursing Home Benefits'-May 1968; and (k) No. 45-Report 'Care of the Aged in Australia'-December 1970.
(2) Which of the above-mentioned documents have now otherwise been made available.
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so, what conditions.
(4) Which of the documents does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. 37-Financial Details of Medical and Hospital Funds-In accordance with section 76A of the National Health Act (section 76A was included in 1970) an annual report 'Operations of the Registered Medical and Hospital Benefits Organizations' is tabled in Parliament and provides financial details of medical and hospital funds. It is assumed that this is the document to which reference was made.

No. 40-Departmental calculation of an Index of health costs-My Department has not calculated any index of health costs. It has however published a number of documents relating to total health expenditures and information of this nature is included in the Director-General of Health's annual reports. In June 1980, my Department released a document which provided an analysis of Australian Health Expenditure 1974-75 to 1977-78. A further extension of this publication is in preparation. In addition, a summary of Commonwealth estimates of expenditure as provided in Parliamentary Appropriations for Health is also prepared.

(2) No. 38-The Register of Health Funds-Section 73 (2) of the National Health Act requires that two registers 'The Register of Medical Benefits Organizations' and 'The Register of Hospital Benefits Organizations' be maintained. These registers contain the name of each organization, the State or Territory to which the registration relates and the date of the registration.
Section 73 (4) provides that-'A register shall not be open for inspection except by a person authorized in writing by the Minister.

The registers are not generally available because of this legislative restriction. However, any reasonable request for access would be accepted. In any event the names of all registered organizations are included in the annual report to the Parliament made under section 76A of the National Health Act.

It will be noted also that section 81 (1) of the National Health Act provides that the Director-General of Health shall publish in the Commonwealth Gazette a notice showing particulars of all subsisting registrations of organizations under section 73. Notification was contained in Gazette No. G2 of 13 January 1981.

No. 45-Report 'Care of the Aged in Australia'-December 1970-There is no restriction on the circulation of the material contained in this report and copies of it have been made available to interested parties. There are very few copies of the report currently available and, in any case, the material is now considerably dated. More recent documents include the 'Care of the Aged' report of the Social Welfare Commission (1974) and the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Care of the Aged and the Infirm which was tabled in Parliament in February 1977. Both these documents have been made available to interested parties.

(3) No. 25-Report of the 1969 Workshop on Health and Nutrition of Aborigines-It is assumed that this reference relates to 'Report of the 1969 Workshop on Health and Nutrition of Aboriginal Children'. This document was marked confidential in 1969 because it included extracts from a then unpublished thesis. Such a classification is no longer appropriate and a copy can be made available for perusal if the honourable senator so wishes. The material is, however, now dated.

No. 29-Manual of Composition of Proprietary Medicines-My Department does not publish a manual of composition of proprietary medicines. It does however produce a National Poisons Register Manual which contains extracts from the formulations of up to 40,000 chemical products including medicinal preparations, pesticides, agricultural chemicals and household products. This information is for use by hospitals and Poisons Information Centres in giving advice to medical practitioners actually treating cases of poisoning.

No. 39-Departmental surveys of medical fees-My Department conducted a number of ad hoc surveys of the fees commonly charged by doctors in the years prior to the issue of Mr Spigelman's book in 1972. The results were used in consultation with representatives of the health insurance industry to arrive at changes in the Medical Benefits Schedule. In the latter part of 1970 a continuing survey commencing with claims for the September quarter of 1970 provides for a wide range of analysis to be made including fees charged. The continuing survey also provides information needed by the Department for estimating the costs of individual medical services. It is believed that summaries of the methodology and principal results were made available as working documents for various discussions but there was no concise document which lent itself to issue as a publication in its own right. Information of the observance of common or Scheduled fees is published in the annual reports of the Director-General of Health. The information is restricted only where it may breach the confidentiality of the activities of individual health benefits organisations currently supplying the information to this Department. The information available can be examined at offices of the Department.

No. 41-Report on 'Geriatrics including the Frail Aged'-The paper referred to formed part of a report prepared in 1966 by a departmental working party on benefits at that time under the National Health Act. It is an out-dated report and only one copy is known to be currently in existence. Nonetheless, if the honourable senator so desires, a copy can be made available for his perusal.

No. 42-Report 'Nursing Homes and Care of the Aged'-There is no restriction on the release of this document which was prepared in 1966. The material is however very dated and only one copy is known to be in existence. Nonetheless, if the honourable senator so desires a copy can be made available for his perusal.

(4) No. 43-Three 1967 reports entitled 'Nursing Homes'-My Department has no knowledge of reports entitled 'Nursing Homes' prepared in 1967. A report entitled 'Nursing Homes' was prepared in 1972 at the request of a Committee of Cabinet which met on 22nd and 23rd May 1972. That report was considered by an Ad hoc Committee of Cabinet on 30 May 1972. Being a Cabinet document the report is not available for release at this stage.

No. 44-Report on Nursing Homes Benefits-The document referred to was prepared in 1968 for consideration during Ministerial discussions then taking place. In the normal course of events, advice relating to Ministerial discussions of this type would not be published. These discussions were an input into the considerations which resulted in the introduction of an additional supplementary benefit for nursing home patients requiring and receiving 'intensive' nursing care, now known as 'extensive care benefit'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were staffing levels at the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Darwin significantly reduced after Cyclone Tracy and have those staff never been replaced.
(2) Did the ABC recently conduct an investigation into staff levels in Darwin which concluded that more staff were necessary simply to maintain existing output.

(3) Did the investigation recommend the immediate creation of an extra Programme Officer position prior to implementation of the full report; if so, was the recommendation rejected by ABC Head Office Management, contrary to the advice of The Manager, ABC South Australia.
(4) Has no action yet been taken to implement any of the inquiry's recommendations, and was industrial action taken by Darwin ABC staff last year over the issue of relief staff.

(5) Have weather forecasts been pre-recorded on Darwin ABC-TV during the recent cyclone season due to a lack of staff contrary to advice by the Bureau of Meteorology and a directive from the ABC's manager.
(6) Will the Government request that urgent action be taken to ensure the ABC services to the Northern Territory are not restricted through lack of staff numbers.
(7) Will the Minister direct that the ABC be upgraded in the Northern Territory to enable the service to operate on a comparative basis with the States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Staffing levels were reduced, but not to the same extent as reductions in other areas of the ABC.
(2) Yes.

(3) Yes. The staffing situation in Darwin had to be considered in conjunction with other urgent staffing requirements and within the limitations of the staff ceiling set for the ABC. Senior ABC Management appreciates the special needs of the Northern Territory and plans to make an additional Program Officer position available for Darwin although this will have to be done at the expense of another program area.
(4) As in (3). Yes.

(5) The ABC acts on advice from the Bureau of Metereology in determining whether live presentation of the Television Weather Service is necessary. On this advice the Television Weather was presented ''live'' on 11 March, the eve of Cyclone Max.

(6) The ABC is faced, like all Government departments and authorities, with a requirement to work within set staffing and funding levels. The provision of further services and resources for the NT will be determined by the ABC in the context of other urgent requirements and its overall resources. However, there are procedures for review available if a department or authority feels it is unable to meet its staff ceiling.

(7) Following a detailed investigation of the ABC's operations in the Northern Territory, the ABC has recently decided to give full Branch Status to the Territory, which will involve the upgrading of the position of Manager, who will work direct to the ABC's General Manager. In addition, there is to be a progressive review of the classification of several other positions and the creation of a number of new positions as and when possible. As stated earlier the ABC has also decided to create a Program Officer position to improve local program output.

Northern Territory services have been continually upgraded through the re-introduction of evening television news from Darwin on weekdays, increased local news and general programming from Alice Springs, the introduction of the remote area TV service, 24 hour a day ABC radio and a pilot scheme for aboriginal broadcasting in Alice Springs. Furthermore, the ABC will continue to produce national programs which specifically cover Northern Territory topics, such as a recent program in the popular ''Big Country'' series or on current affairs programs such as AM and PM.
A number of recommendations of the ABC Committee of Review have a bearing on services in the Northern Territory and will be given careful consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Transport aware of statements made by the honourable member for Mackellar, Mr J. J. Carlton, on 19 March 1981 contrasting the large amount of information available to the United States Civil Aeronautics Board with the paucity of information in the hands of the Australian Department of Transport.
(2) Is the lack of information in the hands of the Department of Transport and the public concerning the functioning of Australia's domestic civil aviation system to be a problem.
(3) Is any action proposed to remedy this situation; if so, what action is proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following reply:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of statements concerning the extent of information about airline operations which is obtained by the Department of Transport.

(2) and (3) The Parliament recently passed legislation which involves increased reporting obligations on the airlines and greater provision of public information. The Independent Air Fares Committee Act requires that Committee to determine domestic air fares for all regular public transport passenger operators. When issuing a determination the Committee is required to provide a statement of reasons for the decisions and such other appropriate information as would not prejudice the trade secrets of operators. The 1981 Airlines Agreement imposed increased reporting obligations on Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia in regard to their financial performance, the operation of the Agreement and their use of the consultation provisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the locally owned airports scheme and what government authorities are involved.
(2) How many airports come under the Local Ownership Scheme.
(3) Are they situated only in rural country areas or are they also in towns or cities of larger size.
(4) What larger communities operate such a scheme and what sort of funding do they receive.
(5) What is the overall cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth.
(6) Are there any airstrips which are leased, owned, or used by the Royal Australian Air Force within the scheme, or being considered for entry to the scheme.
(7) What are the responsibilities of local authorities participating in the locally owned airport scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan (ALOP) is a co-operative arrangement between the Commonwealth and the licensees of various aerodromes whereby the Commonwealth provides technical advice and financial grants towards the cost of approved aerodrome maintenance and development, subject to various conditions. One of the major conditions is that the licensees keep the aerodromes open for public use. The ALOP is administered by the Department of Transport in consultation with the Department of Finance with respect to Commonwealth grant allocations. Some State Governments also make a contribution. Other agencies responsible for Commonwealth functions such as Customs, Health, Immigration, Tourism, Environment, and Construction are consulted as necessary.
(2) 265 aerodromes presently participate in the ALOP-201 of these are eligible for both development and maintenance grants.
(3) Participating aerodromes are situated in larger towns and cities as well as country areas.
(4) The following communities with a population of 20,000 or more participate in the ALOP through the local authority indicated:
Toowoomba-Toowoomba City Council
Wollongong-Shell Harbour Municipality
Maroochydore-Maroochy Shire Council
Redcliffe-Redcliffe City Council
Albury-Albury City Council
Lismore-Lismore City Council
Orange-Orange City Council
Goulburn-Goulburn City Council
Dubbo-Dubbo City Council
Bathurst-Bathurst City Council
Caloundra-Landsborough Shire Council
Gladstone-Gladstone-Calliope Aerodrome Board
Ayr-Ayr Shire Council
Mildura-Shire of Mildura.

The Commonwealth provides all funds necessary for the provision, operation, and maintenance of all essential safety services such as communications, navigation aids, air traffic control, and rescue and fire fighting services. The licensees of these aerodromes are provided with Commonwealth grants towards the costs of all approved aerodrome development and maintenance works, usually on a dollar-for-dollar basis but grants of up to 100 per cent of costs may be provided in particular circumstances. The licensees also retain all aerodrome revenues such as lease income, rents, and parking fees.

(5) The overall costs to the Commonwealth of development and maintenance grants for ALOP aerodromes was $4.02m in 1979-80. Other costs were incurred by the Commonwealth in respect of its continuing responsibility for provision of the essential services mentioned in part (4) of my answer.

(6) No aerodromes presently leased or owned by the RAAF are incorporated in the ALOP or proposed for entry to the Plan. However, the RAAF is accorded free access to all licensed and Government civil aerodromes, subject only to operational limitations. Hence, the RAAF may occasionally use various aerodromes which participate in the ALOP.
(7) The principal responsibilities of local authorities participating in the ALOP can be briefly described as follows:
(a) to comply with the requirements of the Air Navigation Act and Regulations,
(b) to own, operate and maintain the aerodrome as a licensed aerodrome open to public use and to be responsible for safety and security,

(c) to make available areas on the aerodrome for transport industry users such as airlines, air charter operators, aircraft fuel suppliers, on fair and reasonable terms, and to enable performance of Commonwealth responsibilities such as defence, customs, quarantine, immigration and the provision and installation of the safety services listed in part (4) of the answer, without cost,
(d) to protect the aerodrome clearance surfaces and to create compatible land-use zoning around the aerodrome by such actions as are within their powers,
(e) to design and carry out the aerodrome works for which Commonwealth grants and technical advice are approved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How much money did the Australian Government spend conducting and paying incidental costs for the case Commonwealth of Australia v. John Fairfax and Sons, 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth brought three actions in the High Court as a result of publication of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-1975 or extracts or excerpts therefrom. It has paid a total of $14,330 to its counsel in the three actions. Other costs incurred include salaries of officials and the usual disbursements. It is not possible to ascribe a particular amount to any one of the actions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would be the weekly rate of pension under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 on 1 May 1981, if the minimum pension was adjusted to its 1974 value;
(2) What percentage of that rate does the present weekly payment represent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the first 26 weeks of total incapacity for work the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 provides for payment to an injured employee at a rate equivalent to his full pay sick leave entitlement. After that period weekly compensation of $105 is payable in respect of the employee. An additional $27.50 is payable in respect of a prescribed person (usually a spouse) wholly or mainly dependent upon the employee. For each wholly or mainly dependent child a further $13.10 per week is payable.

From 1 January 1974 to 15 November 1974 the weekly rate of total incapacity benefit payable to a single employee after the first 26 weeks was $43. From 16 November 1974 to 31 December 1974 that rate was $57. By reference to movements in the Consumer Price Index (Six Capitals) between the March 1974 quarter and the March quarter 1981, the value of $43 on 1 May 1981 would have been $92.24 and the value of $57 on 1 May 1981 would have been $122.27.
(2) The weekly rate of total incapacity benefit currently payable in respect of a single employee ($105) represents 114 per cent of $92.24 and 86 per cent of $122.27.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost in the year 1980-81 to the Commonwealth of providing pensioner health cards and associated fringe benefits to all: (a) age pensioners; (b) invalid pensioners; (c) widow pensioners; (d) supporting parent beneficiaries; (e) sickness beneficiaries; (f) unemployment beneficiaries; (g) special beneficiaries; and (h) sheltered employment allowance beneficiaries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Health has advised that the estimated additional cost to the Commonwealth in 1980-81 of extending to all persons in those categories mentioned by the honourable senator the same health and pharmaceutical benefits as are available to holders of Pensioner Health Benefit cards would be as follows:
(a) age pensioners $47.1m
(b) invalid pensioners $5.7m
(c) widow pensioners $5.0m
(d) supporting parent beneficiaries $1.9m
(e) sickness beneficiaries $0.5m
(f) unemployment beneficiaries $54.2m
(g) special beneficiaries $3.9m
(h) sheltered employment allowees $0.02m.

There would be further costs if other Commonwealth fringe benefits available to holders of Pensioner Health Benefit cards were extended to all persons in categories (a) to (h) above, but information on which to base reliable estimates of these further costs is not available in respect of sickness, unemployment, and special beneficiaries. In respect of age, invalid and widow pensioners, supporting parent beneficiaries and sheltered employment allowees, however, it is estimated that the additional cost in 1980-81 would be in the order of $5m.
These costs are based on the assumption that the usage of the concessions would be the same as among existing holders of Pensioner Health Benefit cards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are current quarantine procedures for live fish imports into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Live fish are imported in clear plastic bags packed five or six to a polystyrene container. On arrival in Australia the bags are removed from containers by quarantine officers and examined and the following quarantine procedures carried out where necessary.

Those species which are prohibited under the Customs (Prohibited Species) Regulations, Piranha for example, are removed, destroyed and preserved or held alive in quarantine pending final identification and possible prosecution under the Customs Act.

When fish arrive in cloudy, discoloured or apparently contaminated water, the quarantine officer may have the fish placed into clean water at the airport and dispose of the imported water after disinfection. On arrival at the importing premises importers are required to disinfect all imported water.

Bags of fish sometimes arrive containing a number of sick or dead individuals. The quarantine officer may order infected fish into quarantine for treatment, or if the condition is not treatable, he may have the fish destroyed.

Some bags have been found to contain snails, water weed or other contaminants. These are removed and destroyed or held for identification or, where necessary, the contents of the bag including the fish are destroyed.
When any significant problem arises it is reported to the country of export, and the exporter is warned to prevent any repetition.

An improved quarantine system has been developed by quarantine authorities and this system is now under consideration by the major fish exporting countries. It provides for licensing and inspection of exporting premises, transportation in clean water and a period of quarantine in registered premises on arrival in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to Chapter 8 of a report by the Electronics Industry Advisory Council (1980), which advises that: 'The (Communications) satellite proposal is a crucial 'one off' opportunity for the Australian telecommunications industry to become involved in an area of high technology with significant domestic and export market prospects'; if so, which of the Council's recommendations does the Government endorse and propose to carry into effect.
(2) What recommendations will not be implemented in full by the Government and why will they not be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Electronics Industry Advisory Council provides a very useful channel of advice to the Minister for Industry and Commerce on a wide range of issues relevant to its particular industry sector.

The Government has declared on a number of occasions its intention that Australian involvement in the satellite project be maximised. This has been firmly expressed in the Request for Tender for the national satellite system and has been the subject of extensive discussions between relevant Australian Government authorities, Australian industry representatives and tenderers for the satellite system. As a further initiative, a contract has been placed with an Australian consultant to investigate the scope for Australian industry involvement.

(2) All of the Council's recommendations are being given proper consideration. It should be noted that the national communications satellite system is planned to be operational in mid/late 1985. Evaluation of tenders for the satellite system will not be complete until late this year so that it is not possible at this stage to indicate which, if any, of the Advisory Council recommendations will not be implemented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what ways will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so, how much is it estimated that it will save.
