(3) In what way will those savings break down into component savings.

(4) Can the Minister give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the government more than would the same services provided from within the public service by salaried officers.
(5) If the Minister cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the government more money than they would save and if so what are the details.
(8) Has the Minister received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Studies are being undertaken to determine if there are any further functions which could be contracted out by organisations under my control. The extent of further contracting out will depend in part upon whether-
the private sector can provide the services more economically and/or conveniently or services might be more appropriately provided by State or local government under contract to the Commonwealth;
services are already provided by the private sector and using Commonwealth resources to undertake them would be to compete with suppliers of these services; and
performance of a new function or continuance of an old one would involve an unacceptable level of new capital investment or increased expenditure on salaries or services.

(2) At this stage it is not possible to quantify potential savings though it is anticipated that savings could be achieved through reduced need to buy or repair and maintain capital equipment and through reductions in the need for support services and other overheads.
(3) It is not possible to say at this stage.
(4) This aspect is being considered in the studies being undertaken.
(5)-(8) No extension of contracting out will be effected without considering all economic and other implications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current maximum Tertiary Education Allowances Scheme (TEAS) payment for (a) independent students; and (b) other students.
(2) When were these payments last adjusted.
(3) Which students receiving TEAS allowances also receive a payment equivalent to family allowance, how much is this payment and is this amount included in the payments mentioned in (1).

(4) What are the administrative arrangements between the Departments of Social Security and Education which take place to stop payment of family allowance to a parent and make an equivalent payment to students receiving TEAS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The current maximum living allowance payment under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) is:
(a) for independent students-$2,583 a year ($49.67 a week);
(b) (i) for students receiving living away-from-home rate-$2,583 a year ($49.67 a week); and; (ii) for students receiving living at-home rate-$1,675 a year ($32.21 a week).
(2) Maximum living allowances were increased by 10 per cent as from 1 January 1981, as part of the 1980-81 Budget review.

(3) Students receiving TEAS at the away-from-home and at-home rates (Category (b) (i) and (ii) above) receive an amount of $5.25 a week in lieu of the payment of family allowance to the parent. This amount forms part of the TEAS living allowance.

(4) When a student is eligible to receive a TEAS allowance at the away-from-home or at-home rates, computer processing of his application form produces a special advice form to be forwarded by State Offices of the Department of Education to the Department of Social Security.

The form contains sufficient information about the student and his parents to enable the Department of Social Security to identify them in their family allowance records. (Where family allowance is being paid to a person other than a parent, further liaison is sometimes necessary). The form also advises the date on which payment of the TEAS living allowance, including the family allowance equivalent of $5.25 per week will commence.

When the form is received in the appropriate Department of Social Security Office, action is taken in accordance with Section 95B (1) of the Social Services Act to terminate family allowance payments with respect to that student.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the onus on a 'disadvantaged' person receiving a card for free medical and hospital treatment to reapply for a new card at the end of a six-month period.
(2) Will those persons receive a reminder notice.
(3) Will the rules and instructions relating to the issuing of 'disadvantaged' cards be made public; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Persons in possession of a current health care card will be deemed to have applied for a new Card on the last day of the six month period covered by the old card.

(2) Before the expiration of the six month period coverd by each card, the Department will automatically issue each disadvantaged person with a form seeking such details as are required to determine a person's eligibility for a further card.
(3) The conditions of eligibility and matters of a procedural nature which people need to know in relation to claims have already been publicised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many appellants in each State in 1978-79 and 1979-80 received expenses for travel in connection with their appeals to Social Security Appeals Tribunals.
(2) What was the amount paid towards expenses in each State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistics on the number of appellants who were reimbursed for travel expenses in connection with the appeals to Social Security Appeals Tribunals are not collected.

(2) The amount paid in the way of expenses incurred by appellants is met by the various State administrations from their Petty Cash votes. Efforts were made to compile uniform and reliable national statistics on amounts reimbursed to appellants, but this collection was discontinued because of the lack of demand for this information and difficulties associated with obtaining a reliable dissection of the relevant amounts and relating them to appeals finalised in a particular quarter. Accordingly, statistics are not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are any registered Australian nursing homes owned by foreign interests; if so, what are the names of these nursing homes and their owners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Relevant Commonwealth legislation which governs the nursing home arrangements (the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974) controls the operations of proprietors of nursing homes for the purposes of Commonwealth payments.

Nursing homes are commonly owned and operated by Government and Local Government authorities, non-profit religious and/or charitable bodies, private individuals or companies. The legislation refers to a 'proprietor', according to the type of nursing home concerned, as-
(i) public nursing homes-the authority or body of persons conducting the nursing home;
(ii) private nursing homes-the owner of the business or undertaking carried on at the nursing home;
(iii) voluntary non-profit nursing homes-the organisation, body or other person carrying on the nursing home.

For the purposes of administering the nursing home arrangements, the 'proprietor' of a nursing home must be clearly identified. However, it is not necessary for the Department to maintain details of nationality of owners of nursing homes and it is therefore not possible to provide a conclusive reply in this regard. However, Departmental records do not indicate any Australian nursing homes are owned by foreign interests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is any applicant for a new telephone connection required to pay the full amount due on that connection before joining the waiting list for connection.
(2) Do poorer people in the community suffer more than others because of this policy in view of the fact that the amount due is often over $100.

(3) Would it be fairer, and more in keeping with the needs of those on low and moderate incomes to permit them to join the waiting list on payment of a deposit, the balance of which could be paid on connection.
(4) What amount of money does Telecom have at present which represents payments for connections by people still waiting to be connected.
(5) How much could such an amount yield annually if it were lent out at bank overdraft rates.
(6) Why has no effort been made to reimburse those waiting more than 2 months for interest on their connection charge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) Telecom seeks payment of connection charges for telephone services at the time of application as part compensation to Telecom for the heavy expenditure incurred in establishing the necessary facilities well in advance of actual installation. Payment of fees in two parts would not be appropriate as 70% of orders are completed within 15 working days and payment of fees in advance is not requested when an application for service is deferred, that is, where service cannot be offered pending major extensions of plant and/or availability of equipment.
(4) $4.8m (approx).
(5) If an amount of $4.8m were to be lent out at current bank overdraft rates, it would yield of the order of $750,000 per annum.

(6) See (1) to (3). Once a telephone service is in operation, the subscriber is often in a favourable position since, pending the rendition of an account, credit on calls and phonograms may be allowed for periods up to 4 or 7 months depending on whether the account is issued quarterly or half yearly intervals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the members of the review team assessing the need for social workers in the Department of Social Security and what is their expertise.
(2) Are there any social workers in the team.
(3) What is the team's terms of reference.
(4) Is the charter to reduce social work staffing.
(5) Has there been any evidence of over-staffing of social workers.
(6) Is it also intended to review the staffing level of Aboriginal welfare officers.
(7) When is the report of the review team expected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The review is being conducted by the Public Service Board, in consultation with the Department of Social Security. Two officers from the Department of Social Security (one of whom holds a Diploma of Social Studies) have been seconded to assist the Board with the Review.

(3) to (5) The review broadly covers the activities of the Department's social workers and welfare officers, against the background of the Government's decision that social work activity be confined to social work directly related to the delivery of Social Security benefits, Commonwealth programs and rehabilitation services.
(7) The tentative completion date of the review is 31 August 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What kinds of information will the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs regard as appropriate for the Commonwealth Employment Service offices to collect in relation to persons registered as unemployed: (a) derived from such persons, and (b) derived from other sources.

(2) Does the Minister regard it as legitimate or defensible, and if so, why, for material in relation to any of the following matters to be collected and placed in the file of a person registered as unemployed: (a) political convictions or affiliations; (b) membership of community action organisations; and (c) membership of action groups campaigning against unemployment; or (d) participation in demonstrations or literature distribution in relation to any of the above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) CES standing instructions stipulate that information on job seekers is to be factual and relevant to the type of employment sought. This information recorded is usually obtained from the job seekers themselves. In addition the records can contain some information provided by employers about the results of employment referrals and by specialist officers in, for example, the handicapped or youth employment areas. In all instances the criteria is that the information recorded is useful as part of the placement exercise.

(2) There are express instructions issued to CES staff stipulating that any material, or subjective comment, which is not relevant to the employment sought, is not to be included on a client's Job Seeker Details card.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the nature and extent of Commonwealth involvement in the Santos proposal at Stony Point on the Spencer Gulf, involving hydrocarbons piped from the Cooper Basin, the separation of liquefied petroleum gas and the establishment of a fractionation plant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Cooper Basin producers announced on 6 January 1981 plans to develop liquids production facilities at Stoney Point on the Spencer Gulf in South Australia. The facilities will supply LPG, condensates and crude oil to the Australian market with production expected to commence in 1983-84. The Commonwealth Government has given approval to the export of limited quantities of LPG from the Cooper Basin fields during the years 1984-1988 inclusive, subject to the terms and conditions negotiated being consistent with Government policy and subject to Australian demand for Cooper Basin LPG having been met.

Environmental impact requirements need to be met and will be examined jointly with the South Australian Government. A draft environmental impact statement was issued by the producers on 14 July 1981 inviting comment from interested parties.

The Commonwealth Government will also need to be satisfied in respect of the level of foreign investment as well as that the details of the disposal and pricing of the crude oil and condensate is in conformity with the Government's indigenous crude oil absorption and allocation policies.
